('31', 0, 1, 2, 40) 1. WHAT SHOULD BE DONE WHERE LIQUOR IS BEING SERVED?
('31', 0, 2, 3, 93) A gentleman asks in sorrow: 1
('31', 0, 3, 4, 123) I am not aware of liquor having been served at the garden party.
('31', 0, 3, 5, 188) However, I would have attended it even if I had known it.
('31', 0, 3, 6, 246) A banquet was held on the same day.
('31', 0, 3, 7, 282) I attended it even though liquor was served there.
('31', 0, 3, 8, 333) I was not going to eat anything at either of these two functions.
('31', 0, 3, 9, 399) At the dinner a lady was sitting on one side and a gentleman on the other side of me.
('31', 0, 3, 10, 485) After the lady had helped herself with the bottle it would come to me.
('31', 0, 3, 11, 556) It would have to pass me in order to reach the gentleman.
('31', 0, 3, 12, 614) It was my duty to pass it on to the latter.
('31', 0, 3, 13, 658) I deliberately performed my duty.
('31', 0, 3, 14, 692) I could have easily refused to pass it saying that I would not touch a bottle of liquor.
('31', 0, 3, 15, 781) This, however, I considered to be improper.
('31', 0, 3, 16, 825) Two questions arise now.
('31', 0, 3, 17, 850) Is it proper for persons like me to go where drinks are served ?
('31', 0, 3, 18, 915) If the answer is in the affirmative, is it proper to pass a bottle of liquor from one person to another?
('31', 0, 3, 19, 1020) So far as I am concerned the answer to both the questions is in the affirmative.
('31', 0, 3, 20, 1101) It could be otherwise in the case of others.
('31', 0, 3, 21, 1146) In such matters, I know of no royal road and, if there were any, it would be that one should altogether shun such parties and dinners.
('31', 0, 3, 22, 1281) If we impose any restrictions with regard to liquor, why not impose them with regard to meat, etc.?
('31', 0, 3, 23, 1381) If we do so with the latter, why not with regard to other items which we regard as unfeatable?
('31', 0, 3, 24, 1476) Hence if we look upon attending such parties as harmful in certain circumstances, the best way seems to give up going to all such parties.
('31', 0, 3, 25, 1615) Why then did I go?
('31', 0, 3, 26, 1634) Because I have been doing so for many years now and there was no special reason for not doing so on this occasion.
('31', 0, 3, 27, 1749) On such occasions I myself eat nothing or only fruit, hence I could satisfy my conscience that the part I had taken did not involve any impropriety.
('31', 0, 3, 28, 1898) I know that my participation in this manner has resulted in some persons giving up liquor and some others giving up meat.
('31', 0, 3, 29, 2020) This, however, cannot be an argument in favour of attending such parties.
('31', 0, 3, 30, 2094) I am stating how I satisfied my own conscience.
('31', 0, 3, 31, 2142) I would
('31', 0, 4, 32, 2150) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('31', 0, 4, 33, 2187) It referred to a garden party given by the Thakore Saheb of Rajkot on February 17, “where drinks were served”.
('31', 1, 0, 1, 2298) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 1, 1, 2, 2338) not be worried in the least if others act exactly as I do.
('31', 1, 1, 3, 2397) However, I am aware than, in following my example, others would not merely attend but also run the risk of not discriminating between what should be eaten or drunk and what should not.
('31', 1, 1, 4, 2582) I even know that this has actually happened.
('31', 1, 1, 5, 2627) Moreover, a third question arises, viz., how long should we be held back by such fears?
('31', 1, 1, 6, 2715) In brief, such questions are always most difficult.
('31', 1, 1, 7, 2767) Discretion should be used by each person in finding an answer for himself.
('31', 1, 1, 8, 2842) My advice is that in such matters where one cannot see one single way that is to be followed and where action contrary to mine is also proper, the best course for anyone who is ready to act as I advise, is to do as I ask him, disregarding what I myself do.
('31', 1, 1, 9, 3099) There is danger in imitating my acts.
('31', 1, 1, 10, 3137) Hence it is advisable that people do not go to places where drinks and meat are served, despite the fact that I do so.
('31', 1, 1, 11, 3256) There is no connection between my insistence on khadi and my going to a place where liquor was served.
('31', 1, 1, 12, 3359) It is not a fact that I do not go to any place where khadi is not worn.
('31', 1, 1, 13, 3431) I am firm with regard to the use of khadi at meetings or organizations over which I exercise con trol or where my firmness is not misunderstood.
('31', 1, 1, 14, 3576) In the durbar at Rajkot, not ever yone was clad in khadi; nevertheless I went there.
('31', 1, 1, 15, 3661) I do not like attending marriages and such other functions.
('31', 1, 1, 16, 3721) Hence, when anyone insists on my attending them, if possible I put down the wearing of khadi clothes as a condition.
('31', 1, 1, 17, 3838) All these are questions which involve discrimination and love.
('31', 1, 1, 18, 3901) A thing may be proper on one occasion and improper in another.
('31', 1, 1, 19, 3964) Man is a living being and not an inanimate object like a machine.
('31', 1, 1, 20, 4030) Hence, among human beings and in the acts of every one of them, there is variation, novelty, apparent contradiction, etc.
('31', 1, 1, 21, 4152) However, under the divine guidance of truth and love a discriminating observer could but perceive identity in difference, harmony amidst discord and unity in diversity.
('31', 1, 1, 22, 4321) Love without tolerance is not worth the name.
('31', 1, 1, 23, 4367) I acquire the right to plead courteously with a Muslim not to slaughter the sacred cow by tolerating such slaughter to begin with.
('31', 1, 1, 24, 4498) I acquired the right to bring up courteously the subject of prohibition at the Thakore Saheb’s gathering by suffer ing drinks being served there.
('31', 1, 1, 25, 4644) Would the Thakore Saheb prevent me from bringing up this subject even if I did not attend his party?
('31', 1, 1, 26, 4745) Someone may ask this question.
('31', 1, 1, 27, 4776) The answer is that Thakore Saheb would listen to me because he is polite, but while listening to me he would hardly pay any attention to the subject.
('31', 1, 1, 28, 4926) However, if I talk of prohibition in spite of having attended his
('31', 2, 0, 1, 4992) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 3
('31', 2, 1, 2, 5032) reception, he would give careful consideration to what I say and would not let my tolerance go in vain.
('31', 2, 1, 3, 5136) In conclusion, I should say once again that imitating me in this matter may be dangerous.
('31', 2, 1, 4, 5226) Hence those associating with me should beware of such imitation.
('31', 2, 1, 5, 5291) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 22 3 1925
('31', 2, 2, 6, 5328) 2. A TEACHER’S PROBLEM Khadi is compulsory in schools because its propagation is in dispensable for swaraj.
('31', 2, 2, 7, 5436) A teacher argues as follows against such com pulsion.
('31', 2, 3, 8, 5490) 1. A child being attracted by the colourful foreign clothes of the other members of the family and neighbours accepts khadi as something that is being thrust upon him and, in this way, he learns to practise deceit from his childhood.
('31', 2, 3, 9, 5724) If you claim that such a child would naturally choose khadi in a school where a majority of pupils wear it, rather than make it detested by making it compulsory.
('31', 2, 3, 10, 5886) it would be better to let the child be attracted to khadi naturally after it is admitted to the school and allowing some time for the process.
('31', 2, 3, 11, 6029) The word“compulsory” has been misconstrued here.
('31', 2, 3, 12, 6078) If atten ding a national school was compulsory and then the rule of wearing khadi was compulsory, perhaps it could be said that khadi was made compulsory in an improper way.
('31', 2, 3, 13, 6252) I use the word “perhaps” here because even when education becomes compulsory, certain conditions will still be there for admission.
('31', 2, 3, 14, 6384) It is difficult to say that such com pulsion is necessarily improper.
('31', 2, 3, 15, 6454) Certain subjects will be com pulsory for the pupils.
('31', 2, 3, 16, 6507) Moreover, it will also be required that they should be clean when they come to school, should not wear dirty clothes, nor come naked or with gay, multicoloured clothes.
('31', 2, 3, 17, 6676) Just becasue these are compulsory requirements, would anyone dare to say that they are improper?
('31', 2, 3, 18, 6773) I have the feeling that the question of compulsion and option arises only in the minds of those who are not firmly convinced about the necessity of khadi.
('31', 2, 3, 19, 6928) Whether parents approve of it or not, whether the attitude of neighbours is favourable or not, still we cannot but exercise control over children in some matters.
('31', 2, 3, 20, 7091) For instance, we shall
('31', 2, 4, 21, 7114) 1 The arguments are summarized here.
('31', 3, 0, 1, 7151) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 3, 1, 2, 7191) have to clothe a naked child coming from the jungles.
('31', 3, 1, 3, 7245) Afterwards, when it returns home, it may revert to its naked state.
('31', 3, 1, 4, 7313) If the child uses foul language, we shall have to stop it from doing so.
('31', 3, 1, 5, 7386) Every teacher would impose many such unavoidable restrictions, and, none of the arguments of the above mentioned teacher will hold good against them.
('31', 3, 1, 6, 7536) It is not a fact that wearing khadi had to be made compulsory because we did not succeed in making pupils wear it voluntarily.
('31', 3, 1, 7, 7663) It is because some persons like me think that the necessary atmosphere has not been created for making khadi compulsory, that spinning and khadi are being made compulsory in national schools.
('31', 3, 1, 8, 7855) Very often society accepts compulsion because although the spirit is willing, the flesh resists.
('31', 3, 1, 9, 7952) Hence, many difficulties will be solved if we understand the meaning of the word“compulsory”.
('31', 3, 1, 10, 8046) Compulsion is that which the rulers by virtue of their authority enforce on subjects in the teeth of opposition and under threat of punishment.
('31', 3, 1, 11, 8190) If this definition is accepted, there is no basis for the issue that the teacher has raised.
('31', 3, 2, 12, 8283) 2. Khadi which is worn with understanding, love and in a spirit of rivalary will be worn for a greater length of time.
('31', 3, 2, 13, 8402) Does the method of being patient for a few days rather than making the wearing of khadi compulsory on the first day serve the original purpose any the less?
('31', 3, 2, 14, 8559) Understanding, love and rivalry are necessarily involved in our compulsory use of khadi.
('31', 3, 2, 15, 8648) The burden of making it compulsory lies on the teacher, not on the children.
('31', 3, 2, 16, 8725) The former will not order them like a policeman, but use whatever skill he has in order to win over the hearts of the children.
('31', 3, 2, 17, 8853) We are not talking of making them wear khadi on the very first day but of making them wear it after four years [since the establishment of national schools].
('31', 3, 2, 18, 9011) The word “compul sory” or “obligatory” governs the action of the teacher.
('31', 3, 2, 19, 9085) It draws the latter's attention to his obligation.
('31', 3, 2, 20, 9136) Hence the question does not even arise whether the method of being patient is more or less conducive to the original purpose.
('31', 3, 2, 21, 9262) Patience is, or at any rate should be, the quality of a teacher.
('31', 3, 3, 22, 9327) 3. The rule making khadi compulsory proclaims that its voluntary
('31', 3, 4, 23, 9392) spread was unsuccessful.
('31', 3, 4, 24, 9417) This doubt has been resolved above.
('31', 3, 5, 25, 9453) 4. Will there not be an increase in the number of hypocrites because of this rule of compulsion?.
('31', 4, 0, 1, 9551) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 5
('31', 4, 1, 2, 9591) If the fear of hypocrisy is with reference to children, I do not recognize it.
('31', 4, 1, 3, 9670) Children are not hypocrites.
('31', 4, 1, 4, 9699) If it is in relation to teachers, the possibility may be there.
('31', 4, 1, 5, 9763) However, an element of hypocrisy comes in wherever a rule is observed with some vigour.
('31', 4, 1, 6, 9851) The remedy for this lies in purifying the atmosphere, not in making the rules flexible.
('31', 4, 2, 7, 9939) 5. Because of compulsory khadi, national schools would be only for those who have fulfilled the conditions for swaraj; what schools are there for those who have yet to be trained?.
('31', 4, 2, 8, 10120) There are two reasons for founding national schools.
('31', 4, 2, 9, 10173) In the first place, it is to provide facilities for those who have been imbued with the spirit of nationalism, and secondly, in order to inspire others by serving as models.
('31', 4, 2, 10, 10347) The purpose could not possibly be to mislead the latter by diluting the ideal of nationalism.
('31', 4, 2, 11, 10441) Gradually, as the character of the teachers and pupils in the national schools is formed and becomes apparent, others will not be able to resist the temptation of joining these schools.
('31', 4, 3, 12, 10627) 6. Rules become a snare.
('31', 4, 3, 13, 10652) Whether rules become snares or not depends on those who impose them.
('31', 4, 3, 14, 10721) Even their voluntary observance depends on the rule maker.
('31', 4, 3, 15, 10780) Primary schools are like tender branches and they can be bent as we wish.
('31', 4, 3, 16, 10854) Let us, however, decide to keep them straight.

('31', 4, 4, 18, 10938) 3. MY NOTES
('31', 4, 5, 19, 10950) CRUELTY I write these notes in Travancore Cochin.
('31', 4, 5, 20, 11000) Among many beautiful things that I saw, I cannot forget an intolerable scene that I witnessed on my way to the motor boat for Vykom.
('31', 4, 5, 21, 11133) The people of Cochin make very little use of horse drawn carriages and motor cars, but in their place they use human beings.
('31', 4, 5, 22, 11258) The Japanese type rickshaw is seen everywhere.
('31', 4, 5, 23, 11305) The sight of rickshaws did not pain me much, as I had seen them often in Durban.
('31', 4, 5, 24, 11386) However, when I saw three or four persons huddled together in one rickshaw, I felt like getting down from my carriage and going over to help that rickshaw puller.
('31', 4, 5, 25, 11549) I was to reach a destination and could not get down.
('31', 4, 5, 26, 11602) The wound it inflicted on my mind, however, did not heal.
('31', 4, 5, 27, 11660) This rickshaw is so built that only
('31', 5, 0, 1, 11696) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 5, 1, 2, 11736) one person can sit in it.
('31', 5, 1, 3, 11762) It is also true that so many persons cannot be huddled in it if the puller protests.
('31', 5, 1, 4, 11847) The cruelty of the passengers, however, is not the less for that.
('31', 5, 1, 5, 11913) A human being does a thousand wrong things because of poverty.
('31', 5, 1, 6, 11976) He even crawls on his stomach, performs many base acts.
('31', 5, 1, 7, 12032) However, what is to be said of those who witness these things?
('31', 5, 1, 8, 12095) What of those who compel him to do them?
('31', 5, 1, 9, 12136) There may even be a law in Cochin that not more than one person can ride in a rickshaw.
('31', 5, 1, 10, 12224) If this is so, those who thus overload it are doubly guilty.
('31', 5, 1, 11, 12285) There is a large population of Gujaratis in Cochin; they are influential people.
('31', 5, 1, 12, 12366) The persons that I saw huddled in the rickshaw were Malayalis.
('31', 5, 1, 13, 12429) I do not know whether Gujaratis go to this extreme or not.
('31', 5, 1, 14, 12488) I hope, however, that no Gujarati is so cruel.
('31', 5, 1, 15, 12535) I would like to request them to serve Cochin.
('31', 5, 1, 16, 12581) They should educate public opinion there so that no one would misuse rickshaws.
('31', 5, 1, 17, 12661) I would even advise them to give up using rickshaws.
('31', 5, 1, 18, 12714) This, by giving them some exercise, would improve their health.
('31', 5, 1, 19, 12778) Except in case of illness or disability, it seems sinful for a person to be carried by another.
('31', 5, 1, 20, 12874) How can we put human beings to the same use as animals?
('31', 5, 1, 21, 12930) How can we make others do what we are not prepared to do ourselves?
('31', 5, 2, 22, 12998) A HUSBAND’S DUTY A gentleman asks what a husband should do if his wife does not assist him in practising the dharma of self control.
('31', 5, 2, 23, 13131) My experience tells me that one does not require the consent of the other partner in practising self control.
('31', 5, 2, 24, 13241) It is enjoyment that requires consent.
('31', 5, 2, 25, 13280) Renun ciation is everyone’s prerogative.
('31', 5, 2, 26, 13321) In these matters, however, a great deal of discrimination is required.
('31', 5, 2, 27, 13392) Self control should be genuine.
('31', 5, 2, 28, 13424) The man should carefully observe his own feelings.
('31', 5, 2, 29, 13475) He can persuade the wife to accept his idea through gentleness and pure love.
('31', 5, 2, 30, 13553) It is possible that the wife is not as enlightened as the husband.
('31', 5, 2, 31, 13620) If so, it is his dharma to share his knowledge with her.
('31', 5, 2, 32, 13677) There is no difficulty in practising self control where there is such wisdom in family relation ships.
('31', 5, 2, 33, 13780) It is my experience that the woman is the first to practise self control.
('31', 5, 2, 34, 13854) It is the husband who prevents her from doing so.
('31', 5, 2, 35, 13904) Hence this question appears irrelevant to me; nevertheless, I have answered it with some hesitation because I feel that it required to be answered.
('31', 5, 3, 36, 14052) DIFFERENCE BETWEEN FATHER AND SON The father is rich and pleasure loving, while the son loves renunciation and a simple life.
('31', 5, 3, 37, 14178) The father stands in the way.
('31', 6, 0, 1, 14208) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 7
('31', 6, 1, 2, 14248) should the son do?
('31', 6, 1, 3, 14267) In my humble opinion, the son should not give up his desire for renunciation.
('31', 6, 1, 4, 14345) He should try and gently plead with his father.
('31', 6, 1, 5, 14393) I believe that, where the son is both courteous and firm, the father does not interfere.
('31', 6, 1, 6, 14482) Very often the son becomes arrogant and annoys the father by making even renunciation look like indulgence.
('31', 6, 1, 7, 14590) I do not regard such renunciation as worthy of the name.
('31', 6, 1, 8, 14647) In its pure form there is so much humility that the father is not even aware of the renunciation.
('31', 6, 1, 9, 14745) There is no need to make much fuss about it.
('31', 6, 1, 10, 14790) Renun ciation which is natural does not herald its coming by the blowing of trumpets.
('31', 6, 1, 11, 14876) It comes in imperceptibly without letting anyone notice it.
('31', 6, 1, 12, 14936) Such renunciation is worthy of its name and enduring.
('31', 6, 1, 13, 14990) No one considers it excessive and it is infectious.
('31', 6, 2, 14, 15042) TEACHER FOR UNTOUCHABLES The answer to this question 1 is simple.
('31', 6, 2, 15, 15108) If teachers for the other castes could be engaged at a salary of Rs. 60/ to Rs. 75/ , they could also be so engaged for the untouchables.
('31', 6, 2, 16, 15246) Much, however, depends on the character of the teacher.
('31', 6, 2, 17, 15302) I do not think that one deserves this salary only because one has graduated from the Vidyapith.
('31', 6, 2, 18, 15398) I would wish all of them to be men of character.
('31', 6, 2, 19, 15447) I know, however, that this is not so.
('31', 6, 2, 20, 15485) Besides weaving, etc., Antyajas could also be trained in car pentry or other crafts.
('31', 6, 2, 21, 15570) However, I would, if possible, develop weaving more.
('31', 6, 2, 22, 15623) Many Antyajas do weaving.
('31', 6, 2, 23, 15649) A great deal of time may have to be spent in teaching them the finer points of the art.
('31', 6, 2, 24, 15737) The Antyaja weavers do not weave fine yarn in much quantity, they do not even weave broadcloth, they hardly weave any designs.
('31', 6, 2, 25, 15864) Our task is to give them complete training in the art of weaving.
('31', 6, 2, 26, 15930) We do not have the means to do so as our knowledge does not extend so far.
('31', 6, 2, 27, 16005) Because of this shortcoming on our part, we should not put them to the trouble of learning other crafts, but we should overcome our own shortcoming.
('31', 6, 2, 28, 16154) The latter is the real tragedy.
('31', 6, 2, 29, 16186) We are aware of what we should teach but we have not yet acquired the fitness to do so.
('31', 6, 2, 30, 16274) I see difficulties in immediately introducing any formula about the teacher pupil ratio in national schools.
('31', 6, 2, 31, 16383) In ideal schools, the number of teachers will certainly be large.
('31', 6, 2, 32, 16449) Some time will elapse before students fill them up.
('31', 6, 2, 33, 16501) Until such time, we cannot fix the ratio.

('31', 8, 1, 2, 18174) 5. LETTER TO G. D. BIRLA
('31', 8, 2, 3, 18199) Phalgun Krishna 13 [March 22, 1925] 1
('31', 8, 3, 4, 18237) BHAI GHANSHYAMDASJI, Your two letters.
('31', 8, 3, 5, 18276) You have taken a load of worry off my mind concerning the Muslim University.
('31', 8, 3, 6, 18353) I would certainly not wish your donation to be the cause of dispute among your brothers.
('31', 8, 3, 7, 18442) I shall not disclose your name.
('31', 8, 3, 8, 18474) As for the land acquired by you in Chhota Nagpur, I will not advise you to give it up just because of the death of some of your employees.
('31', 8, 3, 9, 18613) There is not much difference between landed property and property in the shape of bullion; and property is bound to lead to quarrels, even murder.
('31', 8, 3, 10, 18760) There is only one way out of your dilemma; to give up property altogether.
('31', 8, 3, 11, 18835) This, you do not wish to do at present.
('31', 8, 3, 12, 18875) But, as I have said, since property becomes the cause of quarrels and tempts us to do wrong things, we should give it up, and so long as we are not ready to renounce it completely, we should, as its trustees, use it for the good of others and make the minimum use of it for our own enjoyment.
('31', 8, 3, 13, 19168) There is another possibility.
('31', 8, 3, 14, 19198) Has an attempt been made to get in touch with the gentleman who is creating trouble?
('31', 8, 3, 15, 19283) Why does he give this trouble?
('31', 8, 3, 16, 19314) May be, it was his foolishness but has his land been acquired for a song?
('31', 8, 3, 17, 19388) Even a fool would not like to throw away his property.
('31', 8, 3, 18, 19443) But this is another moral problem I have raised.
('31', 8, 3, 19, 19492) Is your wife feeling a little better now?
('31', 8, 3, 20, 19534) I shall leave Madras on the 24th.
('31', 8, 5, 21, 19568) MOHANDAS GANDHI
('31', 8, 6, 22, 19584) From the Hindi original: C.W. 6107. Courtesy G.D. Birla
('31', 8, 7, 23, 19640) 6. SPEECH AT SOCIAL SERVICE LEAGUE, MADRAS 2

('31', 10, 1, 4, 22918) I shall tell you why.
('31', 10, 1, 5, 22940) You have begun rightly with the service of the lowest strata of society.

('31', 10, 1, 9, 23398) There must be some universal occupation which will be of a universal character.

('31', 10, 1, 13, 23744) It is the one indisputable service which carries its own reward.

('31', 10, 1, 17, 24097) And since we have lost the cunning of the wheel, it is impossible for us to take the message of the wheel to them unless we master the science of the wheel and the intricacies of that simple instrument.
('31', 10, 1, 18, 24300) In that service and that service alone there is no waste of efforts.
('31', 10, 1, 19, 24369) There is no room for despondency.
('31', 10, 1, 20, 24403) For just as every blade of grass that is grown by the tiller adds to the wealth of the country, so also every yard of cotton spun in the name of the country adds to the wealth of the country and puts it, even if it is a pie, into the pockets of the starving millions.

('31', 11, 4, 18, 26955) But remember that your sisters in the villages of India have not only no saris such as you have, but have not even enough food to eat.
('31', 11, 4, 19, 27090) And I am telling God’s truth when I say that I have seen hundreds, if not thousands, of women in India who have no clothes to wear but rags.

('31', 12, 4, 16, 28949) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS, When I received the invitation to unveil this portrait, in my reply I said that I would feel honoured to perform this ceremony.
('31', 12, 4, 17, 29103) I feel doubly honoured now, first, because you have given me this privilege of unveiling the portrait of the late Mr. Kasturiranga Iyenger, and secondly, because I am doing it under the chairmanship of one whom I love and respect.
('31', 12, 4, 18, 29334) It shows great wisdom on the part of those who have issued these invitations, that they confined their attention or invitation to no one party, but to all parties.
('31', 12, 4, 19, 29498) I had the privilege of knowing Mr. Kasturiranga Iyengar for the first time in 1915, I think, and in those days when I could say I was a fairly regular reader of newspapers which I am not today.
('31', 12, 4, 20, 29692) (Laughter.) Among the newspapers that I read was certainly The Hindu and I came to understand the value of that paper from that very moment.
('31', 12, 5, 21, 29833) 1 On the occasion of the unveiling of the portrait of S. Kasturiranga Iyengar.
('31', 12, 5, 22, 29912) V. S. Srinivasa Sastri presided.
('31', 13, 0, 1, 29945) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 13, 1, 2, 29986) believe that Mr. Kasturiranga Iyengar represented some of the best that is to be found in Indian journalism.
('31', 13, 1, 3, 30095) He had, I know, a style all his own.
('31', 13, 1, 4, 30132) He commanded a sarcasm which was also peculiarly his own.
('31', 13, 1, 5, 30190) Whether he wrote as an opponent or as a friend, you could not fail to admire the style in which he wrote.
('31', 13, 1, 6, 30296) Sometimes, although the home thrusts that he gave to his opponents felt bitter at the time they were delivered, there appeared always to be a great deal of truth in them because he had a most plausible style.
('31', 13, 1, 7, 30505) I think it can be fairly claimed for him that he never wavered in his faith in his own country.
('31', 13, 1, 8, 30601) And although he was always a courteous critic, he was also one of the most fearless critics of the Government.
('31', 13, 1, 9, 30712) I had on many an occasion to differ from him.
('31', 13, 1, 10, 30758) But I always valued his decision because I understood thereby wherein lay the weakness of my argument or my position; because, I cannot recall an occasion when there was not something to be said for the argument that he advanced.
('31', 13, 1, 11, 30988) Very often it appeared to me that he occupied, if I may take such a parallel, about the same position in this Presidency that the editor of the London Times occupies in England (Applause.) and it was in this manner.
('31', 13, 1, 12, 31204) I never thought that Mr. Kasturiranga Iyengar was an out and out reformer but he had cultivated journalism for the sake of journalism as it appeared to him.
('31', 13, 1, 13, 31361) (“Hear, hear.”) He felt that if he was to retain that character, he must not lead the country, at least not lead the country too much, but always accurately reflect its opinion.
('31', 13, 2, 14, 31539) Those who followed the columns of The Hindu cannot fail to recognize that whenever they saw a change in the editorial policy, it was because with an unerring instinct he recognized which way the country was going or which way the wind was blowing.
('31', 13, 2, 15, 31787) It may be said that this was a defect in him, but I do not consider it to be so.
('31', 13, 2, 16, 31868) (Mr. C. R. Reddy: “Hear, hear.”) If he had taken upon himself, as I venture to say I have, the role of a reformer, then he would have to give expression to his own individual opinion, no matter what the whole country around him thought of it.
('31', 13, 2, 17, 32111) I think that also is a phase in the country’s life; but that is not the peculiar function of a journalist.
('31', 13, 2, 18, 32218) A journalist’s peculiar function is to read the mind of the country and to give definite and fearless expression to that mind.
('31', 13, 2, 19, 32345) And I think that Mr. Kasturiranga Iyengar was almost unrivalled this quality of his.
('31', 13, 2, 20, 32430) (Applause).
('31', 14, 0, 1, 32442) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 15
('31', 14, 1, 2, 32483) What is more; there was one other thing also I noticed about The Hindu and that was that its news columns satisfied the ambition of a most voracious reader (“Hear, hear” and laughter.); because Mr. Kasturiranga Iyengar gave everything that was to be given in the shape of the events in the country and he had also cultivated the art— and it is an art as I can tell you from my own experience—of clipping.
('31', 14, 1, 3, 32888) All his clippings were really admirable; and if a man studied The Hindu he would not have to read any other newspaper so far as the news of the world was concerned, because he had a most catholic taste.
('31', 14, 1, 4, 33091) He went to the whole newspaper world and he made the choicest extracts from all the magazines and all the newspapers and placed them before his readers in an attractive manner.
('31', 14, 1, 5, 33268) So a man living in the Madras Presidency if he took up The Hindu, and as a counterblast, took up the Madras Mail, I think he would find that he had all he wanted to know about both sides of the question.

('31', 14, 1, 9, 34012) They always wanted to know what The Hindu had to say upon a particular question.

('31', 17, 1, 28, 42362) A gentleman has just now handed me a note containing some questions on this matter.

('31', 17, 1, 30, 42468) He asks if the untouchables are allowed the use of roads you would support their further claim to enter Hindu temples like any other Hindu.
('31', 17, 1, 31, 42608) I am surprised at this question at this
('31', 18, 0, 1, 42648) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 19
('31', 18, 1, 2, 42689) time of the day.
('31', 18, 1, 3, 42706) My answer is emphatically in the affirmative.
('31', 18, 1, 4, 42752) I claim that to the untouchables, not only public roads should be open but also all temples which are open to non Brahmins, and all public schools where non Brahmins and others are admitted and all public places such as public wells or travellers’ bungalows, or anything which is supposed to belong to the public at large, should be open to the untouchables as they are to us.
('31', 18, 1, 5, 43129) Not till this simple elementary, primary human right is guaran teed to every single human being on this piece of God’s earth will I consider that the claim in regard to untoucha bility is vindicated.
('31', 18, 1, 6, 43329) It is not so much a right that belongs to the untouchables as it is the duty which we, the caste Hindus, owe to them.
('31', 18, 1, 7, 43447) It is the least penance that we owe to the untouchables and to the world at large.
('31', 18, 1, 8, 43530) But let me not be misunderstood.
('31', 18, 1, 9, 43563) I do not want at this stage to vindicate the whole of this right by way of satyagraha.
('31', 18, 1, 10, 43650) Vykom satyagraha will stop immediately the roads in question are thrown open.
('31', 18, 1, 11, 43728) I recognize that, wrongly though it is, there is opposed to us a tremendous wall of prejudice in connection with temples.
('31', 18, 1, 12, 43850) I for one would be no party to any violence in any shape or form being used even in order to eradicate this root evil which is eating into the vitals of the Hindu community.
('31', 18, 1, 13, 44024) But there is no mistaking the fact that it is the bounden duty of every Hindu not to rest satisfied until full right is guaranteed to the untouchables and until the very word “untouchables”, or “invisibles” is blotted out of our dictionary.
('31', 18, 1, 14, 44265) The friend next asked me for a definition of a sanatani Hindu and say: “Could a sanatani Hindu Brahmin inter dine with a Hindu non Brahmin although the latter may be a non vegetarian?” My definition of a sanatani Brahmin is: He who believes in the funda mental principles of Hinduism is a sanatani Hindu.
('31', 18, 1, 15, 44570) And the funda mental principles of Hinduism are absolute believe in truth (satya) and ahimsa (non violence).
('31', 18, 1, 16, 44679) The Upanishads proclaim, the Mahabh arata proclaims from the housetop: “Put in one scale all your rajasuyas 1, all your ashvamedhas 2 and all your merits and put truth in the other scale, the scale in which truth is thrown will outweight everything else.” Therefore use truth as your anvil, non violence as your hammer and anything that does not stand the test when it is brought to the anvil of truth and hammered with ahimsa, reject as
('31', 18, 2, 17, 45117) 1 Sacrifices performed at the time of the coronation of Hindu kings in ancient times 2 Horse sacrifices performed by emperors to establish their supremacy
('31', 19, 0, 1, 45272) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 19, 1, 2, 45313) non Hindu.
('31', 19, 1, 3, 45324) For a fuller definition of sanatani Hindu I must refer the friends and those who have similar doubts to the pages of Young India.
('31', 19, 1, 4, 45454) I have said repeatedly that inter dining and intermarriage have no connection whatsoever with the removal of untouchability, for inter dining or intermarrying is a matter of choice and should be so too with every human being.
('31', 19, 1, 5, 45680) It is an indulgence, whereas untoucha bility is a refusal to serve our fellowbeings.
('31', 19, 1, 6, 45765) And truth and ahimsa demand that no human being may debar himself from serving any other human being, no matter how sinful he may be.
('31', 19, 1, 7, 45899) My friend asks me my views on varnashramadharma.
('31', 19, 1, 8, 45948) I believe in the four varnas and the four ashramas.
('31', 19, 1, 9, 46000) We have created confusion in these four varnas and instead of treating them as we ought to, we have arrogated to ourselves superiority, one over another.
('31', 19, 1, 10, 46154) And to our humiliation and degradation we have blotted out three ashramas and retained an apology for grihasthashrama.
('31', 19, 1, 11, 46273) All the four stages in a man’s life are devised by the seers in Hinduism for imposing discipline and self restraint.
('31', 19, 1, 12, 46390) Grihasthashrama is the fair fruit of brah macharya in life for a series of years.
('31', 19, 1, 13, 46472) We have grown into the habit of straining at a gnat and swallowing a camel.
('31', 19, 1, 14, 46548) It was the first ashrama that gave a stability to Hinduism which has survived many an age and has witnessed the fall of many civilizations and which still remains secure.
('31', 19, 1, 15, 46719) And if we would resume the other two ashramas— vanaprastha and sannyasa—and become wholesale national workers devoting our whole time and attention to national service, we would not then have witnessed the farce, the degradation and tragedy of infant marriages and infant widows.
('31', 19, 1, 16, 46999) And if we but follow varnashramadharma in its spirit, we shall cease to be puny individuals and we shall walk in the fear of God and never fear a single human being.
('31', 19, 1, 17, 47165) Today we are afraid of one another, we are afraid of Mussalmans and we are afraid of Englishmen.
('31', 19, 1, 18, 47262) We have lost the nerve force that we had inherited from our forefathers and we have become a bundle of nerves.
('31', 19, 1, 19, 47373) The friend lastly asks—rather it is the first question—“What is the duty of the voters in the coming elections to the Legislative Council?

('31', 23, 1, 2, 55847) Your real education begins after you leave your colleges and schools.

('31', 24, 3, 5, 58234) I thank also the Madras Literary Academy for its address.

('31', 24, 3, 7, 58435) I have thrown in my lot with you so far as a man like me could do, and I have done so because I feel that India’s salvation lies through you.
('31', 24, 3, 8, 58577) I have done so also because I feel that India’s salvation lies in labour, in manual labour, which is not to be had by reading books or mental gymnastics.
('31', 24, 3, 9, 58731) I have realized and I am realizing it day after day that man is born to labour with his own body for his bodily sustenance.
('31', 24, 3, 10, 58855) In mixing with a spinner, weaver and other labourers, I insistently tell them never to cease to be labourers but to add to their bodily labour mental education.
('31', 24, 3, 11, 59016) But I know that the joy that I can derive from labour is not your lot.
('31', 24, 3, 12, 59087) Labour to most of you is painful toil without pleasure.
('31', 24, 3, 13, 59143) It is so, and it is painful toil, partly because your labour is exploited by moneyed men but mostly because of your own defects and limitations.
('31', 24, 3, 14, 59288) The third reason, therefore, why I have become a labourer is to be able to draw, from the same level that you occupy, your attention to these limitations and defects.
('31', 24, 3, 15, 59455) You know that I am practically living with thousands of labourers in Ahmedabad.

('31', 24, 3, 20, 59834) You are often jealous of one another.
('31', 24, 3, 21, 59872) You often do not do the work allotted to you in an honest manner.
('31', 24, 3, 22, 59938) You often place yourselves under the guidance of those who do not lead you in the proper channel and, I know, become impatient of any wrong that is done to you.
('31', 24, 3, 23, 60099) You sometimes think that you can remove that wrong by using violence.
('31', 24, 3, 24, 60169) Those of you who do not belong to the Panchama classes regard yourPanchama brethren with despite and contempt.

('31', 26, 3, 13, 64176) 12. IS BOMBAY ASLEEP ?
('31', 26, 4, 14, 64199) [MADRAS, Monday, March 23, 1925] 1
('31', 26, 5, 15, 64234) I constantly hear complaints to the effect that spinning wheels do not ply in Bombay, no one buys khadi, the people are not found wearing it, black caps are again as common as in 1920, national schools are closing down, etc., etc.
('31', 26, 5, 16, 64465) Bombay is being served by two khadi bhandars2 and the All India Khadi Board.
('31', 26, 5, 17, 64542) Together, their sales do not exceed Rs. 30,000. Shri Jerajani3 has published the figures for four years, which throw some useful light.
('31', 26, 5, 18, 64678) It is now the fifth year since the bhandar started working under his management.
('31', 26, 5, 19, 64759) Its sales during January 1923 amounted to Rs. 22,299 and during January 1924 to Rs. 22,516, whereas last January they amounted to only Rs. 14,401. In those years, for the month of February they amounted to Rs. 15,747 and Rs. 21,664, respectively, as compared to which this February they amounted to Rs. 13,524 only.
('31', 26, 5, 20, 65075) Thus I find that instead of rising, the sales are on the decline.

('31', 32, 2, 3, 73903) March 24, 1925
('31', 32, 3, 4, 73918) FRIENDS, I am obliged to you for having invited me to meet you.
('31', 32, 3, 5, 73982) I am obliged to you also for your address.
('31', 32, 3, 6, 74025) I appreciate and understand your sentiments; the more so, as you may not admit it, but some day even you will admit that I am engaged in running the greatest co operative society that the world has ever seen.
('31', 32, 3, 7, 74234) I may fail miserably and if I fail it will be because of your weakness or want of response.
('31', 32, 3, 8, 74326) I am engaged in running a cooperative society in which 300 millions of people of this earth may become willing members, men, women and children, lepers and men—men who are in perfect health and lepers in mind, body and soul.
('31', 32, 3, 9, 74551) So you see that at least here there is a desire to follow literally the maxim that you have got, viz.,“Each shall live for all and all shall live for each.” If you really measure the value of that teaching, you will find the hidden meaning of that truth and understand the deep and hidden meaning of the spinning wheel.
('31', 32, 3, 10, 74871) Therefore, I invite you, the co operators, to join the greatest co operative society in the world.
('31', 32, 3, 11, 74970) You cannot begin to do that unless you make up your minds to spin for at least half an hour per day, and unless you adopt khaddar as your costume.

('31', 34, 3, 5, 79006) 20. SPEECH ON PROHIBITION, MADRAS 1
('31', 34, 4, 6, 79042) March 24, 1925 It is a very great pleasure that I am able today to speak to you on the matter of temperance and it is a matter of great honour that I am doing so under the chairmanship of one whom I revere for her long, great and continuous services to the motherland.
('31', 34, 4, 7, 79311) The cause of temperance I have handled now, I think, for 30 years, if not longer.
('31', 34, 4, 8, 79393) The horror of drink I have inherited from my revered mother when she gave me her permis sion to proceed to England.
('31', 34, 4, 9, 79509) Some of you may know she imposed upon me three vows or obligations, one of which was that I should abstain from drinking.
('31', 34, 4, 10, 79631) I may tell you that she did not know what a great curse the drink evil was.
('31', 34, 4, 11, 79707) She had no knowledge of the masses and the destruction that the drink evil was bringing into their homes.
('31', 34, 4, 12, 79813) In the place where I was brought up and at the time of which I am now speaking to you there was probably very little drinking going on in that beautiful little city, Rajkot.
('31', 34, 4, 13, 79987) However, the fact that she imposed this obligation on me, naturally, put me upon my guard and set me thinking also why it was that rather than imposing other vows she had imposed these three vows of which this was one.
('31', 34, 4, 14, 80206) I set sail and I met several people on board.
('31', 34, 4, 15, 80252) I was a duffer and could not carry on a sustained conversation with my fellow pass engers in English.One of them was from Kutch, a district in Kathiawar, and he told me that after we had crossed the Bay of Biscay I would be compelled to drink.
('31', 34, 4, 16, 80496) I said I would wait.
('31', 34, 4, 17, 80517) He asked what I would do if my doctors advised drink.
('31', 34, 4, 18, 80571) I said I would die if that were the only condition on which I could live, rather than break a sacred promise deliberately made to my mother.
('31', 34, 4, 19, 80712) So I proceeded to London.
('31', 34, 4, 20, 80738) I saw everything that was going on before my eyes whenever I stood in front of those great palaces called public houses, where people went in as sober men and came out of
('31', 34, 5, 21, 80909) 1 At a meeting of temperance workers at the Gokhale Hall.
('31', 34, 5, 22, 80967) Dr. Besant presided.
('31', 35, 0, 1, 80988) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 35, 1, 2, 81029) these so called palaces dead drunk.
('31', 35, 1, 3, 81065) I had absolutely no opportunity to do any work in England.
('31', 35, 1, 4, 81124) It filled one with a great desire for working in the cause of temperance and a great desire for rescuing Indians from this curse.
('31', 35, 1, 5, 81254) I may also inform you that the time when I went to London was the time when some of the students and teachers were infatuated with everything Western and so they drank on the liner and it was supposed to be a fashionable thing to do so.
('31', 35, 1, 6, 81491) So when I observed this in London, I felt that I should work in order to wean away the youths of our country from indulging in drink in this land.
('31', 35, 1, 7, 81638) Little did I know that I would find myself within two years of my return to India in South Africa and amidst some of the poorest of our land, all of whom were given not only to drinking but drinking to excess.
('31', 35, 1, 8, 81848) But such was my good fortune or misfortune, whichever you may call it, that I witnessed the ruin, in Natal, among the indentured Indians, of hun dreds of helpless women as well as men who were given to drinking.
('31', 35, 1, 9, 82060) I tried— and in those days I was not a non co operator; although I was fighting the Government in different parts of South Africa, I was closely co operating with them in all humility wherever they accepted the co ope ration so tendered—I tried to persuade them to prohibit drinking among our own countrymen.
('31', 35, 1, 10, 82369) You will be painfully surprised to know that I had to face opposition from our own countrymen and they set up the question of rights and privileges and they said that where Europeans could drink freely, Indians must also have that right.
('31', 35, 1, 11, 82607) (Laughter.) It was not possible for me and, I must confess, it was to my shame that the majority of them I was really unable to convince, even after 20 years’ stay in South Africa, that was a question which admitted of no privilege and competition.
('31', 35, 1, 12, 82856) If I had time I could give pictures of captains who were dead drunk, when sailing under them was really a dangerous thing; not that they wanted to drink to excess but that they forgot themselves.
('31', 35, 1, 13, 83052) Some of them had become my friends but when they took to these things I saw what a curse it proved to them; what a danger they were to the community which was at that time under their absolute charge.
('31', 35, 1, 14, 83253) I told my friends that it was not a matter of right, that if we at least for ourselves could secure prohibition, we could save these families.
('31', 35, 1, 15, 83396) And ever since that time it has been a question with me and some of my friends who were against me on the matter of prohibition versus purely taking the gospel of temperance to the
('31', 36, 0, 1, 83577) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 37
('31', 36, 1, 2, 83618) homes of the people.
('31', 36, 1, 3, 83639) I have definitely come to the conclusion that merely preaching amongst the masses will not do, for they do not know what they are doing.
('31', 36, 1, 4, 83776) I was, just before I came to this Presidency, travelling as you are aware, in Kathiawar.
('31', 36, 1, 5, 83865) It is a place which contains numerous small principalities.
('31', 36, 1, 6, 83925) In one of these places the families of men who were given to this wretched habit pleaded that they should be saved from themselves.
('31', 36, 1, 7, 84057) How could I save them from themselves except by pro hibiting distillation altogether, except or medicinal purposes?
('31', 36, 1, 8, 84173) I would apply absolutely the same formula to drink as the opium lea gues in America are applying to opium.
('31', 36, 1, 9, 84280) I do not know whether opium is a greater evil than drink.
('31', 36, 1, 10, 84338) Possibly there is not much to choose, but from a purely moral point of view I am inclined to think that if I had to give a decided opinion, I would vote against drinking because drinking saps the moral foundations.

SPEECH AT WOMEN’S CHRISTIAN COLLEGE, MADRAS March 24, 1925 As you know, throughout my journey in India, I meet students, both boys and girls, but whenever I come to the South, I meet many more girls than I meet elsewhere except, perhaps in Bengal, because in Bengal the education of girls has gone forward much more than in other parts of Upper India but, by no means, so much as in South India.
('31', 40, 2, 6, 94736) I was really surprised to see the stride that education among girls had taken in the State of Travancore.
('31', 40, 2, 7, 94842) It was a perfect eye opener to me.
('31', 40, 2, 8, 94877) The question has always occurred to me: “What will India do with its modern girls?” I call you modern girls of India.
('31', 40, 2, 9, 94995) The education that we are receiving on these institutions, in my opinion, does not correspond with the life around us, and, when I say life around us, I do not mean the life around us in the cities but the life around us in the villages.
('31', 40, 2, 10, 95233) Perhaps some of you girls, if not all of you, know that real India is to be found not here in the very few cities but in the seven hundred thousand villages covering a surface of 1,900 miles long and 1,500 miles broad.
('31', 40, 2, 11, 95452) The question is whether you have any message for your sisters in the villages.
('31', 40, 2, 12, 95531) Men do not need the message perhaps so much as the women, and I have long before come to the conclusion that unless women of India work side by side with men, there is no salvation for India, salvation in more senses than one.
('31', 40, 2, 13, 95758) I mean political salvation in the broadest sense, and I mean economic salvation and spiritual salvation also.
('31', 40, 2, 14, 95868) We may call ourselves Christians, Hindus or Mohammedans.

('31', 46, 1, 2, 108645) 26. ALL ABOUT TRAVANCORE
('31', 46, 2, 3, 108670) A LAND OF BEAUTY It was a perfect pleasure to visit Travancore and incidentally Cochin.
('31', 46, 2, 4, 108758) It is a land of perfect beauty.
('31', 46, 2, 5, 108790) My few days in Travancore were days of incessant journeying and meeting vast crowds of people.
('31', 46, 2, 6, 108885) Travancore is blessed with a magnificent waterway and equally mag nificent roads.
('31', 46, 2, 7, 108967) Its extreme length is 179 miles and breadth 75 miles.
('31', 46, 2, 8, 109021) Its area is 7,625 square miles more than half of which is covered by hills and forests.
('31', 46, 2, 9, 109109) I entered at the northern entrance.
('31', 46, 2, 10, 109145) Vykom lies almost on the northern border.
('31', 46, 2, 11, 109187) The route lay through a beautiful waterway studded on either side with luxuriant vegetation, chiefly palms.
('31', 46, 2, 12, 109295) I was taken to the extreme south, the Cape Comorin, where the sea daily washes in adoration the feet of Hind Mata 1. And as I travelled, I seemed to go from one end of a beautifully laid out garden to the other.
('31', 46, 2, 13, 109507) Travancore is not a country containing a few towns and many villages.
('31', 46, 2, 14, 109577) It looks like one vast city containing a popu lation of over 4,00,000 males and females almost equally divided and distributed in small farms studded with pleasant looking cottages.
('31', 46, 2, 15, 109759) There was, therefore, here none of the ugliness of so many Indian villages in which human beings and cattle live together in an overcrowded state in spite of the open air and open space surrounding them.
('31', 46, 2, 16, 109963) How the Malabaris are able to live thus in isolated cottages and to feel, as they evidently do, safe from the robber and the beast I do not know.
('31', 46, 2, 17, 110109) Those of whom I inquired about the cause could not say anything beyond corroborating my inference that both men and women must be brave.
('31', 46, 3, 18, 110246) THE STATUS OF WOMEN
('31', 46, 4, 19, 110266) The woman in India lives nowhere in greater freedom than in Malabar.
('31', 46, 4, 20, 110335) She is more than well protected by the local law and custom.
('31', 46, 4, 21, 110396) Education among women is nowhere greater than in Travancore.
('31', 46, 4, 22, 110457) Indeed Travancore appears educationally to be the most advanced part of India.
('31', 46, 4, 23, 110536) In 1922, general literacy was 244 per thousand of the population, 330 in the case of males and 150 in the case of females.
('31', 46, 4, 24, 110659) This literacy is daily increasing both among males and females.
('31', 46, 4, 25, 110723) The backward classes are taking their full share in this wonderful progress.
('31', 46, 4, 26, 110800) This progress even disturbs a sceptic like me.
('31', 46, 4, 27, 110847) If all the education
('31', 46, 5, 28, 110868) 1 Mother India
('31', 47, 0, 1, 110883) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 47, 1, 2, 110924) means a general discontent with one’s surroundings, a wrench with the past without hope for the future and a general scramble for employment, the whole of the beautiful edifice must one fine morning come down with a sudden crash.
('31', 47, 1, 3, 111154) Without the culture of the heart and the hand mere growth of literacy has no attraction for me.
('31', 47, 1, 4, 111250) What is wanted therefore is a drastic measure giving not an indifferent manual training but a proper occupational training specially designed to make it worth while for highly educated men not to look up to Government service but to farming, or say weaving, for their maintenance.
('31', 47, 1, 5, 111531) Unless the mind of the student world is given a bent in the direction of the main and natural sources of livelihood and is developed in a scientific spirit in keeping with the special Indian conditions, the gulf between the educated classes and the masses must widen, the former must live on the latter instead of the former living with and for the latter and sweetening their life.
('31', 47, 2, 6, 111914) HER HIGHNESS THE MAHARANI REGENT

('31', 54, 1, 7, 128617) Asked whether Christians and Mussalmans were permitted to use these roads, he replied in the affirmative and said that they were superior to the unapproachables in as much as, he said, they, the unapproachables, were so born as a fit punishment for their misdeeds in the past incarnation and that the taint was indelible during their present incarnation.
('31', 54, 1, 8, 128972) The spokesman who expressed these views is, I am told, a learned man.
('31', 54, 1, 9, 129042) I have no doubt that he believes what he says.
('31', 54, 1, 10, 129089) Whilst, therefore, I hold this view to be totally mistaken and contrary to Hinduism and humanity, I can find it in me to treat him as a friend worthy of regard and affection.
('31', 54, 1, 11, 129264) That is my meaning of toleration.
('31', 54, 1, 12, 129298) I do not look forward to a time when we shall all hold one and the same view but I do look forward to a time when we shall love one another in spite of the sharpest differences of opinion.
('31', 54, 1, 13, 129487) And so I made the following proposals to the friends: 1. They should produce Shankara’s authority in support of their contention and I would advise the withdrawal of satyagraha from Vykom should the learned Shastris, whom I may consult, regard it as authentic and clearly bearing the construction sought to be put upon it by the orthodox party.
('31', 54, 1, 14, 129832) It could not bind me for all places for the simple reason that even if Shankaracharya held the view in his time, I would not be bound by what appeared to me to be contrary to religion and humanity.
('31', 54, 1, 15, 130030) 2. The whole matter could be referred to arbitration consisting of a learned man to be nominated by them, another to be
('31', 54, 2, 16, 130150) 1 Vide “Discussion with Caste Hindu Leaders, Vykom”, 10 3 1925
('31', 55, 0, 1, 130213) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 55, 1, 2, 130254) nominated by me on behalf of the satyagrahis and the Dewan of Travancore to be the umpire.
('31', 55, 1, 3, 130345) 3. A referendum to be taken of all the adult male and female caste Hindus of Vykom alone or of the whole of Travancore or selected areas according as they prefered.
('31', 55, 1, 4, 130510) The Government should be invited to participate in the organization of the referendum.
('31', 55, 1, 5, 130597) The third proposal was put first by me as it was contended by the orthodox party that the caste Hindus were against the reform.
('31', 55, 1, 6, 130725) But when I took them at their word and said that I would gladly agree to a referendum, the spoksmen veered round and said that in a matter of religious conviction a man could not be bound by the verdict of a majority.
('31', 55, 1, 7, 130943) I appreciated the force of the suggestion and made the other two proposals.
('31', 55, 1, 8, 131019) I may say in passing that I proposed a re ferendum because the present satyagraha is based upon the suppo sition that savarna public opinion is in favour of reform.
('31', 55, 1, 9, 131184) None of the proposals was, however, accepted by the gentlemen and I am sorry to say that we parted company without coming to any understanding.
('31', 55, 1, 10, 131328) I then waited upon Her Highness and she granted me a patient and courteous hearing.
('31', 55, 1, 11, 131412) She was anxious for the opening of the road at Vykom and appreciated the proposals made by me.
('31', 55, 1, 12, 131507) I waited also upon His Holiness Shri Narayan Swami Guru.
('31', 55, 1, 13, 131564) He entirely approved of the satyagraha movement and said that violence would never succeed and that non violence as the only method.
('31', 55, 1, 14, 131697) The next day I waited upon the Dewan Bahadur.
('31', 55, 1, 15, 131743) He too said he was entirely on the side of reform.
('31', 55, 1, 16, 131794) His only difficulty was that as an administrator he could not legislate unless there was strong and clearly expressed public opinion.
('31', 55, 1, 17, 131928) I suggested that he should insist upon the opponents of reform accepting one of my proposals.
('31', 55, 1, 18, 132022) They could not entrench themselves behind an ancient custom if it was, as this was, contrary to humanity and public morals.
('31', 55, 1, 19, 132146) SATYAGRAHI’S DUTY Here the matter rests for the time being.
('31', 55, 1, 20, 132206) The satyagrahis hold the result in the hollow of their hands.
('31', 55, 1, 21, 132268) They must continue without fatigue, without despair, without anger or irritation and with for bearance towards the opponents and the Government.
('31', 55, 1, 22, 132413) By their dignified bearing and patient suffering they will break down the iron wall of prejudice and they will stimulate and draw public opinion towards them and will force the hands of the Government if the orthodoxy itself does not yield to their gentle treatment.

('31', 56, 2, 7, 133015) 28. STONING TO DEATH My brief note 2 on the penalty of stoning of death awarded against certain members of the Ahmadiya community has resulted in a great deal of correspondence on the subject.
('31', 56, 2, 8, 133208) I am unable to print all the correspondence.
('31', 56, 2, 9, 133253) But I am printing enough to put the reader in possession of the views of my correspondents.
('31', 56, 2, 10, 133345) Here is what Maulana Zafar Ali Khan has to say in the matter.
('31', 56, 3, 11, 133407) I hasten to fulfil the promise which I made in my last letter to deal at
('31', 56, 4, 12, 133480) some length with the controversial points arising out of your note on the
('31', 56, 5, 13, 133554) stoning of certain Qadianis in Kabul.
('31', 56, 5, 14, 133592) I have read the note over and over
('31', 56, 6, 15, 133627) again and each successive study has strengthened me in the conviction that as
('31', 56, 7, 16, 133705) President of the National Congress and above all in your personal capacity
('31', 56, 8, 17, 133780) you had better left it unwritten.
('31', 56, 8, 18, 133814) I reproduce the passages, which to my mind
('31', 56, 9, 19, 133857) are open to exception:
('31', 56, 10, 20, 133880) “I understand that the stoning method is enjoined in the Koran only in certain circumstances which do not cover the cases under observation.
('31', 56, 10, 21, 134021) But as a human being living in fear of God, I should question the morality of the method under any circumstance whatsoever.
('31', 56, 10, 22, 134145) Whatever may have been necessary or permissible during the Prophet’s lifetime and in that age this particular form of penalty cannot be defended on the mere ground of its mention in the Koran.
('31', 56, 10, 23, 134338) Every formula of every religion has in this age of reason to submit to the acid test of reason and universal justice if it is to ask for universal assent.
('31', 56, 10, 24, 134493) Error can claim no exemption even if it can be supported by the scriptures of the world.
('31', 56, 10, 25, 134582) It is the form of penalty that wounds the human conscience.
('31', 56, 10, 26, 134642) Both reason and heart refuse to reconcile themselves to torture for any crime no matter how vile the crime may be.”
('31', 56, 11, 27, 134758) The opening lines of the above extract are open to correction.
('31', 56, 12, 28, 134821) 1 Vide, “Notes”, 5 3 1925, sub title, “An Oasis in the Desert”.
('31', 56, 12, 29, 134885) 2 Vide “Notes”, 26 2 1925, sub title “Stoning to Death”.
('31', 56, 12, 30, 134942) Subsequently, Gandhiji wrote on the subject in “My Crime”, 5 3 1925 and in “Notes”, 12 3 1925, sub title, “No Stoning in Koran”.
('31', 57, 0, 1, 135071) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 57, 1, 2, 135112) Koran nowhere prescribes stoning to death as a penalty for any crime and you have erroneously attributed to it a statement which has no basis in fact.
('31', 57, 1, 3, 135263) This is, however, a very trivial affair as compared with the attitude taken up by you that you form of penalty which according to your standard of morality is unacceptable to you must be condemned as inhuman even if it is supported by the Koran and all the other scriptures of the world.
('31', 57, 1, 4, 135551) This means that the Koran as a source of Islamic law must be looked upon as a bundle of errors because it “wounds the human conscience” by ordaining the punishment of flogging for adultery and mutilation in respect of theft.
('31', 57, 1, 5, 135776) I would not mind in the least if such sweeping statements emanated from the unsympathetic critics of Islam with whom we are only too familiar.
('31', 57, 1, 6, 135919) But your position is quite different.
('31', 57, 1, 7, 135957) As President of the National Congress you occupy the proud position of the head of the three hundred million Indians who expect you to respect their beliefs.
('31', 57, 1, 8, 136115) As Mahatma Gandhi, the champion of Khilafat, millions of Mussalmans have grown accustomed to regard you as their “guide”, philosoher and friend”.
('31', 57, 1, 9, 136261) Your categorical denunciation, therefore, of a peculiar aspect of the penal provisions of the Shariat was most unexpected; and Mussalmans whose
('31', 57, 2, 10, 136405) susceptibilities in matters concerning the fundamentals of their faith are extremely delicate, naturally look upon the expression of such views as an uncalled for interference in an affair which concerns themselves alone.
('31', 57, 2, 11, 136627) You have certainly the right of personally holding any opinion as to the validity of the moral sanction of penalties imposed by Islam on such of its followers as transgress its law.
('31', 57, 2, 12, 136809) But a public expression of this opinion, in what very much looks like the capacity of a Muslim jurisconsult makes your illustrious position rather awkward, and it is my solicitude for your prestige throughout the Islamic world that has prompted me to address you in this manner.
('31', 57, 3, 13, 137088) I now turn to the main point at issue.
('31', 57, 3, 14, 137127) The Koran as a penal code has prescribed punishment only in respect of a limited number of crimes, viz., murder, adultery, theft and slander of chaste women.
('31', 57, 3, 15, 137285) Punishment for other offences has been left to the discretion of the Prophet whose lifelong practice forms the basis of the legislative activities of his successors.
('31', 57, 3, 16, 137451) Full latitude for the exercise of independent judgment has been conceded to the latter where the Prophet’s authority is not forthcoming.
('31', 57, 3, 17, 137588) Thus the Koran as the word of God, the practice of the Prophet, the first and infallible interpreter of the revealed book, and the collective judgment of the Islamic world constitute the Shariat, and no Mussalman who is worth his salt dare impugn its authority.
('31', 57, 4, 18, 137850) Now apostasy, as such, is an offence punishable with death under the Shariat; and although the Koran is silent on the subject, the other two sources
('31', 57, 5, 19, 137999) of the Islamic law have announced in unmistakable language that an apostate
('31', 58, 0, 1, 138075) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 59
('31', 58, 1, 2, 138116) must forfeit his life.
('31', 58, 1, 3, 138139) I have dealt exhaustively with this subject in a series of articles which I am writing for the Zamindar.
('31', 58, 2, 4, 138244) To people who have been dazzled by the glamour of modern scepticism, this unrelenting attitude of Islam towards apostasy might seem a direct challenge to the freedom of human conscience, whatever that expression may connote.
('31', 58, 2, 5, 138469) These gentry should, however, remember that Islam is not only an institution for the guidance of those who profess it but a State which must exact allegiance from its subjects.
('31', 58, 2, 6, 138646) If a British Indian subject can be hanged for infringing Section 121 of the Indian Penal Code and cannot escape such fate on the plausible plea that he is at liberty to shake off King George’s allegiance, surely it stands to reason, on similar grounds, that a Mussalman who rebels against the overlordship of Islam should pay for the act with his life.
('31', 58, 3, 7, 138999) The question now is whether capital punishment in the case of an apostate should or should not take the form of stoning.
('31', 58, 3, 8, 139120) I will cut short this discussion in one word.
('31', 58, 3, 9, 139166) Forms of punishment are always regulated by the cultural stage of a people.
('31', 58, 3, 10, 139242) Legislators in every age have obeyed this psychological necessity.
('31', 58, 3, 11, 139309) Even the British Government which prides itself on its humanitarianism has been forced to enact the notorious Frontier Crimes Regulation in the North West Frontier Province, which it would not think of promulgating in the United Provinces of Agra and Oudh.
('31', 58, 3, 12, 139566) The Kabul Government is following the same natural law in stoning to death a number of Quadianis who have been proved guilty of high treason not only against the
('31', 58, 4, 13, 139728) spiritual but the temporal power of Islam.
('31', 58, 4, 14, 139771) Maulana M. Safdar writing from Sialkot says:
('31', 58, 5, 15, 139816) I have read your note “Stoning to Death” in the Young India dated
('31', 58, 6, 16, 139882) 26th February, as well as the rejoinder by Maulvi Zafar Ali Khan as published in the Zamindar dated 4th March.
('31', 58, 6, 17, 139993) I am afraid any controversy might lead to
('31', 58, 7, 18, 140035) misunderstandings and the point in issue should be cleared at once.
('31', 58, 7, 19, 140103) As you have stated Koran enjoins the punishment of Rajam i.e., stoning to death, nowhere.
('31', 58, 7, 20, 140193) The word Rajam is only twice mentioned in the Koran.
('31', 58, 7, 21, 140246) Firstly in Sura Had where the people of Midian tell their Prophet, “O Shuaib!
('31', 58, 7, 22, 140324) We do not
('31', 58, 8, 23, 140334) understand much of what you say and most surely we see you to be weak among us, and were it not for your family we would surely stone you and you are not mighty against us”.
('31', 58, 8, 24, 140508) (Sura Had, verse 91, page 470 M. Mohammed Ali's translation).
('31', 58, 8, 25, 140570) Secondly in Sura “The Cave” where one of the dwellers in the
('31', 58, 9, 26, 140631) cave goes to the market to purchase food with a coin hundreds of years old and is told by the provision seller, “or surely if they (i.e., Government) prevail against you they would stone you to death of force you back to their religion
('31', 59, 0, 1, 140867) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 59, 1, 2, 140908) and then you will never succeed” (Sura “The Cave”, verse 20, page 591 M. Mohammed Ali’s translation).
('31', 59, 1, 3, 141010) This will show that the word Rajam is
('31', 59, 2, 4, 141048) mentioned only in the course of references to the ancient history and is not at all enjoined by the Koran as a punishment.
('31', 59, 2, 5, 141171) I feel, you are right in saying that the present human morality cannot stand this barbarous penalty and in saying this you by no means contravene the teaching of the Koran and thus wound the religious susceptibilities of the Mussalmans.
('31', 59, 2, 6, 141408) I fear, M. Zafar Ali Khan is not right in qualifying Rajam as Islamic Shariat.
('31', 59, 2, 7, 141487) Koran does not support him and
('31', 59, 3, 8, 141518) opinions differ as to what later Muslim jurists hold it to be.
('31', 59, 3, 9, 141581) Khwaja Kamaluddin, head of the Muslim Mission at Woking, says:
('31', 59, 4, 10, 141644) The Koran proposes no punishment whatsoever for apostasy, on this side of the grave.
('31', 59, 4, 11, 141729) The Book advocates absolute freedom of conscience in matters of religion and prohibits all sorts of compulsion in this respect.
('31', 59, 4, 12, 141857) I have directed my office (Lahore) to send you a copy of my book India in the Balance which I wrote sometime in 1922; in it you will find a chapter on the subject as an appendix.
('31', 59, 4, 13, 142036) You have read the Koran, and I am afraid you made a mistake in saying that the Koran proposes punishment of stoning to death.
('31', 59, 4, 14, 142162) Will you kindly refer to the Verse as well, when you write on the subject again.
('31', 59, 4, 15, 142243) I fail to see anything like that in the Book.
('31', 59, 4, 16, 142289) Apostasy occurred in the lifetime of the Holy Prophet in many cases, but no punishment was awarded to anyone, solely for it.
('31', 59, 4, 17, 142414) No tradition can abrogate the Koran.
('31', 59, 4, 18, 142451) The Holy Prophet said, “You will hear many sayings ascribed to me; if they are according to the Koran they are from me; if they are not according to the Koran they are not from me.” This is the only test with us to find the truth of what has been ascribed to our Prophet as his traditions.
('31', 59, 4, 19, 142741) I am very glad to find that there is no penalty of stoning to death in the Koran.
('31', 59, 4, 20, 142823) I did not say that there positively was.
('31', 59, 4, 21, 142864) I said, “I understand that the stoning method & c.
('31', 59, 4, 22, 142915) .” But Maulana Zafar Ali Khan whilst saying that the penalty is not prescribed in the Koran energetically argues that it has nevertheless a place in Islam and gives it his support.
('31', 59, 4, 23, 143096) To me, an outsider, it is the same thing so long as a particular practice is part of Islamic practice whether it is defended on the basis of “the practice of the Prophet” or “the collective judgment of the Islamic world”.
('31', 59, 4, 24, 143318) What I would like my Mussalman friends to do is unhesitatingly to condemn, irrespective of its source, what the world’s reasoned opinion rejects as contrary to humanity.
('31', 59, 4, 25, 143488) I am glad, therefore, that Maulana Safdar and Khwaja Kamaluddin condemn the penalty of stoning altogether, and that of death at all, for apostasy.
('31', 59, 4, 26, 143635) I wish that they could say with me that even if it could be established
('31', 60, 0, 1, 143707) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 61
('31', 60, 1, 2, 143748) that the practice of stoning of death could be proved to be derived from the Prophet’s practice or “the collective judgment of the Islamic world”, they could not defend it as being repugnant to their sense of humanity.
('31', 60, 1, 3, 143967) I would relieve the Maulana of his anxiety for my “prestige throughout the Islamic world”.
('31', 60, 1, 4, 144058) It would not be worth a day’s purchase if it could be reduced to a nullity on account of an honest expression of my opinion about practices defended in the name of Islam.
('31', 60, 1, 5, 144229) But the fact is, I have no desire for prestige anywhere.
('31', 60, 1, 6, 144286) It is furniture required in courts of kings.
('31', 60, 1, 7, 144331) I am a servant of Mussal mans, Christians, Parsis and Jews as I am of Hindus.
('31', 60, 1, 8, 144409) And a servant is in need of love, not prestige.
('31', 60, 1, 9, 144457) That is assured to me so long as I remained a faithful servant.
('31', 60, 1, 10, 144521) And I would ask the Maulana to transfer his anxiety to the prestige of Islam.
('31', 60, 1, 11, 144599) And I shall share his burden.
('31', 60, 1, 12, 144629) In my opinion he has unconsciously diminished that prestige by his defence of an indefensible practice.
('31', 60, 1, 13, 144733) No amount of casuistry can defend the penalty of stoning to death in any event or that of death, whether by stoning or otherwise, for apostasy.
('31', 60, 1, 14, 144877) My own position is clear.
('31', 60, 1, 15, 144903) In my writing about Islam I take the same care of its prestige that I do of Hinduism.
('31', 60, 1, 16, 144989) I apply the same method of interpretation to it that I apply to Hinduism.
('31', 60, 1, 17, 145063) I no more defend on the mere ground of authority a single text in the Hindu scriptures than I can defend one from the Koran.
('31', 60, 1, 18, 145188) Everything has to submit to the test of reason.
('31', 60, 1, 19, 145236) Islam appeals to people because it appeals also to reason.
('31', 60, 1, 20, 145295) And in the long run it will be found that any other method would land one in trouble.
('31', 60, 1, 21, 145381) There are undoubtedly things in the world which transcend reason.
('31', 60, 1, 22, 145447) We do not refuse to bring them on the anvil of reason but they will not come themselves.
('31', 60, 1, 23, 145536) By their very nature they defy reason.
('31', 60, 1, 24, 145575) Such is the mystery of the deity.
('31', 60, 1, 25, 145609) It is not inconsistent with reason, it is beyond it.
('31', 60, 1, 26, 145662) But stoning to death is no more beyond reason than, say, the practice of honesty or of swearing.
('31', 60, 1, 27, 145759) Taken in its broadest sense apostasy means “abandonment of one’s religion”.
('31', 60, 1, 28, 145835) Is that a grievous crime meriting the punishment of death?
('31', 60, 1, 29, 145894) If it is, reconversion of a Hindu convert to Islam is a step involving capital punishment.
('31', 60, 1, 30, 145985) The Maulana Saheb’s suggestion that I should not criticize any act in Islam or say anything of the Koran because I am President of the Congress and friend of Mussalmans is, I am afraid, unacceptable.
('31', 60, 1, 31, 146185) I should be unworthy of either position if at a critical moment I suppressed my own judgment.
('31', 60, 1, 32, 146279) The stoning incident

('31', 61, 1, 2, 146341) is a matter with which every publicist is concerned.

('31', 70, 9, 16, 162949) We see the ocean on all three sides of Kanyakumari as it is on the tip of India.

('31', 72, 1, 2, 166645) I did not pity the ignorance of the idolatrous Hindu, but, on the contrary, realized his wisdom.
('31', 72, 1, 3, 166742) By discovering the way of image worship, he has not multiplied the one God into many, but realized the fact and shown it to the world that man can worship—and he will continue to worship—God in His diverse forms.
('31', 72, 1, 4, 166955) Although the Christians and the Muslims do not regard themselves as idolators, nevertheless, those who worship their ideals are also image worship pers.
('31', 72, 1, 5, 167108) A mosque or a church also involved a form of image worship.
('31', 72, 1, 6, 167168) Imagining that one can become more holy only by going to these places is a form of idolworship, and there is no harm in such belief.
('31', 72, 1, 7, 167301) Even the faith that God is revealed only in the Koran or the Bible is idol worship and an innocent one.
('31', 72, 1, 8, 167405) The Hindu goes further and says that everyone should worship God in the form he likes.
('31', 72, 1, 9, 167492) Even a person who makes an idol of stone or gold or silver and after attributing divinity to it, purifies himself by meditating on it, will be fully qualified to attain moksha.
('31', 72, 1, 10, 167669) While circumambulating the temple, all this became clearer to me.
('31', 72, 1, 11, 167735) However, even there my happiness was not untainted by sorrow.
('31', 72, 1, 12, 167797) I was allowed to make a complete circle, but I was not per mitted to go to the inner shrine because I had been to England.
('31', 72, 1, 13, 167920) The restriction imposed on untouchables, however, was due to the fact of their birth.
('31', 72, 1, 14, 168006) How can this be tolerated?Could Kanyakumari be polluted?
('31', 72, 1, 15, 168063) Has this practice been followed since ancient times?
('31', 72, 1, 16, 168116) My inner voice cried out that this could not be.
('31', 72, 1, 17, 168165) Moreover, if it had been, it would be sinful.
('31', 72, 1, 18, 168211) That which is sinful does not cease to be so or become meritorious through its antiquity.
