('31', 85, 0, 1, 194879) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 85, 1, 2, 194920) consider that in agreeing to a referendum or Shastric interpreta tion I have endangered the reform itself.
('31', 85, 1, 3, 195027) The present campaign in its inception is based on the assumption that the reform is required by the vast majority of the caste Hindus and that the prohibition against the suppressed classes is not warranted by the genuine Hindu scriptures.
('31', 85, 1, 4, 195267) For me, therefore, not to have made the proposals would have betrayed woeful lack of resourcefulness.
('31', 85, 1, 5, 195369) It was the most natural thing for a satyagrahi like myself to have made the proposals which, if they had proceeded from the orthodox party, I could not have honestly rejected.
('31', 85, 1, 6, 195545) Indeed, I make bold to say that my proposals paved the way for the remarkable support the cause received everywhere, save among the very few members of the orthodox party.
('31', 85, 1, 7, 195717) Had there been real opposition from the majority of caste Hindus, or had there been any doubt as to the Shastric endorsement of the reform, the satyagraha would have assumed a different shape altogether.
('31', 85, 1, 8, 195921) It would have been then a movement for a change in the religion rather than the removal of an irreligious custom.
('31', 85, 1, 9, 196035) Indeed, those who were in immediate charge of the movement never questioned the propriety of my proposals.
('31', 85, 1, 10, 196142) I could not take any step without consultation with them and without their full concurrence.
('31', 85, 1, 11, 196235) It now remains for the satyagrahis at Vykom to carry out the letter and the spirit of the agreement and for the caste Hindus to support the movement in the manner promised by them everywhere to ensure the speedy and successful ending of the struggle.
('31', 85, 1, 12, 196486) The satyagrahis must fulfil the letter by not overstepping the boundary line until a settlement is reached, or a crossing after due notice by me becomes necessary for furthering the object of the agreement.
('31', 85, 1, 13, 196693) The spirit of it requires gentleness and utmost humility on the part of the satyagrahis.
('31', 85, 1, 14, 196782) Their uniform courtesy towards the opponents of reform will break the edge of the opposition.
('31', 85, 1, 15, 196876) They must regard the Government not as opposed to the reform but as pledged to carry it out at the earliest possible moment.
('31', 85, 1, 16, 197001) I have not the slightest reason to doubt the word of Her Highness the Maharani Regent or the Dewan or the Commissioner of Police.
('31', 85, 1, 17, 197131) The conduct of satyagrahis in the Ashram must be in correspondence with their bearing at the boundary line.
('31', 85, 1, 18, 197239) The Ashram must be a busy hive in which every member is ever found at his own allotted task.
('31', 85, 1, 19, 197332) It must be a model of simplicity and sanitation.
('31', 85, 1, 20, 197381) The members are pledged to the charkha work during all spare moments.
('31', 85, 1, 21, 197451) The spinning, the carding and the weaving departments admit of considerable improvement.
('31', 86, 0, 1, 197540) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 87
('31', 86, 1, 2, 197581) inmate should be an expert carder and spinner if everyone cannot also become an expert weaver.
('31', 86, 1, 3, 197676) The members must insist on spinning and weaving at least the cloth required by them.
('31', 86, 1, 4, 197761) They should also learn Hindi well.
('31', 86, 1, 5, 197796) They are or should regard themselves as trustees for the prestige and dignity of Hinduism.
('31', 86, 1, 6, 197887) Theirs is a fight not to end with the opening of the roads round temples but it should be considered to be the beginning of a glorious struggle for the purity of hinduism and removal of the abuses that have crept into it.
('31', 86, 1, 7, 198109) They are not reformers who would take no note of the opposite side or would violate every sentiment of the orthodox people.
('31', 86, 1, 8, 198233) They would vie with the tallest among the orthodox in purity of conduct and veneration for all that is good and noble in the Shastras.
('31', 86, 1, 9, 198368) They would not disregard scriptural authority without the deepest thought, and to tha end, some of them would even study Sanskrit and explore the possibilities of reform within the four corners of the scriptures.
('31', 86, 1, 10, 198581) They will not be in a hurry, but having fearlessly taken all the steps that they can consistently with their creed of truth and non violence, will have the patience and the faith of the rishis of old.
('31', 86, 2, 11, 198782) ENTRY INTO TEMPLES For, the opening of the roads is not the final but the first step in the ladder of reform.
('31', 86, 2, 12, 198892) Temples in general, public wells, public schools must be open to the untouchables equally with the caste Hindus.
('31', 86, 2, 13, 199005) But that is not the present goal of the satyagrahis.
('31', 86, 2, 14, 199058) We may not force the pace.
('31', 86, 2, 15, 199085) The schools are almost all open to the untouchables.
('31', 86, 2, 16, 199138) The temples and the public wells or tanks are not.

('31', 87, 2, 3, 199804) SIKH SACRIFICE The Akali position still seems to be uncertain.
('31', 87, 2, 4, 199867) In the resume published by Sardar Mangal Singh in his capacity as President of the Central Sikh League occurs the following summary of the Sikh sacrifices:
('31', 87, 3, 5, 200023) 30,000 arrested, 400 died and killed, 2,000 wounded, Rs. 15 lakhs of fine including forfeitures of pensions of retired soldiers.
('31', 87, 3, 6, 200152) If these figures are verifiable, they tell a tale of sacrifice which reflects the highest credit on Sikh courage and self sacrifice, and means equal discredit for a Government that has taken no count of their sufferings.
('31', 87, 4, 7, 200373) BENGAL I hope to attend the Provincial Conference that is to be held at Faridpur on 2nd May next.

('31', 87, 5, 13, 201094) MILK SLIVERS I understand that in several places mill slivers are still used for spinning.

('31', 87, 5, 16, 201476) It is impossible and useless to send mill slivers to these villages.
('31', 87, 5, 17, 201545) To cart slivers from Bombay to a Punjab village would be a remedy worse than the disease.
('31', 87, 5, 18, 201635) Carding is not a defunct occupation.
('31', 87, 5, 19, 201672) It is possible to get professional carders almost anywhere.

('31', 90, 3, 17, 208347) 58.THE NATIONAL WEEK The 6th and 13th of April must for ever remain green in Indian memory.
('31', 90, 3, 18, 208439) 6th April 1919 witnessed an unexpected and huge mass awakening of the nation.
('31', 90, 3, 19, 208517) On 13th of April the nation we made to offer a sacrifice in which Hindu, Mussalman and Sikh blood mingled at Jallianwala Bagh.
('31', 90, 3, 20, 208644) They became one in death.
('31', 90, 3, 21, 208670) Since then much water has flown under the Sabarmati bridge.
('31', 90, 3, 22, 208730) The nation has passed through many vicissitudes.
('31', 90, 3, 23, 208779) Today Hindu Muslim unity seems to have been but a dream.
('31', 90, 3, 24, 208836) I observe that both are preparing for a fight.

('31', 91, 1, 2, 209259) upon the British bayonet or the slippery justice of law courts.
('31', 91, 1, 3, 209323) Not to rely upon either, at the crucial moment, is the best training for swaraj.
('31', 91, 1, 4, 209404) The supersession 1 of Sir Abdur Rahim, the passage of the Supplementary Ordinance 2, the restoration of the salt tax, tell us in plainest language that the British rulers propose to rule in spite of our opposition.
('31', 91, 1, 5, 209619) In fact, they tell us by their action as clearly as possible, that they can and will rule without our assistance.

('31', 92, 2, 7, 212204) 59. TWO QUESTIONS During my travels in the South, I discovered that Congress organizations accepted money in lieu of yarn for membership.
('31', 92, 2, 8, 212342) I understood that the practice had become almost universal.
('31', 92, 2, 9, 212402) As a member myself and as editor, I have no hesitation in saying that the practice is illegal.
('31', 92, 2, 10, 212497) Whether it is so in fact or not only the Working Committee can decide.
('31', 92, 2, 11, 212568) I have no desire as President to give rulings in such matters.
('31', 92, 2, 12, 212631) But as a common sense man writing for common sense people, I remind Congressmen that the idea of importing money payment as an alternative was discussed and rejected.
('31', 92, 2, 13, 212798) The idea of yarn being treated as subscription was that everyone desirous of joining the Congress was to be expected himself to take the trouble of knowing good hand spun yarn from bad and purchasing it.
('31', 92, 2, 14, 213002) The Congress ledgers can only contain yarn receipts, not monetary subscriptions.
('31', 92, 2, 15, 213083) To take money payments, therefore, is to violate the constitution.
('31', 92, 2, 16, 213150) I would go a step further and say that the spirit of the pact 1 requires the Congress organizations to cater and canvass for only self spinning members.
('31', 92, 2, 17, 213303) Those who do not wish to spin themselves may send in their quota of yarn but a Congress organization should put forth its best effort by merely catering for self spinners to popularize hand spinning among its members.
('31', 92, 2, 18, 213521) I, therefore, hold it to be the duty of the Congress organizations to return all monetary payments.
('31', 92, 2, 19, 213621) It is for private agencies to provide hand spun yarn to those who wish to buy it.
('31', 92, 2, 20, 213703) Unless this limitation is observed, we cannot claim to have worked or given a fair trial to the new franchise.
('31', 92, 2, 21, 213814) Personally, I do not mind even though we may have only a few hundred self spinning members
('31', 92, 3, 22, 213905) 1 The Calcutta Pact; vide “Joint Statement with Party Leaders”, November 6, 1924.
('31', 93, 0, 1, 213987) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 93, 1, 2, 214028) provided that they do the spinning without any stimulation save what is contained in the pride of belonging to the Congress.

('31', 132, 2, 4, 304802) 79. NOTES
('31', 132, 3, 5, 304812) TO PROVINCIAL SECRETARIES
('31', 132, 4, 6, 304838) I hope that Provincial Secretaries will continue to send to the General Secretary and to Young India office the returns of mem bership from week to week and with such further details as may throw light on the working of the franchise.
('31', 132, 4, 7, 305073) It is the easiest thing for Congress organizations to defeat the purpose of the new franchise.
('31', 132, 4, 8, 305168) But they are expected to put their whole heart into it, to make it work successfully.
('31', 132, 4, 9, 305254) Nor is mere enlistment the sole or even the chief part of the work.
('31', 132, 4, 10, 305322) To keep up the membership requires ceaseless watching and continuously improved oraganization.
('31', 132, 4, 11, 305417) It is no easy thing for those who have hitherto satisfied their national conscience by simply flinging a few rupees or a few annas into the Congress cash box to think of the nation day after day and to labour for it even though it be for half an hour per day.
('31', 132, 4, 12, 305677) Ten thousand such spinners will revolutionize our national life and bring light to the dim eyes of millions of paupers of India.
('31', 132, 4, 13, 305806) These ten thousand spinners must be voluntary in every sense of the term—not the semi starved spinners who spin for a living but who would give also perhaps half an hour to the nation free.
('31', 132, 4, 14, 305996) I want these, too, if they will spin without undue pressure.
('31', 132, 4, 15, 306057) But the real khaddar atmosphere—the atmosphere of action rather than speech, of self help rather than helplessness—will be produced only by ten thousand spinners drawn from the middle class men and women who today belong to the Congress and work the organization.
('31', 132, 5, 16, 306321) KHADDAR IN KATHIAWAR The Working Committee of the Kathiawar Political Conference has arrived at an important decision regarding khaddar propaganda.
('31', 132, 5, 17, 306469) It resolved to collect cotton from the various districts of Kathiawar for distribution among spinners and get it spun.
('31', 132, 5, 18, 306588) It had already received promises of over 300 maunds from donors.
('31', 132, 5, 19, 306653) Now it had resolved to
('31', 133, 0, 1, 306676) 134 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 133, 1, 2, 306718) collect at least 800 maunds or, which is the same thing, Rs. 19,200 for the work.
('31', 133, 1, 3, 306800) The idea is to get this cotton spun and woven into khaddar.
('31', 133, 1, 4, 306860) Kathiawar is a poor peninsula with a very small rainfall.
('31', 133, 1, 5, 306918) In some places there is a chronic famine condition.
('31', 133, 1, 6, 306970) Thousands of women would spin for supplementing their slender resources.
('31', 133, 1, 7, 307043) It has also thousands of weavers among untouchables, who for want of their hereditary occupation are obliged to go to Bombay or elsewhere and work as scavengers in order to keep body and soul together.
('31', 133, 1, 8, 307245) Khaddar at the present moment is not as cheap as it might be.
('31', 133, 1, 9, 307307) It has, therefore, been resolved to find out families that would spin for their own clothing if they had a supply of silvers at cheap rates and facilities for getting their yarn woven also at cheap rates.
('31', 133, 1, 10, 307512) The Parishad has, therefore, in order to encourage such families, undertaken to supply silvers at 6 annas per lb., no family to be supplied with more than 10 lbs.
('31', 133, 1, 11, 307675) during the year, and to pay half the cost of weaving.
('31', 133, 1, 12, 307729) The khaddar
('31', 133, 2, 13, 307741) will cost the consumer a little over a third of the cost of 31 4 annas per
('31', 133, 3, 14, 307816) yard instead of 9 annas which is the usual rate ruling in Kathiawar.
('31', 133, 3, 15, 307885) Thus he will have 50 p.c.
('31', 133, 3, 16, 307911) bounty in order to induce him to spin and wear the khaddar woven out of his yarn.
('31', 133, 3, 17, 307993) To put it another way it is proposed to clothe out of Rs. 19,000 worth of cotton at least 2,750 families consisting of husband, wife and child.
('31', 133, 3, 18, 308137) The following wages will have been distributed or earned before the cotton becomes khaddar: Ginning 800 Mds.
('31', 133, 3, 19, 308246) Rs. 1,000 Carding 800 Mds.
('31', 133, 3, 20, 308273) Rs. 4,000 Spinning 700 Mds.
('31', 133, 3, 21, 308301) Rs. 7,000 Weaving 675 Mds.
('31', 133, 3, 22, 308328) Rs. 6,750
('31', 133, 4, 23, 308338) Total : Rs. 18,750 In the process of carding the weight will be reduced from 800 to 700 and in spinning it will be further reduced to 675 mds.
('31', 133, 4, 24, 308481) In length the khaddar will be 67,500 yards and 30 inches in width.
('31', 133, 4, 25, 308548) The count will be on an average 8. This is an experiment which is fraught with important economic consequences.
('31', 133, 4, 26, 308660) The cotton, it will be noted, will be hand ginned.
('31', 133, 4, 27, 308711) I hope to summarize the results of the experiment from time to time.
('31', 133, 4, 28, 308780) I must mention here that it is possible to contemplate an experiment of his nature only because Kathiawar has got three well managed khaddar centres with trained workers.
('31', 133, 4, 29, 308951) The money has still to be collected and it must be inside of two months’ time.
('31', 133, 4, 30, 309030) I hope that every Kathiawari will help either by contributing his labour or funds.

('31', 143, 1, 7, 332128) These resolutions provide three ways of popularizing khadi and spinning.
('31', 143, 1, 8, 332201) The first and the best is to induce some Families to wear cloth made from yarn spun by themselves.
('31', 143, 1, 9, 332300) The second is to have a class of members who would spin for half an hour daily and would always wear khadi, buying their requirements from the market.
('31', 143, 1, 10, 332451) The third way is to produce khadi for those who wear it though they themselves do not spin.
('31', 143, 1, 11, 332543) Though the last two steps in this are important, they call for no discussion.
('31', 143, 1, 12, 332621) But the first one does.
('31', 143, 1, 13, 332645) It is the best way for popularizing khadi.
('31', 143, 1, 14, 332688) It involves a little expenditure, however.

('31', 144, 0, 1, 332812) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 145

('31', 144, 1, 3, 332879) The plan is to get 2750 families to spin and wear khadi, at an expenditure of Rs. 19,200. One family is estimated as consisting of a couple and a child, making a total of 8250 persons.
('31', 144, 1, 4, 333064) The benefit is evident enough.
('31', 144, 1, 5, 333095) Yarn produced from ten pounds of slivers will give sufficient cloth for a family to last for a year.
('31', 144, 1, 6, 333196) After this, no further effort will be required to create love of khadi in those who have worn it for a year.

('31', 144, 1, 9, 333463) Hence Shri Devchandbhai has described this plan as an insurance against famine, and he is right.

('31', 152, 1, 2, 350862) 87. INTERVIEW TO “ THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE 1”
('31', 152, 2, 3, 350905) BOMBAY, [On or before April 13, 1925]
('31', 152, 3, 4, 350943) Questioned whether there was any truth in the suggestion that he had purposely avoided calling the meeting of the All India Congress Committee, although more than three months had elapsed since the Congress session, Mahatma replied: The charge is baseless.
('31', 152, 3, 5, 351200) I have not convened a meeting of the A.I.C.C. for the simple and obvious reason that I have no new policy or new programme to place before the country.
('31', 152, 3, 6, 351352) Nor have I heard of any new programme to be placed before the Committee by any member.
('31', 152, 3, 7, 351439) The one that was mapped out at Belgaum is incredibly simple.
('31', 152, 3, 8, 351500) It has only to be worked out by each province to the best of its ability.
('31', 152, 3, 9, 351574) If, however, there is a desire on the part of any members for the A.I.C.C. to meet, I shall gladly ask Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru to convene the meeting.
('31', 152, 4, 10, 351725) Is it true that some Committees are accepting cash value for yarn as

('31', 160, 3, 18, 369377) 93. NOTES TO CORRESPONDENTS I have before me a pile of correspondence from all parts of the world which demands my personal attention.

('31', 177, 1, 2, 407770) 106. SPEECH IN REPLY TO ADDRESS BY LOCAL BOARD, BROACH April 18, 1925 Prompted by your overwhelming love for me, you have used irrelevant epithets in your address.
('31', 177, 1, 3, 407934) Whether I deserve them or not is a different matter.
('31', 177, 1, 4, 407987) It is therefore difficult for me to make a fitting reply.
('31', 177, 1, 5, 408045) Your duties include cleaning of roads and making provision for the education of children, including the children of Antyajas.
('31', 177, 1, 6, 408171) These are certainly public duties, and of considerable importance though seem ingly trivial.
('31', 177, 1, 7, 408264) But the epithets you have used will not help you in their performance.

('31', 179, 2, 5, 412653) 108. MY NOTES
('31', 179, 3, 6, 412667) A CORRECTION Writing about the wedding of Shri Devchandbhai Parekh’s daughter, I said that Shri Trikamlal alone had formed the bride groom’s party.
('31', 179, 3, 7, 412815) 1 But he informs me that he had gone merely in conformity with the practice in his community, that is, accom panied by twenty five for more persons.
('31', 179, 3, 8, 412964) I felt unhappy when I heard this.
('31', 179, 3, 9, 412998) He also felt sorry to have to correct my error.
('31', 179, 3, 10, 413046) But whether or not one feels sorry, an error is an error and must be corrected.
('31', 179, 3, 11, 413126) We cannot create examples by imagining what never happened.
('31', 179, 3, 12, 413186) Shri Trikamlal need not have taken twenty five persons with him.
('31', 179, 3, 13, 413251) But, having already carried out many reforms, he did not have the cour age to attempt one more and so took with him such a large party.
('31', 179, 3, 14, 413387) Even so, he followed one rule very firmly, and that is, that no one in the party accepted even a pie by way of customary gift from the bride’s father.
('31', 179, 4, 15, 413538) HARDSHIPS OF “ANTYAJAS”
('31', 179, 5, 16, 413562) During the present tour of Kathiawar, I have come to know more about the hardships of Antyajas.
('31', 179, 5, 17, 413658) They cannot get water from wells in the villages.
('31', 179, 5, 18, 413708) They are permitted to draw it only from troughs meant for cattle and other animals.
('31', 179, 5, 19, 413792) They complained to me at many places about this.
('31', 179, 5, 20, 413841) This is, certainly, no small hardship.
('31', 179, 5, 21, 413880) It is well nigh impossible of dig separate wells for them in every village.
('31', 179, 5, 22, 413956) In the hard soil of Kathiawar, where water is struck only at very great depth, digg ing a well may cost as much as three thousand rupees.
('31', 179, 5, 23, 414094) In such circumstances, how many new wells can we afford to dig?
('31', 179, 5, 24, 414158) Everyone has a right to water.
('31', 179, 5, 25, 414189) To exclude Antyajas even from this is the very limit of hatred.
('31', 179, 5, 26, 414253) If people are afraid of being polluted by contact with them, separate hours for drawing water may be fixed for them.
('31', 179, 5, 27, 414370) I cannot see any trace of religion in such hard heartedness.
('31', 179, 6, 28, 414431) 1 Vide “My Notes”, 29 3 1925.
('31', 180, 0, 1, 414461) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 181
('31', 180, 1, 2, 414503) EVILS AMONG “ANTYAJAS” If I saw more of the cruelty towards Antyajas during this tour of Kathiawar, I had also some bitter experience of the evils prevalent among them.
('31', 180, 1, 3, 414672) While talking with the Antyajas of Dhasa, Hadala and Mangrol, I came to know that they eat carrion.
('31', 180, 1, 4, 414772) They call it ‘dust’.
('31', 180, 1, 5, 414793) When I pressed them to give us this unclean habit, they replied that it was an old practice and was difficult to give up.
('31', 180, 1, 6, 414915) I tried hard to persuade them, but to no effect.
('31', 180, 1, 7, 414964) They admitted that the practice should be given up, but pleaded that they did not have the necessary energy and said no more.
('31', 180, 1, 8, 415090) However earnestly one may plead with Hindus, it will be extremely difficult to remove the general aversion against those who eat rottent meat.
('31', 180, 1, 9, 415233) Perhaps people may tolerate this unclean habit of the Antyajas but they will never mix with them with real love.
('31', 180, 1, 10, 415346) Whatever the difficulty in the way, the Antyajas should make a determined effort to get rid of this habit.
('31', 180, 1, 11, 415453) They and their sadhus should start a vigorous movement and must end this extremely disgusting practice.
('31', 180, 1, 12, 415557) One Antyaja, while admitting his weakness, was frank enough to tell me that if they were never asked to remove dead cattle, they would give up eating their flesh.
('31', 180, 1, 13, 415720) I asked him if Antyajas would agree to the Durbar Saheb passing a law forbidding any chamar from removing dead cattle, and he immediately answered they would.
('31', 180, 1, 14, 415879) ‘‘But, then, how would you live ?’’ ‘‘We shall manage somehow, perhaps take up weaving, but will not come to you with our difficulties.’’ I knew that it was necessary to study the chamar’s profession and remove the drawbacks in it, but I realized this all the more clearly after the above conversation.
('31', 180, 1, 15, 416182) Another evil among the Antyajas is that Dheds, who are wea vers, avoid touching chamars and the latter avoid touching Bhangis.
('31', 180, 1, 16, 416309) In this way, the practice of untouchability has spread as between sections of the Antyajas.
('31', 180, 1, 17, 416401) The logical meaning of this is that we should have separate wells, schools, etc., for chamars, Bhangis and so on.
('31', 180, 1, 18, 416515) It is extremely difficult to satisfy all sections among six crores of Antyajas.
('31', 180, 1, 19, 416595) The only way out of this is that we should mix freely among the communities regarded as the lowest among them and, whatever we do to help Antyajas, should be for the benefit of these communities and only in places where their needs are likely to be served.
('31', 180, 1, 20, 416852) Then all distinctions will disappear automatically.
('31', 181, 0, 1, 416904) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 181, 1, 2, 416946) For these evils, it is the so called high caste Hindus who are responsible.
('31', 181, 1, 3, 417022) They kept away from the Antyajas completely, and the latter, for want of opportunities of advance, fell very low.
('31', 181, 1, 4, 417136) In giving them a helping hand, we shall be raising ourselves.
('31', 181, 1, 5, 417198) Unless one comes down, one cannot raise others.
('31', 181, 1, 6, 417246) In raising the Antyajas, the caste Hindus will be raising themselves.
('31', 181, 2, 7, 417316) MODEL VILLAGES Chalala, a village at a little distance from Amreli, is in many ways a model village.
('31', 181, 2, 8, 417417) A meeting was held there in the early morning The utmost quiet prevailed and the arrangements made were the finest.
('31', 181, 2, 9, 417533) The people of the village have, with their own unaided efforts, reared trees on the road and so we saw there beautiful neem trees such as are rare in those parts.
('31', 181, 2, 10, 417696) The village has a school which runs very well.
('31', 181, 2, 11, 417743) Antyajas are freely admitted to it.
('31', 181, 2, 12, 417779) They attended the meeting and sat mixed indistinguishably with the rest of the audience.
('31', 181, 2, 13, 417868) There is a school for khadi work in Chalala, in which people spin, some more, some less.Very few people were dressed in khadi, but when I appealed to them to take a pledge quite a few hands were raised.
('31', 181, 2, 14, 418071) The village owed these reforms to four or five persons, and chiefly, as others told me, to the ceaseless efforts of Shri Hargovind, a school teacher, and Manibehn, his sister.
('31', 181, 2, 15, 418247) A visitor to Chalala will discover what the sincere and persevering efforts of one or two persons can achieve.

('31', 182, 1, 2, 419221) DELICATE There are young men among us who are much too soft in every way, soft in body and soft in mind.
('31', 182, 1, 3, 419326) Some of these delicate friends have addressed letters to me after reading my article.
('31', 182, 1, 4, 419412) “Is this Non co operation?” 1 The substance of their letters is that I have not listened to and tried to understand the non co operators, side of the story and have done them injustice.
('31', 182, 1, 5, 419598) The correspondents believe that my criticism was aimed at them.
('31', 182, 1, 6, 419662) I do not know against whom it was aimed.
('31', 182, 1, 7, 419703) I did not have any particular person in mind when writing the article.
('31', 182, 1, 8, 419774) I merely used letters of criticism from other correspondents and tried to remove some misconceptions.
('31', 182, 1, 9, 419876) There is not a single sen tence in my criticism which can be interpreted to mean that I have credited the statements of those correspondents.
('31', 182, 1, 10, 420018) When I receive any criticism of a person, and doubts arise in my mind, I generally place my doubts.
('31', 182, 1, 11, 420118) before him and only then do I make any statement.
('31', 182, 1, 12, 420168) In this particular case, I do not even remember the names, except one.
('31', 182, 1, 13, 420239) I do not understand how these friends who have written to me thought that the criticism in my altogether objective article fitted them.
('31', 182, 1, 14, 420375) If they deserve the criticism, they have no reason to feel hurt.
('31', 182, 1, 15, 420440) If they do not deserve it, they should see that it is not meant for them.
('31', 182, 1, 16, 420514) These correspondents should not think that this explanation, too, is aimed at them.
('31', 182, 1, 17, 420598) It is aimed at the softness common among us, at our sensitiveness.
('31', 182, 1, 18, 420665) Public workers should know that they are certain to be criticized.
('31', 182, 1, 19, 420732) It is one of the qualities necessary in such workers that they should be able to bear criticism.
('31', 182, 1, 20, 420829) People who criticize do so with pure motives.
('31', 182, 1, 21, 420875) There are exceptions, of course; some persons criticize through spite.
('31', 182, 1, 22, 420946) One should bear even their criticism.
('31', 182, 1, 23, 420984) My criticism was, and is, about a certain state of mind which is quite common.
('31', 182, 2, 24, 421063) THE PLAGUE I had to return through Rajkot at the end of my recent tour of Kathiawar.
('31', 182, 2, 25, 421148) From friends who met me at the station I heard that the city had been completely deserted because of the plague.
('31', 182, 2, 26, 421261) I will not discuss at the moment whether it is right for people thus to leave a place out of fear or to remain there and observe the rules of cleanlines and take other suitable measures.
('31', 182, 2, 27, 421448) This, however, I can say, that it
('31', 182, 3, 28, 421482) 1 Dated April 5, 1925
('31', 183, 0, 1, 421504) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 183, 1, 2, 421546) should be quite easy to protect a city like Rajkot against the plague.
('31', 183, 1, 3, 421617) But the report which pained me most was that some persons are even afraid of performing the funeral rites of plague victims, and these rites, therefore, have to be attended to by the Seva Samiti or the State.
('31', 183, 1, 4, 421826) However much one may fear death, one is bound to nurse one's own people.

('31', 183, 2, 7, 422080) CART FOR CARRYING THE DEAD In this connection, I recall Bhai Chhotalal Tejpal’s suggestion for a cart to carry the dead.
('31', 183, 2, 8, 422201) He has, in fact, gone crazy over his idea.
('31', 183, 2, 9, 422244) As I see a panacea in the spinning wheel, so he sees one in such a cart.
('31', 183, 2, 10, 422317) We need not however, pay attention to his habit of exaggeration or to his craziness.
('31', 183, 2, 11, 422402) We should only consider the valid elements in his argument.
('31', 183, 2, 12, 422462) He argues that carrying the body of a dead person on shoulders in a hardship, that it requires the attendance of many person at the funeral and that it is an almost impossible task for the poorest sections in society.
('31', 183, 2, 13, 422680) He suggests, therefore, that the right thing is to use a cart for carrying a dead body.
('31', 183, 2, 14, 422768) With this idea, he has actually designed a cart for use in Rajkot and lends it free of charge to the common people.
('31', 183, 2, 15, 422884) We may leave aside for the moment the question whether on every occasion of death we should carry the body in a cart.
('31', 183, 2, 16, 423002) But in situations like an epidemic of the plague, when men are not available in sufficient number and those who carry the bodies run a risk, it is wisdom to use a cart whenever necessary.
('31', 183, 2, 17, 423190) It has not been laid down that the body of a dead person should always be carried by men on their shoulders.
('31', 183, 2, 18, 423299) It is only a matter of custom.
('31', 183, 2, 19, 423330) In places where the cremation ground is at a distance or there is extreme heat or the number of persons to carry the body is very small, the cart can be a great help.
('31', 183, 2, 20, 423497) The cart designed by Shri Chhotalal can be drawn by men and does not require a horse or any other animal.
('31', 183, 2, 21, 423603) Just one or two persons can draw it all the way without getting fatigued.
('31', 183, 2, 22, 423677) I would advise everyone to use this cart wherever necessary.

('31', 187, 2, 5, 428994) BENGAL AGAIN
('31', 187, 3, 6, 429007) I am looking forward to the Bengal tour in great hope.
('31', 187, 3, 7, 429062) Bengal has the finest imagination.
('31', 187, 3, 8, 429097) The Bengali youth are keenwitted.
('31', 187, 3, 9, 429131) They are self sacrificing.
('31', 187, 3, 10, 429158) Letters received from all over Bengal are most enticing.
('31', 187, 3, 11, 429215) I wish I had the health to stand the strain that the tour should involve.
('31', 187, 3, 12, 429289) My Kathiawar tour has given me malarial fever which though brought under subjection has left me very weak.
('31', 187, 3, 13, 429396) I hope to pick up strength during the nine days that still remain at my disposal.
('31', 187, 3, 14, 429478) But I ask the organizers to make my daily labour as light as possible.
('31', 187, 3, 15, 429549) I repeat once more that I would like the whole tour to be thoroughly business like.
('31', 187, 3, 16, 429633) Bengal is said to lack business capacity.
('31', 187, 3, 17, 429675) Let the charge be falsified.
('31', 187, 3, 18, 429704) When business like habits are added to a keen and imaginative intellect the combination carries everything before it.
('31', 187, 3, 19, 429822) May Bengal show the combination.
('31', 187, 3, 20, 429855) I expect, in every place, full statistical information.
('31', 187, 3, 21, 429911) If every address, instead of reminding or informing me of my many virtues, were to give a faithful record of the activities of the district or town presenting it, what an education it would be for me?
('31', 187, 3, 22, 430112) For instance, every address can give me accurate information about the number of self spinning and other members, the number of spinning wheels working, the average capacity of each wheel, the counts spun, the monthly output of yarn and khaddar, the number of looms working with hand spun and other yarn, the number of kha ddar depots and the sales in each, etc.
('31', 187, 3, 23, 430475) The address may also give the number of national schools and colleges with the number of boys and girls attending them.
('31', 187, 3, 24, 430595) It may add all the information about activity among the untouchables and their condition before and after the commencement of organized work among them.
('31', 187, 3, 25, 430748) It should describe the Hindu Muslim condition and finish off with a description of the drink and opium traffic.
('31', 187, 3, 26, 430860) Even if it be too late to embody all the valuable information in the addresses, it would be well to give me the information on a separate piece of paper.
('31', 187, 3, 27, 431014) May I also say that it would be wrong to give me costly caskets or frames for the addresses?
('31', 188, 0, 1, 431107) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 189
('31', 188, 1, 2, 431149) I should be satisfied with hand written addresses on handmade paper or on a piece of khaddar.
('31', 188, 1, 3, 431243) I need not tell Bengal that it may make an address artistic without making if costly or unportable.
('31', 188, 1, 4, 431343) In Travan core, in several places, the addresses were traced on delicate little palmyra leaves.
('31', 188, 1, 5, 431439) I want to reach the heart of Bengal as of India.
('31', 188, 1, 6, 431488) And where heart is to speak to heart, costly things and even fine phrases are a hindrance rather than a help.
('31', 188, 1, 7, 431598) I am hungering for deeds not words.
('31', 188, 1, 8, 431634) Solid khaddar work is dearer to me than heavy gold or silver plate.
('31', 188, 2, 9, 431702) MORE TALES OR WOE The Sikh cup of sorrow is evidently not yet full.
('31', 188, 2, 10, 431770) Here is a wire from Amritsar:
('31', 188, 3, 11, 431800) Shiromani Gurudwara Prabandhak Committee has received harrowing details of beating not excluding pulling of bears and keshas of members 2nd Shahidi Jatha in Camp Jails Nabha on 16th April.
('31', 188, 3, 12, 431989) Beating inflicted to exact apologies.
('31', 188, 3, 13, 432027) Committee has also received some hair and beards pulled out.
('31', 188, 3, 14, 432088) There are now in Nabha one hundred and fourteen cases of sufferers of this beating.
('31', 188, 3, 15, 432172) Composition as under: serious seven, contusion of head two, face eight, arm ten, thigh seven, shin eight, private parts eight, back five, minor hurts fifty one.
('31', 188, 3, 16, 432333) Kindly arrange immediate visit Nabha Camp Jail.
('31', 188, 3, 17, 432381) Either the statement is true or it is untrue.
('31', 188, 3, 18, 432427) If it is true, it calls for an open and impartial inquiry.
('31', 188, 3, 19, 432486) The Government of India cannot plead neutrality.
('31', 188, 3, 20, 432535) Their own officer is administering the State.
('31', 188, 3, 21, 432581) To the Sikh friends I can only say every wrong has a remedy.
('31', 188, 3, 22, 432642) And this wrong, if the allegations can be sustained, will not long remain without a remedy.
('31', 188, 3, 23, 432734) As a journalist as well as President of the Congress, I plead my present helplessness to render aid beyond giving publicity and tendering my sympathy, but God willing I shall not remain long helpless.
('31', 188, 3, 24, 432935) Every wound inflicted on innocence is a wound cut deep into every Congressman and every journalist.
('31', 188, 3, 25, 433035) And these wounds are winged messengers who carry their own tale to the four corners of the earth, pierce through the heavens and reach the great white Throne of Justice.

('31', 189, 1, 2, 433270) 115. NO SIGN YET One of the numerous addresses presented to me in the South contains the following remarkable sentence:
('31', 189, 2, 3, 433390) Though you have cried halt at Bardoli, we still cherish the hope that you will, in the near future, lead us to the battlefield, wherein we shall all subdue our differences in our fight for swaraj, with the pure and unsullied weapon of non violent mass civil disobedience, wihout which, it is well nigh im possible to attain swaraj from the hands of an unwilling and greedy nation, whose imperialism is nothing but ruthless exploitation.
('31', 189, 2, 4, 433827) There is here a slight disappoinment over the Bardoli decision.
('31', 189, 2, 5, 433891) I know that many thought at the time, and still think, that the Bardoli decision was a political blunder of the first magnitude and showed my utter unfitness for political leadership.
('31', 189, 2, 6, 434075) In my opinion, however, the Bardoli decision was a great service I rendered to the country.
('31', 189, 2, 7, 434167) It showed on my part, not lack of political judgment, but abundance of political foresight.
('31', 189, 2, 8, 434259) The lessons that we have learnt since were well worth learning.
('31', 189, 2, 9, 434323) If we had then earned a cheap victory, it would have cost us dear, and British Imperialism would have consolidated itself with fresh vigour.
('31', 189, 2, 10, 434464) Not that it is not consolidated enough now.
('31', 189, 2, 11, 434508) But the consolidation then would have been far more effective.
('31', 189, 2, 12, 434571) Critics may say this is all argument based on probability.
('31', 189, 2, 13, 434630) And so far it is.
('31', 189, 2, 14, 434648) But for me the probability borders on certainty.
('31', 189, 2, 15, 434697) Anyway, the Bardoli decision enables me to hope for a day, not far distant, when a fight will become a great probability.
('31', 189, 2, 16, 434819) Any fight now to be under taken must be a fight to the finish.
('31', 189, 2, 17, 434882) But I must freely confess that there is nothing today on the Indian horizon to warrant the hope of early mass civil disobedience.
('31', 189, 2, 18, 435012) For one thing, there are not enough workers for organizing such a struggle.
('31', 189, 2, 19, 435088) It requires closer touch with the masses than we have yet shown ourselves capable of.
('31', 189, 2, 20, 435174) It needs greater, warmer and continuous service of, and identification with the masses than we have yet felt desirous of.
('31', 189, 2, 21, 435296) We must feel and be one with the masses before we can expect successfully to lead them to a peaceful victory.
('31', 189, 2, 22, 435406) Indeed when we have arrived at that stage, mass civil disobedience will hardly be necessary.
('31', 189, 2, 23, 435499) But we must have that con fidence in ourselves.
('31', 189, 2, 24, 435547) Today I, at any rate, have none.
('31', 189, 2, 25, 435580) Any attempt at the present moment at mass civil disobedience must result in undis ciplined sporadic violence which will be put down the instant it breaks forth.
('31', 189, 2, 26, 435741) But civil disobedience does not admit of any violence or countenancing of violence directly or indirectly.
('31', 189, 2, 27, 435848) The spinning wheel
('31', 190, 0, 1, 435867) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 191
('31', 190, 1, 2, 435909) is undoubtedly designed to bring about that peaceful and calm atmosphere of solemn determination.
('31', 190, 1, 3, 436007) It is the symbol of social service of the highest order.
('31', 190, 1, 4, 436064) It is the cement to bind the masses to us national servants.
('31', 190, 1, 5, 436125) It is a precursor of conscious co operation on a scale hitherto unknown to the world.
('31', 190, 1, 6, 436211) If the wheel fails, it means blank despair and starvation for the masses.
('31', 190, 1, 7, 436285) Nothing can so quickly put the masses on their legs as the spinning wheel and all it means.
('31', 190, 1, 8, 436377) It is resistless in its march.
('31', 190, 1, 9, 436408) It is innocence personified.
('31', 190, 1, 10, 436437) It adds dignity to the poverty of the masses because if relieves it of its worst features.
('31', 190, 1, 11, 436528) The wheel is marking progress but not rapid enough for our purpose—not even for bringing about exclusion of foreign cloth from the country.
('31', 190, 1, 12, 436668) But there is no cuase for despair.
('31', 190, 1, 13, 436703) The wheel will weather many a storm and will come through them all scatheless.
('31', 190, 1, 14, 436782) And as I have no other means but truth and non violence for fighting India's battle for freedom, I must swear by it.Though, therefore, mass civil disobedience is practically an impossibility, individual civil disobedience is a possibility, at any time.
('31', 190, 1, 15, 437035) But even that time is not yet.
('31', 190, 1, 16, 437066) There are too many dark and threatening clouds on the horizon that threaten to overwhelm us from within.
('31', 190, 1, 17, 437171) The faith of the out and out believers in charkha, removal of untouchability and Hindu Muslim unity has still to be tested to warrant a positive knowledge of who is who.
('31', 190, 1, 18, 437341) Young India, 23 4 1925
('31', 190, 2, 19, 437364) 116. VARNASHRAM AGAIN A correspondent writes:
('31', 190, 3, 20, 437410) If your recent Madras speech 1 you have re stated your faith in the our varnas.
('31', 190, 3, 21, 437490) But should the varnas be strictly hereditary?
('31', 190, 3, 22, 437536) Some people think that
('31', 190, 4, 23, 437559) you favour rigid adherence to the hereditary principle; others that you do not.
('31', 190, 5, 24, 437639) From a perusal of your writings I am inclined to agree with the former.
('31', 190, 6, 25, 437711) instance, what else does your dictum, that the ‘untouchables should be classed
('31', 190, 7, 26, 437790) with Shudras’ and that they should enjoy all the rights of non Brahmins,
('31', 190, 8, 27, 437863) indicate?
('31', 190, 8, 28, 437873) Why this constant reiteration of the old arbitrary distinction
('31', 190, 9, 29, 437936) between Brahmin and non Brahmin as if the two belonged to biologically
('31', 190, 10, 30, 438007) different spcies?
('31', 190, 10, 31, 438025) If an untouchables can become a non Brahmin, can he not
('31', 190, 11, 32, 438081) also become a Brahmin in this very life?
('31', 190, 11, 33, 438122) Again, if it is possible for an
('31', 190, 12, 34, 438154) untouchable to become a Shudras, how is it impossible for a Shudra to
('31', 190, 13, 35, 438224) 1 Vide “Speech at Public Meeting, Madras”, 22 3 1925.
('31', 191, 0, 1, 438278) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 191, 1, 2, 438320) become a Vaisya, for a Vaisya to become a Kshatriya or for a Kshatriya to
('31', 191, 2, 3, 438394) become a Brahmin in this very life?
('31', 191, 2, 4, 438430) Why do you hurl the Law of Karma in the
('31', 191, 3, 5, 438470) face of those who believe it to be possible?
('31', 191, 3, 6, 438515) Is there a better Brahmin than Sree Narayana Guru Swami, the Ezhava?
('31', 191, 3, 7, 438584) I have no better Brahmin than
('31', 191, 4, 8, 438614) Gandhiji, the Bania.
('31', 191, 4, 9, 438635) I know also of hundreds of other ‘non Brahmins’ who
('31', 191, 5, 10, 438687) are better Brahmins (in the best sense of that term) than most birth Brahmins.
('31', 191, 6, 11, 438766) If you did not favour strict application of the principle of heredity, you would not seek to prohibit intermarriages between people of the same race professing the same religion and following the same customs as are several members of the three Dwija 1 castes.
('31', 191, 6, 12, 439027) Nor would you so strenuously oppose
('31', 191, 7, 13, 439063) inter dining between, say, vegetarian Brahmins and vegetarian non Brahmins.
('31', 191, 8, 14, 439139) Of course, heredity is a great law of life, but there are even greater laws controlling its mysterious processes.
('31', 191, 8, 15, 439253) One of them is the law of variation in the phraseology of Evolutionary Biology.
('31', 191, 8, 16, 439333) Heredity is the static and variation is the dynamic principle of the universe.
('31', 191, 8, 17, 439412) The latter it is that holds the key to
('31', 191, 9, 18, 439451) what we call 'Progress' for want of a better name.
('31', 191, 9, 19, 439502) No social system can ignore the law of heredity with impuntity; neither can a social system ignore the law of variation except at is peril.
('31', 191, 9, 20, 439642) The history of the caste system in India affords enough proof of this.
('31', 191, 9, 21, 439713) It proves above all that the worst form in which the law of heredity can be applied in any social organization is of create a hereditary clergy to be the sole custodians of its intellectual and spiritual affairs and
('31', 191, 10, 22, 439929) trustees in perpetuity of its religion.
('31', 191, 11, 23, 439969) Even Babu Bhagwan Das, than whom there is no more orhodox Brahmin
('31', 191, 12, 24, 440035) and who has done some hard thinking on the subject of social reconstruction
('31', 191, 13, 25, 440111) in India, conceded some years ago that the herditary principle in Varnashrama
('31', 191, 14, 26, 440189) Dharma must be considerably relaxed.
('31', 191, 14, 27, 440226) It would be indeed, strange if you of all
('31', 191, 15, 28, 440268) men championed rigid adherence to it.
('31', 191, 15, 29, 440306) As a great many people do not know
('31', 191, 16, 30, 440341) what exactly you think of it all, I hope it will be possible for you to publish
('31', 191, 17, 31, 440421) this letter with your reply in your esteemed journal.
('31', 191, 17, 32, 440475) I fancy that I have answered all the arguments advanced by the correspondent agains Varnashram.
('31', 191, 17, 33, 440571) But evidently readers have short memories or only those who are concerned for the moment read what is written for them.
('31', 191, 17, 34, 440691) Thus, for instance, I have often shown the distinction betwen Varnashram and untouchability.
('31', 191, 18, 35, 440784) 1 Literally twice born—the term refers to the ceremony of investiture with Upanayma ( sacred thread) which was denied to the Sudras but considered obligatory for the Brahmins, Vaisyas and Kshatriyas.
('31', 192, 0, 1, 440984) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 193
('31', 192, 1, 2, 441026) defended the one as a rational scientific fact and condemned the other as an excrescence, an unmitigated evil.
('31', 192, 1, 3, 441137) I may be that my denseness sees a distinction where none exists.
('31', 192, 1, 4, 441202) It may be, too, that I see science where there is ignorance or superstition.
('31', 192, 1, 5, 441279) But I do regard Varnashram as a healthy division of work based on birth.
('31', 192, 1, 6, 441352) The present ideas of caste are a perversion of the original.
('31', 192, 1, 7, 441413) There is no question with me of superiority or inferiority.
('31', 192, 1, 8, 441473) It is purely a question of duty.
('31', 192, 1, 9, 441506) I have indeed stated that varna is based on birth.
('31', 192, 1, 10, 441557) But I have also said that it is possible for a Shudra, for instance, to become a Vaisya.
('31', 192, 1, 11, 441646) But in order to perform the duty of a Vaisya he does not need the label of a Vaisya.
('31', 192, 1, 12, 441731) Swami Narayan Guru does not need to be called a Brahmin in order to enable him to be, what he reported to be, a Sanskrit scholar.
('31', 192, 1, 13, 441861) He who performs the duty of a Brahmin will easily become one in the next incarnation.
('31', 192, 1, 14, 441947) But a translation from one varna to another in the present incarnation must result in a great deal of fraud.
('31', 192, 1, 15, 442056) The natural consequence must be the obliteration [of] varna.
('31', 192, 1, 16, 442117) I have seen no reason to justfiy its destruction.
('31', 192, 1, 17, 442167) It may be a hindrance to material ambition.
('31', 192, 1, 18, 442211) I must be excused from applying material consi derations to an institution that is based on religious considerations.
('31', 192, 1, 19, 442329) Nor is the correspondent happy in his analogy.
('31', 192, 1, 20, 442376) I have asked that a Panchama should be regarded as a Shudra because I hold that there is no warrant for belief in a fifth case.
('31', 192, 1, 21, 442504) A Panchama does the work of a Shudra and he is, therefore naturally classfied as such when he ceases to be regar ded as a Panchama.
('31', 192, 1, 22, 442636) I do believe that this constant confusion between untouchability and Varnashram and attack on the latter in the same breath as the former retards the progress of reform regarding untouchability.
('31', 192, 1, 23, 442831) It is now clear that the law of variation is left untouched by Varnashram.
('31', 192, 1, 24, 442906) Nay it is provided for.
('31', 192, 1, 25, 442930) Only, types do not vary in a few years or even in a few generations.
('31', 192, 1, 26, 442999) There is no fundamental difference between a Brahmin and a Pariah, but he who runs may see that class considered, there is a marked and noticeable difference between Brahmins and Pariahs or for that matter all the four castes.
('31', 192, 1, 27, 443226) What I would like my correspondent to join me in is a fight against an arrogant assumption of superiority whether it is assumed by Brahmins or others.
('31', 192, 1, 28, 443377) It is the abuse of Varnashram that should be combated, not the thing itself.
('31', 192, 1, 29, 443454) Young India, 23 4 1925

('31', 193, 1, 3, 443646) They approached the task in fear and trembling, for they were not sure of response from divided Delhi.
('31', 193, 1, 4, 443749) To their agreeable surprise, however, the hawking and the bhajans that accompanied it, took effect.
('31', 193, 1, 5, 443849) All the common folk bought khaddar with pleasure and the volunteer hawkers had on difficulty in disposing of their stock from day to day.
('31', 193, 1, 6, 443987) This experience has a lesson of its own.
('31', 193, 1, 7, 444028) The general body of people are still sound, if the facts given by my correspondent are facts.
('31', 193, 1, 8, 444122) I have no reason what soever to doubt their accuracy.
('31', 193, 1, 9, 444176) Will the Congress workers try to enlist members more systematically and with more confidence than hith erto?
('31', 193, 1, 10, 444285) Nothing can be a greater tribute to Hakim Saheb than that in his absence Delhi has come up to her former level.

('31', 195, 8, 10, 447087) MAGANLAL, Chi.
('31', 195, 8, 11, 447102) Chhotelal is not likely to have peace here.
('31', 195, 8, 12, 447146) He wishes immediately to return to the Ashram.

('31', 199, 5, 29, 454765) Their education, therefore, should centre round their agricultural

('31', 204, 2, 5, 464107) UNWASHED CLOTHES During my recent tour of Gujarat, I observed a large number of pupils in the national schools.
('31', 204, 2, 6, 464219) Many of them were untidy and dirty in appearance.

('31', 204, 2, 11, 464591) Some wore clothes which were torn.
('31', 204, 2, 12, 464626) I think that, as children suffering from contagious diseases are forbidden to attend school, so also children whose clothes or bodies are dirty or who are wearing torn clothes should be forbidden to attend.
('31', 204, 2, 13, 464833) If it is asked when and where, in that case, the children will learn to be tidy, the reply is simple.
('31', 204, 2, 14, 464935) A child which comes to the school in such condition should first be taken to the tap and washed there; it should be made to wash its clothes with its own hands and should be provided with other gar ments from the school while its own are drying.
('31', 204, 2, 15, 465181) When they have dried, it may change into them, then wash the garments provided by the school, dry them and return them properly folded.
('31', 204, 2, 16, 465317) If it is feared that this will mean increase in the school’s expenditure, the child should be given a note and sent home, and may be permitted to attend when it returns in a clean condition.
('31', 204, 2, 17, 465508) Physical cleanliness and tidiness should be the first lesson.

('31', 205, 1, 4, 466484) I can call to mind one or two schools in which 900 pupils came together, noiselessly, within three minutes of a whistle and, when the programme was over, they returned to their classes in the same number of minutes, and were back at work as if they had never left them.

('31', 205, 1, 17, 467846) It has become almost impossible to have clean surroundings in cities.

('31', 210, 1, 2, 475498) 136. SPEECH AT ALL INDIA COW PROTECTION CONFERENCE, BOMBAY April 28, 1925
('31', 210, 2, 3, 475572) In presenting for approval the draft constitution of the All India Cow Protection Association 1 to the public meeting held at Madhav Bag, Bombay, on the 28th April, Mr. Gandhi made a speech in Gujarati, of which the following is a summary : I do not think that I have in my life approached any under taking with the fear and trembling that I experience today.
('31', 210, 2, 4, 475932) I am regar ded as a man who is generally not afraid of taking risks.
('31', 210, 2, 5, 476001) I have in terested myself in cow protection, almost ever since my childhood, and have given a careful study to the subject during the past thirty years.
('31', 210, 2, 6, 476154) I have also occasionally written and spoken about it.
('31', 210, 2, 7, 476208) And yet I have not felt myself equal to the present undertaking, nor do I feel today.
('31', 210, 2, 8, 476294) Not that I do not know the ways to do it.
('31', 210, 2, 9, 476336) I do know it.
('31', 210, 2, 10, 476350) But the successful carrying out takes more than an intellectual understanding of the ways and means.
('31', 210, 2, 11, 476451) It requires deeper purification and I would have fain added to my modest stock of it before I launched on this new undertaking.
('31', 210, 2, 12, 476579) But Fates decide my undertakings for me.
('31', 210, 2, 13, 476620) I never go to seek them.
('31', 210, 2, 14, 476645) They come to me almost in spite of me.
('31', 210, 2, 15, 476684) That has been my lot all my life long, in South Africa as well as ever since my return to India.
('31', 210, 2, 16, 476781) I had not dreamt that the task of forming an All India Cow Protection Association would fall to me, when I consented to preside over the Cow Protection Conference at Belgaum.
('31', 210, 2, 17, 476956) But those in charge of it had formulated big plans, and as President I had to consider them.
('31', 210, 2, 18, 477049) We had a meeting of the committee appointed thereto at Delhi, where a draft constitution was prepared and approved by all present there, including men like Pandit Malaviyaji, Lala Lajpat Rai, Swami Shraddhanandji and Dr. Moonje.
('31', 210, 2, 19, 477278) Even then I was marking time.
('31', 210, 2, 20, 477308) I waited and watched, before I could decide on taking the final step.
('31', 210, 2, 21, 477378) But the ever active Chaunde Maharaj would not leave me in peace.
('31', 210, 2, 22, 477443) I then proposed that we should get the whole constitution app roved and accepted at a public meeting of all interested in cow pro tection.
('31', 210, 2, 23, 477582) This meeting then which should have been help in Delhi is held here tonight, more for my convenience than anything else.
('31', 210, 2, 24, 477703) The task for which I want your approval and in which I seek your help is immense.
('31', 210, 2, 25, 477785) It is bigger than perhaps the struggle for swaraj
('31', 210, 3, 26, 477835) 1 Vide “Draft Constitution of All India Cow Protection Sabha”, 24 1 1925
('31', 211, 0, 1, 477908) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 211, 1, 2, 477950) inasmuch as it is of an entirely religious character.
('31', 211, 1, 3, 478004) In my work of a prominently political character, I have often erred and blundered, I have done penance and repaired those errors and blunders.
('31', 211, 1, 4, 478147) But in the present undertaking an error would be well night irretrievable for the simple reason that the cow we propose to serve is a dumb creature, she cannot complain, she has no voice to raise against what may be against her interests.
('31', 211, 1, 5, 478386) An untouchable may cry and raise a protest, a Hindu or a Mussalman may raise a protest and even break heads to settle a grievance.
('31', 211, 1, 6, 478517) But the cow is entirely at our mercy.
('31', 211, 1, 7, 478555) She consents to be led to slaughter, and to be embarked for Australia and gives her progeny to carry whatever burden we want it to carry, in sun or rain.
('31', 211, 1, 8, 478709) The task is thus immense and I have undertaken it out of a pure sense of duty.
('31', 211, 1, 9, 478788) But I may warn that there are limits to my capacity for undertakings.
('31', 211, 1, 10, 478858) There are certain limits which are obvious.
('31', 211, 1, 11, 478902) For instance though I can collect funds for my purposes, and though I know that the love of my countrymen for me is deep enough to find me money for any good undertaking that I take up, I want you to know that I cannot go about from place to place asking for money for the present task.
('31', 211, 1, 12, 479189) I have not the time nor the energy for it.
('31', 211, 1, 13, 479232) Then there is the honest, careful and efficient disposal of the funds.
('31', 211, 1, 14, 479303) I obviously cannot look to or supervise every detail, and the cow won’t impale you on her horns for mismanagement or similar blunders.
('31', 211, 1, 15, 479438) We have, therefore, to do the work in fear of God and with the full consciousness of the sacredness of the task.
('31', 211, 1, 16, 479551) I gave at Belgaum 1 my meaning of cow protection.
('31', 211, 1, 17, 479601) It includes, as I explained, the protection and service of “both man and bird and beast”.
('31', 211, 1, 18, 479691) It presupposes a through eschewal of violence.
('31', 211, 1, 19, 479738) A Hindu, if he is a true Hindu, may not raise his hand against a Mussalman or an Englishman to protect the cow.
('31', 211, 1, 20, 479850) I have, for our present purposes, confined myself to considering the ways and means of protecting the cow merely.
('31', 211, 1, 21, 479964) For I know that if we once succeed in the protection of the cow proper, we shall some day be able to serve the cow in all creation.
('31', 211, 1, 22, 480096) And if we succeed in Bombay, we shall also thereafter succeed elsewhere.
('31', 211, 1, 23, 480169) But to do so we have to bring both our reason and our heart to bear on the task.
('31', 211, 1, 24, 480250) We shall have to examine ourselves and realize that it is primarily a Hindu’s duty in the matter that this Association seeks to
('31', 211, 2, 25, 480378) 1 Vide “Presidential Address at Cow Protection Conference, Belgaum”, 28 12 1924.
('31', 212, 0, 1, 480459) VOL.31: 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 213
('31', 212, 1, 2, 480500) be fulfilled, we have to realize that we have not so much to save the cow from the butcher’s knife as from our own.
('31', 212, 1, 3, 480616) And, for that purpose, we shall have to grasp the economics of the thing.
('31', 212, 1, 4, 480690) Nowhere in the world is the proportion of the bovine to the human population so small as in India.
('31', 212, 1, 5, 480789) Nowhere is the cow so feeble, and her yield so little as in India.

('31', 212, 1, 9, 481031) It is the Hindus, therefore, who have to fulfil their obligations in the matter.

('31', 212, 1, 11, 481189) I gave all the help that I could for the Khilafat, because I wanted to enlist the Mussalman’s sympathy in the matter of cow protection.
('31', 212, 1, 12, 481325) But let us fulfil our obligations first.
('31', 212, 1, 13, 481366) We are doing nothing today.
('31', 212, 1, 14, 481394) The little work that is being done by Chaunde Maharaj and others is as a mere drop in the ocean.
('31', 212, 1, 15, 481491) Two things I want to invite your attention to as important in the constitution, viz., the establishment of tanneries and dairies.
('31', 212, 1, 16, 481621) That is too practical, too earthly you will say.
('31', 212, 1, 17, 481670) But religion which takes no count of practical affairs and does not help to solve them, is no religion.
('31', 212, 1, 18, 481774) That is what the life of the Ascetic King Janaka teaches us.
('31', 212, 1, 19, 481835) And that is why I am putting a religious matter before you in a practical form.
('31', 212, 1, 20, 481915) We shall have to take control of the milk supply and also of the disposal of dead cattle.
('31', 212, 1, 21, 482005) You are perhaps shocked as I speak of hides and tanneries.
('31', 212, 1, 22, 482064) But do you know that because we would not take charge of them the untouchable who does the work today excuses himself for eating carrion and remaining unclean ?
('31', 212, 1, 23, 482225) Let us show him the proper way of doing things and he will reform his ways.
('31', 212, 1, 24, 482301) I am suggesting all these things with the fullest consciousness of the meaning of all that I say.
('31', 212, 1, 25, 482399) I may tell you that it was I who vowed never more to take cow’s or buffalo’s milk when I learnt for the first time in South Africa the cruel way in which the last drop of milk was drawn out of them.
('31', 212, 1, 26, 482598) I know that there are beef eaters amongst Vaishnavas, I know that there are Vaishnavas who do not hesitate to take Liebeg’s “Extract of Beef”, on the pretext that it is prescribed by the doctor.
('31', 212, 1, 27, 482793) Should we then hesitate to control tanneries in a religious spirit ?
('31', 212, 1, 28, 482862) I tell you we have come to this state because we would not take care of disabled and dead cattle and because we exported them to America.
('31', 212, 1, 29, 483000) Let us, therefore, establish tanneries and look to the proper disposal of dead cattle.
('31', 212, 1, 30, 483087) Let us establish dairies and ensure a cheaper
('31', 213, 0, 1, 483133) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 213, 1, 2, 483175) and better supply of milk.
('31', 213, 1, 3, 483202) I will not hesitate to seek co opertation of the government in this matter, for I know they have got the services of good dairy experts.
('31', 213, 1, 4, 483339) If we do these two things then alone is it possible to stop the avoidable slaughter of thosuands of cattle annually.
('31', 213, 1, 5, 483456) The other things in the constitution are of a non controversial character and explain themselves.
('31', 213, 1, 6, 483554) We now want a treasurer and a secretary for our work.
('31', 213, 1, 7, 483608) The treasurer should be such as everyone trusts, as can collect the necessary funds, and can find them himself when they are not forthcoming.
('31', 213, 1, 8, 483750) The secretary’s first qualification is that he should be a brahmachari if possible,—not a mere celebrate but a truly religious brahmachari who has control over all the senses.

('31', 214, 1, 2, 485106) 138. INTERVIEW TO “ NEW INDIA”
('31', 214, 2, 3, 485137) BOMBAY, April 29, 1925
('31', 214, 3, 4, 485160) Interviewed by New India’s special correspondent on the Commonwealth of
('31', 214, 4, 5, 485232) India Bill, Gandhiji said: I wish I had the time to study Dr. Besant’s Commonwealth of India Bill with the care and attention that it demands.
('31', 214, 4, 6, 485375) But such study as I have been able to give it has led me to the following conclusion : The recognition of the King Emperor as Sovereign and Protector of the Common wealth seems to have been assumed as an indispensable condition.
('31', 214, 4, 7, 485604) I do not subscribe to it.
('31', 214, 4, 8, 485630) I recognize that in any Bill passed by mutual consent, some such provision is necessary, but I could not teach the people that the British connection is an inviolable thing.
('31', 214, 4, 9, 485804) There should be some provision in the Bill for the immediate participation by Parliament in the defence of the Commonwealth.
('31', 214, 4, 10, 485929) All the existing financial and other obligations of the Government of India seem to have been taken over under the Bill.
('31', 214, 4, 11, 486050) I cannot be a party to such a transaction.

('31', 219, 9, 27, 498107) In the midst of suspicion, discord, antagonistic interests, superstition, fear, distrust and the like, there is not only no safety in numbers but there may be even danger in them.

('31', 222, 1, 2, 503614) 142. TO ‘REVOLUTIONARY IN THE MAKING’
('31', 222, 2, 3, 503652) You will pardon me for not reproducing your letter.
('31', 222, 2, 4, 503704) I would have gladly published it, if it was a presentable letter—not that the language of your letter is at all in bad taste or violent.
('31', 222, 2, 5, 503841) On the contrary, you have attempted to present your case fairly and calmly, but the argument is loosely and unconvincingly put.
('31', 222, 2, 6, 503969) What you want to say is that the revolutionary does no violence because when he takes the life of his adversary, he does so to benefit him, i.e., his soul, even as a surgeon performs a painful operation on a patient for his (the latter’s) good.
('31', 222, 2, 7, 504214) You argue that the adversary has a vile body which vitiates the soul and that the sooner it is destroyed, the better for him.
('31', 222, 2, 8, 504340) Now, the analogy of the surgeon is wrong because he is concerned merely with the body.
('31', 222, 2, 9, 504427) He operates on the body to benefit the body.
('31', 222, 2, 10, 504472) His science ignores the soul.
('31', 222, 2, 11, 504502) Who can say how many bodies have been repaired by surgeons at the expense of the soul?
('31', 222, 2, 12, 504589) But the revolutionary destroys the body for the supposed benefit of the adversary’s soul.
('31', 222, 2, 13, 504679) In the first instance, I do not know a single re volutionary who has ever thought of the adversary’s soul.
('31', 222, 2, 14, 504786) His single aim has been of benefit the country even though the adversary may perish, body and soul.
('31', 222, 2, 15, 504886) In the second instance, since you believe in the Law of Karma, a compulsory destruction of a body merely paves the way for the creation of a tougher body for the same soul.
('31', 222, 2, 16, 505059) For the man whose body is destroyed will weave for himself a body after his own longing.
('31', 222, 2, 17, 505148) That, to my mind, is the meaning of the persistence of evil and the crimes we see about us.
('31', 222, 2, 18, 505240) The more we punish, the more persistent crimes become.
('31', 222, 2, 19, 505295) They may change colour, but the substance is the same.
('31', 222, 2, 20, 505350) The way to serve the adversary’s soul is to appeal to the soul.
('31', 222, 2, 21, 505414) It defies destruction, but it is amenable to appeals tuned to the required pitch.
('31', 222, 2, 22, 505496) Souls must react upon souls.
('31', 222, 2, 23, 505525) And since non violence is essentially a quality of the soul, the only effective appeal to the soul must lie through non violence.
('31', 222, 2, 24, 505655) And do we not arrogate to ourselves infallibility when we seek to punish our adversaries ?
('31', 222, 2, 25, 505746) Let us remember that they regard us to be as harmful to society as we regard them.
('31', 222, 2, 26, 505829) It is idle to drag in the name of Krishna.
('31', 222, 2, 27, 505872) Either we believe him to be the very God or we do not.
('31', 222, 2, 28, 505927) If we do, we impute to him omniscience and omnipotence.
('31', 222, 2, 29, 505983) Such a one can surely destroy.

('31', 227, 1, 2, 515039) 145. “SEEKER AFTER TRUTH” One who describes himself a seeker after truth sends me his own reflections arising out of my discussion of revolutionary views.
('31', 227, 1, 3, 515194) He tells me that at first he was a non co operator, then, he began to think that non co operation was merely a social movement and that the revolutionary was the only true political movement.
('31', 227, 1, 4, 515386) At Belgaum again, he began to think anew.
('31', 227, 1, 5, 515428) I condense below his reflections with out in any way whatsoever changing the sense or his language:
('31', 227, 2, 6, 515528) The Revolutionary is certainly patriotic.
('31', 227, 2, 7, 515570) He is a Hero.
('31', 227, 2, 8, 515584) He is prepared to give up his life in the cause of Motherland.
('31', 227, 2, 9, 515647) But his very aim is wrong.
('31', 227, 3, 10, 515674) What is it the Revolutionary wants?
('31', 227, 3, 11, 515710) Freedom for the country.
('31', 227, 3, 12, 515735) So far quite right.
('31', 227, 3, 13, 515755) Why is the freedom required?
('31', 227, 3, 14, 515784) So that the people may be happy.
('31', 227, 3, 15, 515817) This also is right.
('31', 227, 3, 16, 515837) How can the people be happy?
('31', 227, 3, 17, 515866) By changing the system of Government.
('31', 227, 4, 18, 515904) Now here comes the real point.
('31', 227, 5, 19, 515935) Let us just consider our state.
('31', 227, 5, 20, 515967) We Indians have ever so many virtues.
('31', 227, 5, 21, 516005) But what of our weaknesses?
('31', 227, 5, 22, 516033) We have become cowards.
('31', 227, 5, 23, 516057) We have taken to several vices.
('31', 227, 5, 24, 516089) Amongst the Hindus we have the untouchables.
('31', 227, 5, 25, 516134) We till the ground and produce grains, vegetables and such things which could very easily feed us all.
('31', 227, 5, 26, 516237) All the same, the fact remains that the major portion of us are half starving.
('31', 227, 5, 27, 516316) We all weave and work in mills.
('31', 227, 5, 28, 516348) Still we are but half clad.
('31', 227, 5, 29, 516376) We have got enough clay.
('31', 227, 5, 30, 516401) We know how to make bricks and build beautiful houses.
('31', 227, 5, 31, 516456) Still there are several of us who have no other place than beneath trees to live.
('31', 227, 6, 32, 516538) No doubt the foreigners are, to a very large extent, to blame for our difficulties.
('31', 227, 6, 33, 516622) Wrong though it may be, that is our sincere opinion.
('31', 227, 6, 34, 516675) But what of our own share of the responsibility?
('31', 227, 6, 35, 516724) Are we not at all to blame?
('31', 227, 7, 36, 516752) Or suppose that we, with the help of the revolvers or such things, do drive away the enemies?
('31', 227, 7, 37, 516846) Is it not possible for any other foreigner to occupy the position of the present foreigner?
('31', 227, 7, 38, 516938) After all warfare is but a sort of gambling.
('31', 227, 8, 39, 516983) I do not propose to deal with the utility or otherwise of non violence, maintaining armies and such things.
('31', 227, 8, 40, 517091) I consider myself absolutely incompetent to discuss this subject.
('31', 227, 8, 41, 517157) Suffice it to say that I am beginning to understand Gandhiji’s views on this subject and his views appear to me to be right.
('31', 227, 9, 42, 517282) The United States of America, it is generally said, have a very good Government.
('31', 227, 9, 43, 517363) What of the several plots, the several murders, dacoities, swindlings, etc., that take place there?
('31', 227, 9, 44, 517463) The Bolshevik system is considered to be good.
('31', 227, 9, 45, 517510) Why then the daily increasing capital punishment, riots and such things?
('31', 227, 9, 46, 517583) Any number of such examples can be given.
('31', 228, 0, 1, 517625) VOL.31: 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 229
('31', 228, 1, 2, 517666) To dispose of Gandhiji's ideas as merely idealistic and impracticable is wrong; much more so for a revolutionary to do so.
('31', 228, 1, 3, 517789) For he has really the welfare of the people at heart.
('31', 228, 2, 4, 517843) It is not impossible to bring about a situation where the world will be an abode of happiness.
