('31', 229, 1, 2, 519785) 146. SPEECH AT NAGPUR April 30, 1925
('31', 229, 2, 3, 519822) Amidst the thundering cries of “Mahatma Gandhi ki Jai” the train conveying Mahatma Gandhi en route to Calcutta arrived here at exactly 9.25 a.m.
('31', 229, 2, 4, 519967) Mahatmaji was led to the dais by Sikh volunteers with naked swords in hands.
('31', 229, 2, 5, 520044) After requesting the audience to remain quiet Mahatmaji delivered a small speech.
('31', 229, 2, 6, 520126) He said that though he was very glad to see them there, his heart burned within himself to find very few clad in pure khaddar.
('31', 229, 2, 7, 520253) So long as they did not put on khaddar and all classes of people such as Sikhs, Parsis, Hindus, Mahomedans and others were not firmly united, and so long as the curse of untouchability was not removed, swaraj was impossible.
('31', 229, 2, 8, 520478) He appealed to the people of Nagpur to bring about real Hindu Muslim unity and take to spinning.
('31', 229, 2, 9, 520575) After this speech Mahatmaji was presented by the Secretary, City Congress Committee, with the report of the work done in the city.
('31', 229, 2, 10, 520706) Mahatmaji left Nagpur at about 10. The Bombay Chronicle, 1 5 1925
('31', 229, 3, 11, 520772) 147. ILLUMINATING DOCUMENTS
('31', 229, 4, 12, 520800) [April 30, 1925] 1
('31', 229, 5, 13, 520819) These notes are being written during the trying journey to Calcutta.
('31', 229, 5, 14, 520888) This being my first passage through the Central Provinces after my discharge from prison, people are embarrassingly attentive at every station and there is no rest for the wearied limbs.
('31', 229, 5, 15, 521075) The discarding of khaddar is most noticeable.
('31', 229, 5, 16, 521121) Instead of a forest of white khaddar caps, I see everywhere the provoking black foreign caps on almost every head.
('31', 229, 5, 17, 521236) A friend sadly remarked to me that there was hardly one in a thousand who wore khaddar habitually.
('31', 229, 5, 18, 521335) I am witnessing all along the route a striking demonstration of the fact.
('31', 229, 5, 19, 521409) All honour then to the one per thousand who remain faithful to khaddar against heavy odds.
('31', 229, 5, 20, 521500) My faith in khaddar rises as I find this indifference to if not revolt against khaddar.
('31', 229, 5, 21, 521588) The demonstration of the painful truth became complete at Nagpur—the centre that re affirmed the Calcutta resolution of non violent non co operation.
('31', 229, 5, 22, 521738) There was a vast crowd at the station.
('31', 229, 5, 23, 521777) The Congress officials had even arranged a meeting just outside the station.
('31', 229, 5, 24, 521854) The hot sun was beating overhead.
('31', 229, 5, 25, 521888) The din was terrific.
('31', 229, 6, 26, 521910) 1 From the reference to the “journey to Calcutta”, the article appears to have been written on April 30 after the halt at Nagpur.
('31', 229, 6, 27, 522040) Gandhiji reached Calcutta on the morning of May 1.
('31', 230, 0, 1, 522091) VOL.31: 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 231
('31', 230, 1, 2, 522132) Nobody heard anybody, much less listened to anybody.
('31', 230, 1, 3, 522185) There were volunteers but there was no discipline.
('31', 230, 1, 4, 522236) No way was kept for me to pass through.
('31', 230, 1, 5, 522276) I insisted on a way being made if I was to go to the meeting place during the half hour that the train was to stop at the station.
('31', 230, 1, 6, 522407) The way was made with difficulty.
('31', 230, 1, 7, 522441) I waded through it in the best manner I could took me over five minutes to reach the platform.
('31', 230, 1, 8, 522536) Without the crowd pressing from all sides, I could have reached it in half a minute.
('31', 230, 1, 9, 522621) I took no more than one minute to deliver my message.
('31', 230, 1, 10, 522675) It took me longer to return to the train than it took to reach the platform, for the crowd had now lost its head completely.
('31', 230, 1, 11, 522800) The intoxication of affection was now at its height.
('31', 230, 1, 12, 522853) The shouts of “ ki jai” rent the sky.
('31', 230, 1, 13, 522891) I was ill able to bear the din and the dust and the suffocation.
('31', 230, 1, 14, 522956) “O God!
('31', 230, 1, 15, 522964) deliver me from this affection” was the silent prayer that went up to the Great White Throne.
('31', 230, 1, 16, 523058) I reached the train in safety.
('31', 230, 1, 17, 523089) It was provokingly late going.
('31', 230, 1, 18, 523120) I stood in the doorway wishing and hoping to talk to the crowd if it would keep still for a while.
('31', 230, 1, 19, 523219) The Congress officials tried, a big Akali tried, to silence the crowd.
('31', 230, 1, 20, 523290) It was no use.
('31', 230, 1, 21, 523305) It had come to have darshan.
('31', 230, 1, 22, 523334) That it was having with delirious joy.
('31', 230, 1, 23, 523373) Its joy was my pain.
('31', 230, 1, 24, 523394) My name on the lips and black caps on the heads,—what a terrible contrast!
('31', 230, 1, 25, 523469) What a lie!
('31', 230, 1, 26, 523481) I could not fight the battle of swaraj with that crowd.
('31', 230, 1, 27, 523537) And yet, I know that Maulana Shaukat Ali would say there was hope so long as there was that affection, blind though it was.
('31', 230, 1, 28, 523661) I am not so sure and therefore I was in agony.
('31', 230, 1, 29, 523708) At last, I got a hearing.
('31', 230, 1, 30, 523734) I demanded the black caps.
('31', 230, 1, 31, 523761) The response was instantaneous but not generous.
('31', 230, 1, 32, 523810) From that vast crowd I do not think more than one hundred caps were thrown, four of which were thrown not by the owners.
('31', 230, 1, 33, 523931) They were claimed and promptly returned.
('31', 230, 1, 34, 523972) This sight had a double lesson for me.
('31', 230, 1, 35, 524011) With proper organized work, people could be induced to discard foreign or mill made cloth.
('31', 230, 1, 36, 524102) That was one lesson; but there was another.
('31', 230, 1, 37, 524146) People there were who were yet ready to remove the neighbour’s cap, just the preliminary to coercion.
('31', 230, 1, 38, 524248) But there should be no coercion in khaddar wearing or in anything else.
('31', 230, 1, 39, 524320) Those who wear it must do so voluntarily or not at all.
('31', 230, 1, 40, 524376) But the most illuminating information was given to me by the documents that the business like officials had prepared for presen tation to me.
('31', 230, 1, 41, 524518) The documents tell me a truthful, simple, unvarnished story of Congress work.

('31', 234, 7, 9, 532242) 149. INTERVIEW TO “THE STATESMAN”
('31', 234, 8, 10, 532276) CALCUTTA,
('31', 234, 9, 11, 532286) May 1, 1925
('31', 234, 10, 12, 532298) In a room practically devoid of furniture, on the floor of which were spread
('31', 234, 11, 13, 532375) lengths of carpet, Mr. Gandhi, clad only in loin cloth, sat cross legged and, after a
('31', 234, 12, 14, 532461) greeting, asked to be excused while his spinning wheel was adjusted.
('31', 234, 12, 15, 532530) He then
('31', 234, 13, 16, 532538) expressed his readiness to converse, and proceeded to do so, spinning rapidly and
('31', 234, 14, 17, 532620) skilfully the while.
('31', 234, 15, 18, 532641) Seldom taking his eyes from his work, he answered questions without the slightest hesitation, although his voice, soft and musical, was sometimes almost inaudible through the gentle whirr of the charkha.At the outset he smilingly acquiesced in a suggestion that the charkha was the machine on which he pinned his political faith.
('31', 234, 16, 19, 532971) Mr. Gandhi was first invited to express an opinion regarding the attitude of Europeans in the present political situation and the difficulty which many people experienced in defining a clear cut policy from the maze of political panaceas enunciated from time to time.
('31', 234, 17, 20, 533239) He replied that there must be some organization to guide political thought and
('31', 234, 18, 21, 533318) the National Congress ought to represent the national feeling.
('31', 234, 18, 22, 533381) There were two sides
('31', 234, 19, 23, 533402) to the present programme—the internal and the external.
('31', 234, 19, 24, 533458) The object of the former was
('31', 234, 20, 25, 533487) to achieve unity among all races, “Hindu Muslim unity” being a short term to cover
('31', 234, 21, 26, 533570) all classes—the removal of untouchability by the Hindus, the spinning wheel and
('31', 234, 22, 27, 533650) khaddar.
('31', 235, 0, 1, 533659) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 235, 1, 2, 533701) On the external side, there was the activity in the Council represented by the
('31', 235, 2, 3, 533780) Swaraj Party, which was an integral part of the National Congress.
('31', 235, 2, 4, 533847) That was the
('31', 235, 3, 5, 533860) whole of the national programme.
('31', 235, 4, 6, 533893) Asked to express his opinion on the general political situation in India,
('31', 235, 5, 7, 533967) Mahatma Gandhi said :
('31', 235, 6, 8, 533989) I am certainly not a pessimist, but I do not see much sign of hope.
('31', 235, 6, 9, 534057) I shall begin to hope when we meet with demonstrable success in our internal programme.
('31', 235, 6, 10, 534145) meaning thereby the unity of all races in India, the removal of untouchability and the development of spinning and the use of khaddar.
('31', 235, 7, 11, 534280) As a declared “friend of the British”, Mr. Gandhi regretted that he was unable to
('31', 235, 8, 12, 534362) see a change of heart on their part.
('31', 235, 8, 13, 534399) Europeans may well co operate on the internal as well as on the external side, and I invite them, as I have always invited them, to examine the programme in both its aspects.
('31', 235, 8, 14, 534574) As regards the external side, if they are satisfied that we mean what we say, that we have absolutely no desire, even if we could, to drive out the English, or to end the British connection they should make common cause with us.
('31', 235, 9, 15, 534803) Touching on the question of non co operation, Mr. Gandhi said : The programme of non co operation, so far as the nation is concerned, is suspended, but so far as I am personally concerned, it is not suspended, although the individual suspension had little meaning in it today.
('31', 235, 9, 16, 535080) I never was a Council goer, but I suppose at the present moment with me it is a virtue of necessity, because my late imprison ment debars my entry into the Councils.
('31', 235, 9, 17, 535246) I had long suspended my practice, but the Society of the Inner Temple has removed the last vestige of temptation from me.
('31', 235, 10, 18, 535368) What, therefore, remains of non co operation in me is, as Mr. Das 2 would put it, a matter of “mental attitude”.
('31', 235, 10, 19, 535481) But it is an attitude that I personally prize because, claiming as I do, to be a friend of the British, I want to tell them that I see no trace yet of any real change of
('31', 235, 11, 20, 535651) 1 By striking his name off the rolls; vide Appendix “Inner Temple Order”, 21 12 1922. 2 Chitta Ranjan Das (1870 1925); eminent lawyer and Congress leader; orator and author; President, Indian National Congress, 1922; founded the Swaraj Party in 1923
('31', 236, 0, 1, 535901) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 237
('31', 236, 1, 2, 535943) I am a born co operator, but non co operation with me became a necessity; but I am waiting for the opportunity when I can declare that I will again become a hearty co operator.
('31', 236, 2, 3, 536120) Referring to the problem of Hindu Muslim unity, Mr. Gandhi said : My travels have shown me that both communities are filled with mutual distrust and fear, but I have not a shadow of doubt that unity is coming in the near future.
('31', 236, 2, 4, 536349) Each party regards it as a national necessity.

('31', 238, 1, 7, 540233) I have said in my opening remarks what a deep grief it was to me this morning to enter 148 Russa Road.
('31', 238, 1, 8, 540336) I know that that house no longer belonged to Deshbandhu Das.
('31', 238, 1, 9, 540397) I knew that he contemplated making over that beautiful mansion to trustees in order to divest himself of the last vestige of wealth that he possessed in this world.
('31', 238, 1, 10, 540562) But, man of the world, living still in the world as I am doing, when I actually entered the house with the knowledge that its distinguished owner had voluntarily dispossessed himself of it, I could not help shedding a tear.
('31', 238, 1, 11, 540786) I felt a wrench within me that the house was no longer Das’s, and when I heard that he had not yet been able to repair his broken down constitution, I felt doubly grieved and my grief was still further increased when I received a brief but beautiful and loving message from him, written by him in pencil hand, telling me how it was impossible for him to stand the double strain and why therefore he had gone away to Faridpur in advance.
('31', 238, 1, 12, 541223) May God grant him health and long life to serve the country which he loves so dearly.
('31', 238, 1, 13, 541309) You will not expect me to tell you anything on what is called the political situation.
('31', 238, 1, 14, 541396) A newspaper reporter told me today about the negotiations that are going on between Lord Birkenhead and Desh bandhu Das.
('31', 238, 1, 15, 541517) I am totally unaware of any such negotiations.
('31', 238, 1, 16, 541564) I have no knowledge of any such negotiations whatsoever; but I do know that there is what may be called a political situation in this country today.
('31', 238, 1, 17, 541713) But that political situation does not interest me sufficiently today.
('31', 238, 1, 18, 541783) I am an economist of time; I have deliberately given my general power of attorney to the Swaraj Party which is an integral part of the Congress.
('31', 238, 1, 19, 541928) The Swaraj Party is in charge of the political programme of the Congress and, seeing that I have the fullest faith in the ability of theSwaraj Party to handle the political situation, seeing that I have the
('31', 239, 0, 1, 542135) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 239, 1, 2, 542177) fullest faith in the wisdom of Deshbandhu Das and Pandit Motilal Nehru 1, so far as the Council programme is concerned, it would be impudence on my part to concern myself about it unless they want me to do so and there is absolutely no reason for them to want my interference or to desire my opinion.
('31', 239, 1, 3, 542478) When they do so you may depend on it that I am always at their service but, what is more, it would be impossible for me to make any effective statement on the political situation unless I have had a consultation with Deshbandhu Das.
('31', 239, 1, 4, 542711) I have not come to Bengal, I am not travelling throughout the length and breadth of India to embarrass the Swaraj Party or to embarrass Deshbandhu or a single member of that party.
('31', 239, 1, 5, 542892) I am pledged in the name of God to help that party to the best of my ability.

('31', 239, 1, 7, 543198) But that does not mean that I must not help them.
('31', 239, 1, 8, 543248) That does not mean that their policy is inimical to the country.
('31', 239, 1, 9, 543313) It simply means that there is a difference of opinion as to the weight and the relative importance to be attached to the political programme and the constructive programme.
('31', 239, 1, 10, 543486) I swear by the constructive programme; the more I examine myself the more I feel that I am more fitted for handling the constructive programme for developing our own power from within than for engaging into diplomatic relations with the matchless diplomats from England.
('31', 239, 1, 11, 543757) I confess to you that I will be ill at ease in carrying on negotiations with any of those officials unless I feel that we have power from within and I am here to confess to you that we have lost today the power that we thought in 1921 we had in abundance, and therefore I propose to the best of my ability to concentrate solely and exclusively upon the constructive programme.
('31', 239, 1, 12, 544134) That will be my best contribution to the country and to the Swaraj Party, and I promise to you that if you, the young men and the young women of Bengal, will help me—no matter to what political party you may belong—if you will kindly help me in making this constructive programme a living, a swinging success, you will find that our fetters automatically drop.
('31', 239, 1, 13, 544495) You will find that those
('31', 239, 2, 14, 544520) 1 1861 1931; lawyer and Swarajist leader; President, Indian National Congress, Amritsar, 1919, and Calcutta, 1928
('31', 240, 0, 1, 544634) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 241
('31', 240, 1, 2, 544676) whom we consider unjustly incarcerated and kept under detention, that those who are today pining away in the Jail at Mandalay, you will find that, if you can make the constructive programme a success, they will be discharged without your asking for their discharge.
('31', 240, 1, 3, 544942) What is that constructive programme by which I swear?
('31', 240, 1, 4, 544996) Let me take you through these three items as rapidly as I can.
('31', 240, 1, 5, 545059) Hindu Muslim unity, meaning unity between all the races that inhabit the fair land of ours.
('31', 240, 1, 6, 545151) Is that programme unattainable byus?
('31', 240, 1, 7, 545188) Is that programme undesirable?
('31', 240, 1, 8, 545219) But I have admitted my incompetence.
('31', 240, 1, 9, 545256) I have admitted that I have been found wanting as a physician prescribing a cure for this malady.
('31', 240, 1, 10, 545354) I do not find that either the Hindus or the Mussalmans are ready to accept my cure and therefore I simply nowadays confine myself to a passing mention of this problem and content myself by saying that some day or other we Hindus and Mussalmans will have to come together if we want the deliverance of our country; and, if it is to be our lot that before we can come together, we must shed one another’s blood then I say the sooner we do so the better it is for us.
('31', 240, 1, 11, 545819) If we propose to break one another’s head, let us do so in a manly way, let us not then shed crocodile tears, let us not ask for sympathy from any quarter if you do not propose to give any quarter.
('31', 240, 1, 12, 546017) That is what I have to say about the Hindu Muslim unity.
('31', 240, 1, 13, 546074) Is it a long drawn out programme or an impossible programme that we Hindus should rid ourselves of the curse of untouchability?
('31', 240, 1, 14, 546202) So long as untouchability disfigures Hinduism, so long do I hold the attainment of swaraj to be an utter impossibility.
('31', 240, 1, 15, 546322) Supposing it would be a gift descending from Downing Street to India that gift would be a curse upon this holy land.

('31', 240, 1, 17, 546559) But what are the implications of this removal of untouchability?
('31', 240, 1, 18, 546624) Let the sanatani Hindus understand from me who claims to be a sanatani Hindu.
('31', 240, 1, 19, 546702) I do not ask you to interdine with anybody; I do not ask you to exchange your daughters with the untouchables or with anybody, but I do ask you to remove this curse so that you may not put him beyond the pale of service.

('31', 259, 1, 3, 589382) Afterwards, they find some time and themselves make the slivers.
('31', 259, 1, 4, 589447) To have good slivers, it is certainly essential that the cotton should have been properly carded but it is also necessary that the rolling of slivers should be done with equal care.
('31', 259, 1, 5, 589629) If in making a sliver the fibre is merely rolled into a cylindrical shape anyhow, even well carded cotton will be wasted.
('31', 259, 1, 6, 589751) If cotton is spread out evenly on a hollow board and, with a thin stick placed over it, rolled with one’s palm five or six times, the fibres get stretched out properly and form a roll to make a fine sliver.
('31', 259, 1, 7, 589958) Only the person who spins with such a sliver knows the pleasure that spinning gives.
('31', 259, 1, 8, 590043) If one or two more turns are given with the palm, the result will be still better.
('31', 259, 1, 9, 590126) On the contrary, if only one or two turns are given, the sliver so made will not yield a well twisted and even thread in spinning.
('31', 259, 1, 10, 590257) In such slivers the fibres just stick together somehow and the thread, therefore, can never be even.
('31', 259, 1, 11, 590358) The women in the region near the Nellore taluk probably know this and, therefore, do not entrust the rolling of slivers to the carders.
('31', 259, 1, 12, 590494) If the carding is not well done, the defect is immediately noticed and can be remedied.

('31', 262, 1, 2, 595223) 161. SPEECH AT BENGAL PROVINCIAL CONFERENCE,
('31', 262, 2, 3, 595268) FARIDPUR
('31', 262, 3, 4, 595277) May 3, 1925
('31', 262, 4, 5, 595289) PRESIDENT AND FRIENDS, I am supposed to be speaking to you to return thanks for the very kind and generous words spoken about me by the Chairman of the Reception Committee and our worthy President.
('31', 262, 4, 6, 595487) At the outset I want to tender my congratulations to the Subjects Committee on having finished its deliberations in perfect harmony.
('31', 262, 4, 7, 595620) It is an open secret—and latterly we have ceased to have any secrets whatsoever in connection with our politics and, therefore, we have been welcoming, and even inviting, detectives so as to enable them to detect flaws in our policy, detect flaws in our doings and in everything that we may do in connection with the national policy and even outside the national policy.
('31', 262, 4, 8, 595991) But still, as I said, it is an open secret that there were some disputes or differences or dissensions in connection with the reso lutions that will be brought before this House this afternoon.
('31', 262, 4, 9, 596185) But all’s well that ends well.
('31', 262, 4, 10, 596216) I do not recall any Subjects Committee in which there have not been little differences or little jars.
('31', 262, 4, 11, 596319) I suppose, they will abide with us to the end of time whether they are in India or else where.
('31', 262, 4, 12, 596414) European Cabinets have their secrets, but if we are permitted to pry into their secrets and into the secrets of their Subjects Committees, I suppose, we would have about the same kind of reports as reports are to be found in connection with our dissensions and disputes.
('31', 262, 4, 13, 596685) Let us not, therefore, exaggerate those dissensions and differences, but let us treasure the thought that, after all, in the end we can unite and we can unite to a purpose.
('31', 262, 4, 14, 596858) (“Hear, hear”.) I read the address of Deshbandhu Das and I have had the privilege and pleasure of reading the English translation.
('31', 262, 4, 15, 596989) I do not know which is the original, whether Bengali or the English translation, because Bengali scholars tell me that the Bengali version reads as sweet and as eloquent as the English version, but, in any case, I had the pleasure and privilege of having an advanced copy of the English address when I was in Calcutta with a brief, little, loving, sweet note from Deshbandhu that, if I could spare a few minutes, I should read that address.
('31', 262, 4, 16, 597430) Well, I read from the start to the finish and I was wondering whether he had pilfered every sentiment from me.
('31', 262, 4, 17, 597541) (Laughter.) But I must confess to you that I saw that the language was
('31', 263, 0, 1, 597612) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 263, 1, 2, 597654) not mine.
('31', 263, 1, 3, 597664) The language was that of a scholar and not of a rustic who delights in calling himself a spinner, a scavenger, a weaver, a farmer and now even a Namasudra.
('31', 263, 1, 4, 597820) (Laughter.) And so I saw that the language was not mine, but the thoughts seemed to have been pilfered and so immediately I said to myself, if he would ask me to subscribe to it, I would have no hesitation in doing so without perhaps altering a single word or a single phrase.
('31', 263, 1, 5, 598097) But, perhaps, some of you will consider that this is no recommendation whatever for that address, but on the contrary that is the surest guarantee that the address is as dull as ditch water.
('31', 263, 1, 6, 598288) Well, I assure you that it is not as dull as ditch water.
('31', 263, 1, 7, 598346) And why do I want to give you that assurance?
('31', 263, 1, 8, 598392) You have listened to it.
('31', 263, 1, 9, 598417) You read it.

('31', 263, 2, 11, 598495) I want to look not at phraseology.
('31', 263, 2, 12, 598530) I do not want to look at the language.
('31', 263, 2, 13, 598569) I only want to look at the thoughts that under lie it and what he has said to us in that address.
('31', 263, 2, 14, 598667) If we are true to ourselves, if we are true to the nation, if we are true to the policy that was enunciated for the first time in Calcutta in 1920 with all the great deliberation that we could bring to bear upon that policy, if we are to be true to that, then, there is absolutely nothing in that address to cavil at.
('31', 263, 2, 15, 598985) And that address is a reenunciation and an emphatic and unequivocal re enunciation of the policy that was laid down for the first time in the history of the Congress in 1920. When I say laid down for the first time in the history of the Congress, it is not that the Congress ever believed in a policy of violence, nor that the Congress ever believed that we should follow anything but legitimate methods, but that the Congress never made that declaration.
('31', 263, 2, 16, 599441) But in 1920 we chose deliberately to tell the world that we intended to attain that goal of swaraj, that in order to attain that goal we intended to follow a means that was absolutely peaceful and legitimate.
('31', 263, 2, 17, 599650) And as I have translated these two phrases or these two words or paraphrases, “non violent and truthful” means, do you abide by that interpretation or that paraphrase or these two words?
('31', 263, 2, 18, 599837) And during the four or five years that have intervened, Deshbandhu has been one of those who have had a part in the shaping of the national policy in those terms—and you have no right to expect anything else from him and you have no right to expect anything more from him today.
('31', 263, 2, 19, 600116) Anything more I say, because some of us like pepper and salt eschewed from our programme for the time being, at any rate.
('31', 263, 2, 20, 600238) We have considered it, everyone of the leaders has considered it, that it is not possible for us to attain our freedom with pepper and salt or with fire and brimstone.
('31', 263, 2, 21, 600406) We shall be able to attain
('31', 264, 0, 1, 600433) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 265
('31', 264, 1, 2, 600475) our national regeneration—shall we say, national salvation—only by means that are absolutely non violent and truthful; not that it need be the religion of any single one of us—it is sufficient if it is our policy, it is sufficient if we accept it from motives of expediency and no other or no higher motive.
('31', 264, 2, 3, 600783) We have problems in India to deal with which no other nation on the earth has.
('31', 264, 2, 4, 600862) We have, if we are Hindus, to deal with our Muslim countrymen, with our Christian countrymen, with our Zoroastrian countrymen, with the Sikhs and so many sections and sub sections of Hindus, which dignify themselves by a name which does not belong to Hinduism.
('31', 264, 2, 5, 601123) How are we to achieve the unity of purpose, the unity of action between the diverse elements except by means which are not open to any question, namely, non violence and truthfulness?
('31', 264, 2, 6, 601307) We will not be able to deal with our Muslim countrymen or with our Hindu countrymen on any other terms.
('31', 264, 2, 7, 601411) And then we have our provincialism.

('31', 264, 2, 9, 601631) Gujarat, which is merely a drop in the ocean compared to Bengal, thinks it must rule the whole of India and India should be merged in Gujarat.

('31', 264, 2, 11, 601834) Why should they not think that they must shape the destiny and policy of India?

('31', 275, 1, 7, 628495) Among those who received medals three were Muslims.
('31', 275, 1, 8, 628547) There were graded medals and prizes for the best carders, best sliver makers, best spinners and best weavers.

('31', 275, 3, 24, 629587) Deshbandhu’s speech was short and interesting.

('31', 275, 3, 29, 629973) There was, therefore, a good deal of heat in the Subjects Committee.

('31', 278, 1, 2, 632853) 166. SPEECH AT PRABARTAK ASHRAM, CHANDERNAGORE
('31', 278, 2, 3, 632900) May 5, 1925
('31', 278, 3, 4, 632912) The Mahatma said that he had long been entertaining the wish to come to the
('31', 278, 4, 5, 632988) Ashram and he was glad that his wish was at last fulfiled.
('31', 278, 4, 6, 633047) He had heard from Nirmal
('31', 278, 5, 7, 633072) Babu a good deal about the inner life and history of the Sangha and expressed how
('31', 278, 6, 8, 633154) profoundly he appreciated its high ideal and mission.
('31', 278, 6, 9, 633208) He was told that the Sangha
('31', 278, 7, 10, 633236) was founded on spiritual life.
('31', 278, 7, 11, 633267) The members followed the inner knowledge and institution and lived the integral ideal of the ancient, sanatan dharma.
('31', 278, 8, 12, 633385) principle was not merely a philosophy of tyaga or rejection, but total acceptance of
('31', 278, 9, 13, 633470) life for the fulfilment of God’s expression.
('31', 278, 9, 14, 633515) That was the Vedic dharma and its foundation was atma darshan or spiritual self realization.
('31', 278, 9, 15, 633608) It was not perfectly true to
('31', 278, 10, 16, 633637) say that his own ideal of life was quite different—nay, largely political.
('31', 278, 10, 17, 633712) Whatever he did, his ideal was paramartha or “selflessenss of the highest self” as he would say,
('31', 278, 11, 18, 633809) and he was strictly a mumukshu or moksharthi, in the sense that he wanted his
('31', 278, 12, 19, 633887) salvation through the service and salvation of the nation and humanity.
('31', 278, 12, 20, 633959) Here he was
('31', 278, 13, 21, 633971) really spiritual, for his motive was self consecration and his whole life and work was
('31', 278, 14, 22, 634058) dedicated entirely to the feet of Sri Krishna and Bharat Mata.
('31', 278, 14, 23, 634121) Therefore, gently
('31', 278, 15, 24, 634139) insisted the Mahatma that his ideal was nowhere essentially different from that of the
('31', 278, 16, 25, 634226) “Prabartak Sangha”.
('31', 278, 16, 26, 634246) Next, he dwelt on the excellent system of spiritual education imparted at the Ashram and he was glad that their motto was swavalamban or practical
('31', 278, 17, 27, 634393) self help.
('31', 278, 17, 28, 634404) Spirituality without economic foundation, as he believed, was a broken
('31', 278, 18, 29, 634475) reed, and he congratulated the Sangha in having achieved such a unique harmony between spiritual life and economic tapasya.
('31', 278, 19, 30, 634599) Afterwards he dwelt on khadi and charkha and said he would be still more glad,
('31', 278, 20, 31, 634678) when he would find that the Sangha had totally rejected mixed yarn.
('31', 278, 20, 32, 634746) As now he would
('31', 278, 21, 33, 634762) tell people wherever he went, to go to the Prabartak Ashram at Chandernagore, to see
('31', 278, 22, 34, 634847) the excellent work there in respect of spiritual culture, exemplary character 
('31', 278, 23, 35, 634926) building—so also he longed to say that the Sangha was doing pure khadi work alone
('31', 278, 24, 36, 635008) as an ideal institution.
('31', 278, 25, 37, 635033) He explained further how his heart throbbed for the crores of India’s sons and daughters who could not get even a mouthful meal every day and were plunged in abject misery.
('31', 278, 25, 38, 635206) For these crores of India’s poverty ridden souls and for nationwide unity did he preach his triple gospel of khaddar, Hindu Muslim unity and removal of
('31', 279, 0, 1, 635358) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 279, 1, 2, 635400) untouchability.
('31', 279, 1, 3, 635416) It was for him his practical Vedanta, for he believed in the one self in all and would harm none for his life, which was the true meaning of his ideal of non violence.
('31', 279, 1, 4, 635584) He exhorted the audience to spin, weave and wear khaddar as the only means revealed to him, for securing swaraj for the millions of India.

('31', 279, 3, 6, 635754) 167. SPEECH AT ASHTANGA AYURVEDA VIDYALAYA
('31', 279, 4, 7, 635797) CALCUTTA, May 6, 1925
('31', 279, 5, 8, 635819) FRIENDS, It was not without greatest hesitation that I accepted the invitation to lay the foundation stone of this great institution.
('31', 279, 5, 9, 635953) You know that some years ago I performed the opening ceremony of the Tibbia College 1 whose presiding deity was my esteemed friend and brother, Hakim Ajmal Khan 2 .
('31', 279, 5, 10, 636118) Even then it was not without hesitation that I performed the ceremony.
('31', 279, 5, 11, 636189) I could not resist the invitation that was given to me by a bosom friend and little could I resist a similar invitation coming again from a bosom friend.
('31', 279, 5, 12, 636343) But I would be untrue to myself and untrue to those assembled if I did not express my deepest thoughts about medicine and particularly about Ayurvedic and Unani medicines and the profession in general.
('31', 279, 5, 13, 636545) It was in 1908 3
('31', 279, 6, 14, 636562) that, for the first time, I reduced to writing my views about medicines and the medical profession, and I am not able, looking at it after so many years, to alter a single word of what I have said there.
('31', 279, 6, 15, 636766) No doubt what I wrote in 1908 was compressed, it was a passing reference to a subject which was included among so many others which I had to deal within a mere booklet.
('31', 279, 6, 16, 636935) Since then I have expanded the same thought, but I have not diminished the strength of the thought that I expressed in 1908. Every time I approach medical men and their medicines, I do so in fear and trembling, and it takes nothing away from my fear that I submitted to the living knife of a surgeon whom I only knew

('31', 280, 1, 2, 637583) perfunctorily in the Yeravda jail 1. I had the fullest confidence in Col.
('31', 280, 1, 3, 637657) Maddock 2 as a man and as a friend but I had not the fullest confidence in his ways and in the medicines that he prescribed.
('31', 280, 1, 4, 637782) If you were to go to him today, he will issue a double certificate—one in my favour and the other against me.
('31', 280, 1, 5, 637892) He will certify to you that to a certain extent I was a willing, obedient and a loyal patient, a more loyal patient he could not wish for.
('31', 280, 1, 6, 638031) But he will also say and certify that I was one of the most difficult patients he had to deal with.
('31', 280, 1, 7, 638131) He had to deal with my prohibitions.
('31', 280, 1, 8, 638168) I will take this and I will not take that and my negations were far more than my ayes.

('31', 280, 1, 10, 638368) It was with the greatest difficulty that he could persuade me to take so many of the medicines that he thought I should take and that I thought I ought not to take.
('31', 280, 1, 11, 638533) (Laughter.) Well, there it is.
('31', 280, 1, 12, 638564) I have merely given you a skeleton of my views about the profession, but perhaps you will better understand my views when I tell you that I belong to that noble, growing, but the still small school of thought which believes more in prevention than in cure, which believes in Nature doing things for herself even for suffering humanity if we would but let Nature take her course.
('31', 280, 1, 13, 638943) I believe in that school of thought which considers that the less interference there is on the part of doctors, on the part of physicians and surgeons, the better it is for humanity and its morals.
('31', 280, 1, 14, 639141) I belong to that school of thought among medical men who are fast coming to the conclusion that it is not their duty merely to subserve the needs of the body, but it is their bounden religious duty to consider the resident within that body, which is after all imperishable.
('31', 280, 1, 15, 639415) And I belong to that school of thought among medical men who consider that they will do nothing in connection with that body if whatever they do is going to impair, in the slightest degree, the soul, the spirit within.
('31', 280, 1, 16, 639634) And it grieves me so often when I find some of my best medical friends—and you will accept my word—but I assure you that it grieves me when they discuss with me the question whether there is such a thing as soul and when they tell me that, if there was a soul, it would not escape their deadly knife.
('31', 280, 1, 17, 639935) Little do they know that the soul survives the knife and that the
('31', 280, 2, 18, 640001) 1 Gandhiji was operated upon for appendicitis in 1924 2 Surgeon General Sassoon Hospital, Poona, who performed the operation
('31', 281, 0, 1, 640126) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 281, 1, 2, 640168) soul is not to be found by any probing of knife, however deep it may be.
('31', 281, 1, 3, 640241) (Laughter).
('31', 281, 1, 4, 640253) Therefore, it was with the greatest hesitation that I have approached this function.
('31', 281, 1, 5, 640338) I wonder whether it is a real sign of civilization when the number of hospitals in a particular place is larger than in another place.
('31', 281, 1, 6, 640473) I wonder whether it is really a test of growth to find in the catalogues and in the directories of medical men that every year their sales are increasing by leaps and bounds and that the inmates in the hospitals and dispensaries are increasing.
('31', 281, 1, 7, 640718) I really wonder whether it is a sign of real progress.
('31', 281, 1, 8, 640773) However, I know that there is the other side of it.
('31', 281, 1, 9, 640825) I don't want to labour only on one side of this question.
('31', 281, 1, 10, 640883) But, in all humility I have placed [these] for consideration of those who are put in charge of the management of this great institution.
('31', 281, 1, 11, 641020) I have hitherto confined my remarks to medicine and surgery in general, but when I come to the Ayurvedic and the Unani system, I am filled with greater doubts.
('31', 281, 1, 12, 641180) You may not know that, even from my boyhood.
('31', 281, 1, 13, 641225) I have come in contact with many physicians, some of them known to be distinguished in their own localities.
('31', 281, 1, 14, 641334) There was a time when I used to swear by the Ayurvedic medicine and used to commend it to all my friends, who went in for Western medicine, to go to these Ayurvedic physicians.
('31', 281, 1, 15, 641511) But I feel sorry to have to own to you that I was undeceived and I found that our Ayurvedic and Unani physician lack sanity.
('31', 281, 1, 16, 641636) They lack the humility.
('31', 281, 1, 17, 641660) Instead of that I found in them an arrogance that they knew everything (Laughter), that there was no disease which they could not cure.
('31', 281, 1, 18, 641796) (Renewed laughter.) I found that they believed that the mere feeling of the pulse could enable them to understand whether the patient was suffering from appendicitis or same such other disease.
('31', 281, 1, 19, 641990) When I found that their diagnosis was false, that it was incomplete in most cases, I felt that it was nothing short of humbug.
('31', 281, 1, 20, 642117) When I turned to the advertisements of medicines—I shall not say from Kavirajas—but Unani Hakims and Vaidyarajas, I felt humiliated I felt a sense of shame coming over me—these advertise ments which pander to the basest passion of humanity, disfigure our newspapers and magazines.
('31', 281, 1, 21, 642398) I have handled magazines devoted to the education of ladies.
('31', 281, 1, 22, 642459) I have seen magazines devoted to the education and information of young men, and I have found these advertisements alluring, no doubt, profitable, no doubt, to those who advertise these nauseating things.
('31', 281, 1, 23, 642664) I felt that they are cutting deep into the vitals of the suffering humanity.
('31', 281, 1, 24, 642741) Therefore, whilst I am going to perform this ceremony of laying the foundation stone of this noble institution and whilst I do so with a prayerful heart and wish it all success, I want the organizers to note
('31', 282, 0, 1, 642949) VOL.31 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 283
('31', 282, 1, 2, 642989) my limitations, to understand the note of warning that I have uttered to those who are called upon to devote their wealth to this institution.
('31', 282, 1, 3, 643132) I utter an all humility this note of warning.
('31', 282, 1, 4, 643178) May this institution be of use to the real suffers.
('31', 282, 1, 5, 643230) May this institution take care not merely of the need of the body but of the imperishable soul that resides in that body.
('31', 282, 1, 6, 643352) May it never be said of this institution that it panders to the basest taste of humanity, that it panders to the basest taste of the youths of Bengal—and I know the youths of Bengal.
('31', 282, 1, 7, 643535) I know how their fair life is being sapped by the medicines that are poured down their throats by physicians who, in the words of the Lord Justice Stephen, “introduce drugs of which they know little into the bodies of which they know less”.
('31', 282, 1, 8, 643776) 1 And so I plead, as I pleaded in Madras at a similar function, for sanity, for humility, for truthfulness, for fear of God among those who are the present organizers of the institution and those who follow.
('31', 282, 1, 9, 643984) With these words I shall have much pleasure as soon as you give me room to go to the place where I have to lay the foundation and I shall have equal pleasure in praying for the success of this institution.

('31', 282, 2, 11, 644221) 168. COW PROTECTION Rightly or wrongly, most reluctantly and in fear and trembling I have shouldered the burden of conducting the All India Cow protection Organization that was brought into being at Madhavbag in Bombay on the 28th ultimo.
('31', 282, 2, 12, 644460) It is a tremendous task for which I am hardly fitted.
('31', 282, 2, 13, 644514) I fancy that I know the disease.
('31', 282, 2, 14, 644547) I know the remedy, but I have neither the time nor yet the men who can help me to carry out the ideas that are to govern this institution.
('31', 282, 2, 15, 644686) Cow protection to me is not mere protection of the cow.
('31', 282, 2, 16, 644742) It means protection of all that lives and is helpless and weak in the world.
('31', 282, 2, 17, 644819) But for the moment cow protection means primarily protection of the cow and her progeny from cruelty and slaughter and derivatively all other cattle, e.g., the buffalo.
('31', 282, 2, 18, 644988) India is the one country in the world where cow protection is a religious obligation for over twenty crores of her people.
('31', 282, 2, 19, 645111) And yet the
('31', 282, 3, 20, 645123) 1 Vide also “General Knowledge About Health [ II]”, 11 1 1913.
('31', 283, 0, 1, 645186) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 283, 1, 2, 645228) cattle of India are miserable looking, ill treated, underfed, over burdened, deteriorating and are even said to be a burden on the land.
('31', 283, 1, 3, 645365) Nowhere else on the earth are milch cattle led to the slaughter house because they go dry long before they should.
('31', 283, 1, 4, 645480) Nowhere else perhaps do cattle give less milk than they cost to feed and keep.
('31', 283, 1, 5, 645559) How can this state of things be remedied?
('31', 283, 1, 6, 645601) Certainly not by multiplying cow protection societies which do not know their business; most certainly not by fighting the Mussalmans about things which they cannot help even if they would.
('31', 283, 1, 7, 645791) I do not here take note of those Mussalmans who, merely to wound Hindu susceptibility, kill cows deliberately and preferably and, as it were, in the Hindus' faces.
('31', 283, 1, 8, 645955) These are exceptional cases.
('31', 283, 1, 9, 645984) I am thinking of the cattle economics.
('31', 283, 1, 10, 646023) If we take care of them, the rest will take care of itself.
('31', 283, 1, 11, 646083) If the cattle are an economic burden and if one cannot set the condition right, nothing can prevent them from perishing or being slaughtered.
('31', 283, 1, 12, 646225) The problem, therefore, is to study the question calmly and without sentiment.
('31', 283, 1, 13, 646304) Religion without the backing of reason and enlightenment is a worthless sentiment which is bound to die of inanition.
('31', 283, 1, 14, 646422) It is knowledge that ultimately gives salvation.
('31', 283, 1, 15, 646471) Devotion to the cow divorced from knowledge is the surest way of imposing premature death on her.
('31', 283, 1, 16, 646569) Therefore, one man with an accurate knowledge of the cattle problem, if he has the heart for the cow, represents in his own person all the cow protection societies that were and will be ever formed.
('31', 283, 1, 17, 646768) This all India organization is conceived with that end in view, to find out men, chaste, pure, lovers of the cow and learned who would give their whole time to the work of investigation and administration.
('31', 283, 1, 18, 646974) I want, therefore, a secretary whose qualifications I have described in the opening speech reported elsewhere in these pages.
('31', 283, 1, 19, 647100) A treasurer too has still to be found.
('31', 283, 1, 20, 647139) Meanwhile, a provisional committee and a provisional trea surer and a provisional secretary have been appointed in order to do the preliminary work.
('31', 283, 1, 21, 647288) The committee is by no means represen tative of all India.
('31', 283, 1, 22, 647347) For it was necessary to appoint one from those present.
('31', 283, 1, 23, 647403) The members of this provisional committee have undertaken, during the three months that are to elapse before it meets again, to enlist over twelve hundred members.
('31', 283, 1, 24, 647567) If the organization is to be representative, it should have members from all the provinces.

('31', 284, 2, 7, 648160) 169. AT IT AGAIN My revolutionary friend has returned to the charge, but I must tell him that he has not been as patient with his composition as before.
('31', 284, 2, 8, 648313) He has introduced in his letter under discussion much irrelevant matter and has argued loosely.
('31', 284, 2, 9, 648409) So far as I can see, he has exhausted all his argument and has nothing new to say.
('31', 284, 2, 10, 648492) But should he write again, I advise him to write his letter more carefully and boil down his thoughts.

('31', 289, 2, 3, 660275) DEIFICATION OF ME A Muslim friend met me at Dungargarh station and told me that the process of deifying me, especially among the Gonds, was going on as merrily as ever.
('31', 289, 2, 4, 660444) I have expressed my horror and strongest disappro val of this type of idolatry more than once.
('31', 289, 2, 5, 660539) I claim to be a mere mortal, heir to all the weaknesses that human flesh betrays.
('31', 289, 2, 6, 660621) It would be infinitely better that the Gonds should be taught to understand the meaning of my simple massage than that they should indulge in a meaningless deification of me which can do no good either to them or to me and can intensify the superstitious nature of such simple people as the Gonds.
('31', 289, 2, 7, 660919) I be speak the help of every Congressman in the nece ssary work of un deceiving the Gonds of their error.

('31', 289, 3, 9, 661139) They presented me with a piece of khaddar spun and woven by them.
('31', 289, 3, 10, 661205) The workers told me that the most substantial work was really done by the untouchables.
('31', 289, 3, 11, 661293) They were giving up drink and carrion and taking to khaddar.
('31', 289, 3, 12, 661354) Had I not been told that the people I met at this station.
('31', 289, 3, 13, 661413) Jharsingada, were untoucha bles, I should not have distinguished them from the rest of the company.
('31', 289, 4, 14, 661513) KHADDAR At Raigarh I was astounded to hear that there was not a single spinning wheel.
('31', 289, 4, 15, 661600) The men who had come to meet me quietly told me that some of them wore what the poor people from the interior brought.
('31', 289, 4, 16, 661719) They informed me that khaddar has become very popular among the people in the villages and that, if there was more interest taken in the work, it could easily become universal.
('31', 289, 4, 17, 661896) The people of the Central Provinces including Chhatisgarh are specially adapted for the wheel and the loom which merely await organization.
('31', 289, 5, 18, 662036) SPLITTING HAIRS A well known Congressman for whom I have great regard and who prides himself of being a disciplinarian was found the other day not being wholly dressed in khaddar.
('31', 289, 5, 19, 662216) I thought that he was fully dressed in khaddar.
('31', 289, 5, 20, 662264) But the friends who lived in the same town with him knew better and asked me to persuade this friend to respect the

('31', 309, 5, 8, 706954) 181. UNTOUCHABLE SAINT NANDA Shri Mahadev has called the story of Nanda from the literature of the South.
('31', 309, 5, 9, 707060) I wish that everyone should read it with interest.
('31', 309, 5, 10, 707111) Let no one believe that the story of Nanda is anyone’s invention.
('31', 309, 5, 11, 707177) There may be exaggeration in it.
('31', 309, 5, 12, 707210) But there indeed lived a saintly Antyaja named Nanda six hundred years ago.
('31', 309, 5, 13, 707286) That, by the strength of his character, he earned his right to enter a temple and that even today he is worshipped by Hindus as an avatar is not to be doubted.The sanc tifying story of Nanda teaches us that though the condition in which one is born is the fruit of one’s actions in the previous life, the Creator has left scope for human effort, so that an Antyaja like Nanda could, by the strength of his character, purify himself during his life and was regarded by others as purified.
('31', 309, 5, 14, 707774) The Brahmins accepted him with love.
('31', 309, 5, 15, 707811) If Nanda could become pure during his life, we must believe that all of us have that power in us.
('31', 309, 5, 16, 707909) Every Antyaja, therefore, should have the right to enter our temples for worship.

('31', 309, 5, 18, 708176) The story of his going through fire is pure poetry.
('31', 309, 5, 19, 708228) Or, even if we believe it to be true, he entered fire of his own free will.
('31', 309, 5, 20, 708304) The vast majority of Brahmins were ready to permit Nanda to enter the temple for the purpose of darshan 2 on condition only that he should take a bath.
('31', 309, 5, 21, 708456) The only moral we should draw from this story is that an Antyaja can, by right effort, purify himself during his present life.
('31', 309, 5, 22, 708583) That is to say, the Antyajas should be free to enter temples on the same condition on which other Hindus can.
('31', 309, 5, 23, 708693) This much for the so called caste Hindus.

('31', 312, 6, 8, 712729) May 10, 1925
('31', 312, 7, 9, 712742) Mahatmaji at first thanked the Reception Committee and the Municipality for the addresses (manpatras as he called them) they had given him.
('31', 312, 7, 10, 712882) It was only the
('31', 312, 8, 11, 712898) outcome of their love for him that the references to his virtues were made therein.
('31', 312, 9, 12, 712982) Accepting their love he said he would pray to God for acquiring those virtues and he,
('31', 312, 10, 13, 713068) therefore, accepted the encomiums as a token of their love.

('31', 312, 12, 15, 713201) Committee’s address so far as the amount of work was concerned, he said that there
('31', 312, 13, 16, 713284) was nothing to be disheartened, if one would stick to one’s work with earnestness,
('31', 312, 14, 17, 713367) spirit of sacrifice and humility.

('31', 312, 15, 19, 713497) Mahatmaji emphasized this, saying our religion teaches us to remain engaged
('31', 312, 16, 20, 713573) to duty.
('31', 312, 16, 21, 713582) He said that he understood the reason of the slow progress of their work; it
('31', 312, 17, 22, 713659) was because the country had very lately entered into the sphere of real action.
('31', 312, 17, 23, 713739) Up to this time we had only talked of work, but did not apply ourselves seriously to undertake work.
('31', 312, 17, 24, 713840) From the period of words we were approaching the period of action.
('31', 312, 17, 25, 713907) We have to advance towards the spiritual life through the sadhana of karma now that we had stepped into the region of action.
('31', 312, 17, 26, 714033) We realized our real situation ten years before when address, eulogy and clapping of hands, were the fashion of political platforms.
('31', 312, 17, 27, 714166) We had thousands of workers.
('31', 312, 17, 28, 714195) Nowadays it is no wonder that the number of workers at the charkha are found less.

('31', 313, 1, 2, 714618) Mahatmaji said that he did not feel at all disappointed at the abnormal decrease in the number of Congress members and no increase in the number of charkha.
('31', 313, 1, 3, 714775) He felt that it was giving him more determination for work.
('31', 313, 1, 4, 714835) For this reason he urged upon his brothers and sisters to have faith in their work.
('31', 313, 1, 5, 714919) He said he would consider thirty members of the Congress who fulfil the conditions of the spinning franchise, Hindu Muslim unity and untouchability more valuable assets than one crore of Congress members who would pay fouranna subscription and do nothing.
('31', 313, 1, 6, 715175) He said that five or seven real and genuine coins were more valuable than one crore of counterfeit coins which should be thrown away into the river and discarded.
('31', 313, 1, 7, 715338) So the spinning franchise of the Congress is only a test to determine the real workers and it would help in finding out counterfeit materials.
('31', 313, 1, 8, 715481) If anybody would say that he has no faith in charkha, he must give up charkha, but if you have faith in charkha you need not be disappointed because others do not take to it.
('31', 313, 1, 9, 715656) You must be alive to your duty and go on with your work.
('31', 313, 2, 10, 715713) Mahatmaji emphatically said that, even if the charkha was given up by the last man of the country, he would alone remain in his house and work with his charkha silently for 8 hours a day.
('31', 313, 3, 11, 715901) He again referred to the miserable condition of the people arising out of want mentioned in the Reception Committee’s address.
('31', 313, 3, 12, 716028) He said he heard of water hyacinth pest in this part of the country which is greatly damaging yearly crop.
('31', 313, 3, 13, 716135) In my opinion, it is owing to the habit of indolence that we are suffering, and it is owing to the very same reason that the water hyacinth is increasing without any check.
('31', 313, 3, 14, 716308) It is for the deliverance of the people of India from their miseries and adversities that I am preaching the gospel of charkha.

('31', 314, 1, 2, 716937) 186. SPEECH AT NATIONAL SCHOOL, CHANDPUR
('31', 314, 2, 3, 716978) May 10, 1925
('31', 314, 3, 4, 716991) The Mahatma met the students at National School and the proceedings there were of extreme interest.
('31', 314, 3, 5, 717091) He first called those boys who would consider themselves to be most wicked.
('31', 314, 3, 6, 717167) None offered at the call at first.
('31', 314, 3, 7, 717202) Later on some boys came forward admitting that they were wicked boys.
('31', 314, 3, 8, 717272) Mahatmaji then called who considered themselves to be ignorant and silly.
('31', 314, 3, 9, 717346) A big lot of boys offered themselves as belonging to the latter category which aroused laughter.
('31', 314, 3, 10, 717443) Mahatmaji then explained the virtues of a wicked boy as well as those of ignorant boys and he gave them some instructions which were heard with attention.
('31', 314, 3, 11, 717598) He asked them to realize the growing poverty of the country.
('31', 314, 3, 12, 717659) Boys who spin the charkhas, he said, could feel this.
('31', 314, 3, 13, 717713) Therefore he urged them to try their best to spin yarn daily.
('31', 314, 3, 14, 717775) The boy who kept no ideal in view in spite of many disappointments was a naughty boy, and an idiot boy was one who felt satisfaction at nothing.
('31', 314, 3, 15, 717920) The more he produced yarn, the more would he think that he had done his duty.
('31', 314, 3, 16, 717998) In the struggle for swaraj these sets of boys are indispensable.
('31', 314, 3, 17, 718063) Finally Mahatma Gandhi urged them to be respectful towards their parents, to love their teachers and all the members of the family and to be on friendly terms with their colleagues.
('31', 314, 3, 18, 718245) With these words he gave them his hearty blessing.
('31', 314, 3, 19, 718296) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 13 5 1925

('31', 316, 1, 2, 721365) him for reply as he knows the Bengal conditions much better than I can ever hope to.

('31', 316, 2, 4, 721470) The writer thinks that the real difficulty about the spread of khaddar in Bengal lies in the high price of cotton.
('31', 316, 2, 5, 721585) The remedy suggested is to introduce and encourage the cultivation of cotton.
('31', 316, 3, 6, 721663) It is surely a difficulty in Bengal that cotton is not grown everywhere.
('31', 316, 3, 7, 721736) But it is not the only difficulty or a serious difficulty.
('31', 316, 3, 8, 721795) Manchester buys her cotton from America and Bombay and sends her mill products to India.
('31', 316, 3, 9, 721884) Surely Bengal can get all the cotton she wants at any of the cotton marts of India.
('31', 316, 3, 10, 721968) Lacs of rupees worth of cotton is grown in Bengal and sent away from the ports of Chittagong and Calcutta.
('31', 316, 3, 11, 722075) Bengal does not utilize for home spinning a fraction of the cotton she grows.
('31', 316, 3, 12, 722153) She can use all her Chittagong and Comilla produce for home spinning and buy what more she requires in the markets of Bihar and United Provinces.

('31', 316, 4, 14, 722421) What is wanting for the spread of khadi is a desire to spin and use khadi and an organization to create and cater for the desire.

('31', 316, 5, 16, 722683) The Ashram might train up an expert in spinning and carding and then demonstrate to the sisters in the neighbourhood that with good slivers and a good charkha it is a pleasure to spin.
('31', 316, 5, 17, 722868) It is only when spinning becomes irksome that imaginary difficulties about the spread of khadi crop up.
('31', 316, 5, 18, 722972) If the sisters of Bengal are helped from orgnizations where charkha experts are in a mood to serve, then every difficulty will disappear and I may even see culti vators introducing cotton cultivation without much coaxing.

('31', 316, 6, 20, 723227) There are processes before it and after it.
('31', 316, 6, 21, 723271) Cotton cultivation, ginning and carding precede, spinning and weaving come after.
('31', 316, 6, 22, 723353) We must confine our attention to efficient carding, spinning and weaving now.
('31', 316, 6, 23, 723431) Serious effort made by determined men from efficient organizations will override all difficulties and make spinning a success in Bengal.
('31', 316, 6, 24, 723568) I hope to see such a day in the near future.

('31', 318, 1, 2, 726835) 190. INTERVIEW TO HARDAYAL NAG
('31', 318, 2, 3, 726866) CHANDPUR, [Before May 12, 1925]
('31', 318, 3, 4, 726898) Gandhiji was interviewed by Babu Hardayal Nag and gave replies to questions put to him.
('31', 318, 4, 5, 726986) Q[UESTION]: Do you still hold that swaraj cannot come from abroad?
('31', 318, 5, 6, 727053) A[NSWER] : Yes, most emphatically.
('31', 318, 6, 7, 727088) Q. Then why did you not controvert Mr. Das’s new theory of swaraj by way of gift and necessarily within the Empire?
('31', 318, 7, 8, 727204) A. I do not think that Mr. Das has said any such thing in his presidential address at Faridpur.
('31', 318, 7, 9, 727300) I read the address quite differently from what you do.
('31', 318, 7, 10, 727355) For Deshbandhu Das does not say that it is necessarily within the British Empire.
('31', 318, 7, 11, 727437) On the contrary, he adheres to the formula—“Within the Empire, if possible; without it, if nece ssary.”
('31', 318, 8, 12, 727541) Q. Do you not feel that certain classes of people are trying to change the colour of administration only, but not its character?
('31', 318, 9, 13, 727670) A. I know that some people merely want to change the colour but not the character.
('31', 318, 10, 14, 727753) Q. I venture to suggest that the Swarajists are trying to add another class to these classes for capturing the services with certain amount of false power transferred to them.
('31', 318, 11, 15, 727929) A. I hope not; nor do I believe it is so.
('31', 318, 11, 16, 727971) I know Deshbandhu Das and Pandit Motilal Nehru.
('31', 318, 11, 17, 728019) I am convinced that they will not be satisfied with mere change of colour.
('31', 318, 12, 18, 728094) Q. I cite the Calcutta Corporation as an instance.
('31', 318, 12, 19, 728145) It is now manned by Swar ajists, as far as possible.
('31', 318, 12, 20, 728198) The Swarajists, I suggest, want to capture the provincial and local administrations only to man them with Swarajists.
('31', 318, 13, 21, 728316) A. I do not know what is happening in the Calcutta Corpora tion.
('31', 318, 14, 22, 728381) Q. I and many others think that swaraj must grow from within and it must
('31', 318, 15, 23, 728454) be built in the village and we accept charkha as the only weapon for the foundation for it.
('31', 318, 15, 24, 728546) Do you agree?
('31', 318, 16, 25, 728560) A. I literally endorse your view.
('31', 318, 16, 26, 728594) But we feel that our task is very difficult on account of the apathy of the Swarajists.
('31', 318, 16, 27, 728682) In Bengal, almost all the Congress organizations are in their hands and they have no
('31', 319, 0, 1, 728767) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 319, 1, 2, 728809) faith in charkha.
('31', 319, 1, 3, 728827) That being the case, charkha is suffering most on account of want of provincial or district organizations.
('31', 319, 2, 4, 728934) Q. Do you approve of any separate organization in favour of charkha and khadi movement?
('31', 319, 3, 5, 729022) A. I shall be very sorry if I discover that the Swarajists have no faith in the spinning wheel.
('31', 319, 3, 6, 729118) I am aware that some of them do not possess the same faith in it that you and I have, but so far as my knowledge goes, I have not met a single Swarajist who has shown his disbelief in the spinning wheel.
('31', 319, 3, 7, 729322) Assuming that they do not believe in the charkha at all, I am still unable to understand your deduction that their apathy is hampering your or my progress.
('31', 319, 3, 8, 729478) On the contrary, you and I should to that extent make greater effort.
('31', 319, 3, 9, 729548) I, therefore, do not consider a separate organization for the development of spinning necessary, so long as the Swarajists do not repudiate the spinning wheel.
('31', 319, 4, 10, 729708) Q. Do you recognize the fact that the two parties are not pulling on well in their respective work?
('31', 319, 5, 11, 729808) A. I do not recognize the fact, but if the two parties are not pulling on well, I would then blame the non Swarajists more than the Swarajists, for the simple reason that the former had not the slightest occasion to stand in the latter’s path.
('31', 319, 5, 12, 730052) They at least have, I expect, made their final choice.
('31', 319, 5, 13, 730107) Let them abide by it and live up to it.
('31', 319, 6, 14, 730147) Q. But considering the fact that you are the accredited leader of both the parties, does your duty end in blaming this party or that party?
('31', 319, 7, 15, 730287) A. Yes, certainly, because though I may be the nominal head of both the parties, I am myself a non Swarajist.
('31', 319, 7, 16, 730397) Therefore, I am entitled to blame the non Swarajists more.
('31', 319, 8, 17, 730456) Q. Many of us have of course individually implicit faith in non violent non co operation as a means to win swaraj.
('31', 319, 8, 18, 730571) Now it is evident that the Swarajists are trying to discredit non co operation only for their class or party purposes and have already made gestures for co operation, of course on certain terms quite immaterial to the people of the country.
('31', 319, 8, 19, 730812) Under the circumstances, in his presidential address at Faridpur, Mr. Das has declared non co operation as a failure.
('31', 319, 8, 20, 730930) In your speech, subsequently made at Faridpur, you laid stress on non violence and truthfulness, but you did not say a word to save non co operation from the attack of Deshbandhu Das.
('31', 319, 8, 21, 731114) Will you illuminate us on this point?
('31', 319, 9, 22, 731152) A. I have discovered no attack on the part of Mr. Das on non co operation.
('31', 319, 9, 23, 731227) Therefore, non co operation was not a relevant matter.
('31', 319, 9, 24, 731282) Moreover, I have debarred myself from saying a word upon non co 
('31', 320, 0, 1, 731347) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH,1925 15 JUNE, 1925 321
('31', 320, 1, 2, 731388) operation from the congress platform, being the author of the resolution suspending non co operation at Belgaum.
('31', 320, 1, 3, 731501) But my own individual view is known to the world and my personal abstention from co operation is an ocular demonstration of my view.
('31', 320, 2, 4, 731634) Q. Of course at Faridpur you spoke not as President of the All India Congress Committee, but in your individual character and the phrases you used there were non violence and truthfulness but not a word about non co operation.
('31', 320, 2, 5, 731861) To my mind, non violence without non co operation is meaningless.
('31', 320, 2, 6, 731927) There is non violence even in cowardice.
('31', 320, 2, 7, 731968) If you have a firm faith in non violent non co operation, how can you allow any Swarajist to speak against it without any protest?
('31', 320, 3, 8, 732099) A. As I have told you there is not a word, so far as I am aware, said in Deshbandhu’s address against non co operation.
('31', 320, 3, 9, 732219) And we should also recollect that I was speaking on the creed of the Congress.
('31', 320, 3, 10, 732298) The creed of the Congress makes no mention of non co operation.
('31', 320, 3, 11, 732362) But it does make mention of “peaceful and legitimate means” and I took care in my speech to say that I paraphrased these two terms by the adjectives : non violence and truthfulness.
('31', 320, 4, 12, 732544) Q. Your declaration at Faridpur is that you have given your general power of attorney to Deshbandhu Das to do what he is doing in the Council.
('31', 320, 4, 13, 732687) Anyone can take it by implication that his performances in the Council are on behalf of you as principal, he being only an agent of you.
('31', 320, 4, 14, 732824) No one can be blamed for taking such a view of your statement according to the law relating to principal and agent.
('31', 320, 4, 15, 732940) Is that the case?
('31', 320, 4, 16, 732958) Do you support also what Deshbandhu Das does in the Council?
('31', 320, 5, 17, 733019) A. When I spoke of Deshbandhu Das or Swarajists being agents I spoke, as an Irishman once spoke of himself as one of the proprietors of the Empire, as one of the shareholders of the concern called the Indian National Congress.
('31', 320, 5, 18, 733246) And the Congress having given authority to the Swarajists to prosecute their Council programme, I think I was quite correct in describing the Swarajists as holders of my general power of attorney, so far as their Council work is concerned.
('31', 320, 5, 19, 733486) I need not, therefore, on that account endorse every detail of the Swarajists’ policy in the provincial Councils or Legislative Assembly.
('31', 320, 5, 20, 733624) As a wise and practical man, having once given my general power of attorney to the agents of my own choice, I do not bother my head about what they are doing.
('31', 320, 6, 21, 733783) Q. If the Swarajists succeed in obtaining a concession from the bureaucracy based on a certain agreement, will you be a party to that agreement?
('31', 320, 7, 22, 733928) A. Oh, when the terms of any agreement with the bureaucracy are out, I shall have to consider them.
('31', 320, 7, 23, 734028) I have issued no power of
('31', 321, 0, 1, 734054) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 321, 1, 2, 734096) attorney to anybody to conclude any settlement with the Government.
('31', 321, 1, 3, 734164) I therefore reserve, like every individual Congressman, my full right to scrutinize any terms of settlement that may be proposed for national acceptance.
('31', 321, 2, 4, 734318) Q. Do you understand what Deshbandhu Das means by provincial autonomy?
('31', 321, 3, 5, 734389) A. I can guess.
('31', 321, 4, 6, 734405) Q. Then what is it?

('31', 321, 9, 13, 734914) A. I should think not.

('31', 321, 11, 17, 735122) There was no occasion.

('31', 321, 12, 19, 735289) Q. But can you illuminate us why he studiously avoided the word which he has been preaching so long?
('31', 321, 13, 20, 735390) A. For the simple reason that he has used a more general term, an inclusive term.
('31', 321, 14, 21, 735472) Q. Can you guess the ultimate result of the work of the Swarajists in Council?

('31', 321, 15, 23, 735572) Because whenever I want to understand what they have done, I have got the newspaper records to fall back upon.

('31', 321, 15, 26, 735867) Because those who have gone to the Councils have declared and must declare that their potency depends upon the work done by the people themselves and the power evolved by them for self rule, I suggest that measure for your and everybody’s acceptance.
('31', 321, 15, 27, 736118) In that case, we need not search the newspaper files nor resort to the dangerous pastime of guessing.
('31', 321, 16, 28, 736220) Q. Do you not feel that non co operation is suffering most on account of

('31', 322, 14, 23, 737466) Without exa mining the instances, I am not able to pass any opinion, as I do not want to sit in judgment on the Swarajists or anybody, specially where there is no necessity for it.

('31', 323, 1, 2, 738623) world, far less with their erstwhile co workers, but they should silently and surely set their faces against obstacles and they should shine the brightest when the obstacles are the greatest.
('31', 323, 2, 3, 738815) Q. Is not the present attitude of the Swarajists worse than their open hostility?

('31', 325, 0, 1, 742992) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('31', 326, 10, 12, 745005) DEAR MR. REDDY, I have your letter.
('31', 326, 10, 13, 745041) I am writing this on the train carrying me to Chittagong.
('31', 326, 10, 14, 745099) I realize fully that the problem in the South is an ex ceptional problem though it is the same disease at bottom.
('31', 326, 10, 15, 745213) In my opinion the construction programme too must fail not because the Scheme is bad but because we are not ready.

('31', 326, 11, 26, 746039) She is undoubtedly bringing swaraj nearer.
('31', 326, 11, 27, 746082) Tell her, if I had any money and if I was a gambler, I would put my all on her and what is more expect to win.

('31', 327, 0, 1, 746296) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 327, 1, 2, 746338) 193. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, CHITTAGONG 1
('31', 327, 2, 3, 746382) May 12, 1925
('31', 327, 3, 4, 746395) Mahatma Gandhi in the course of his speech said he was grateful for the addresses, but was sorry that he could not bring either of the Ali Brothers with him.
('31', 327, 3, 5, 746553) He further regretted that Mr. Sen Gupta was also absent.
('31', 327, 3, 6, 746610) Last time when he visited their place, he was prohibited from speaking by the orders of the Government.
('31', 327, 3, 7, 746714) He thanked the Municipality for the splendid work they were doing.
('31', 327, 3, 8, 746781) He did not know whether it was useful to make education compulsory.
('31', 327, 3, 9, 746849) There were two opinions on the subject.
('31', 327, 3, 10, 746889) He, however, promised to think over the matter more carefully.
('31', 327, 3, 11, 746952) He thanked the Municipality for stopping drink and making its employees wear khaddar.
('31', 327, 3, 12, 747038) Nothing could be done except by khaddar.
('31', 327, 3, 13, 747079) Civil disobedience was an impossibility without khaddar.
('31', 327, 3, 14, 747136) The charkha was necessary to drive poverty out of the country.
('31', 327, 3, 15, 747199) His movement was for self purification.
('31', 327, 3, 16, 747239) He would never say anything which he did not do himself.
('31', 327, 4, 17, 747296) I have been just now asked to say a few words in English.
('31', 327, 4, 18, 747354) I know the Bengali infatuation for English.
('31', 327, 4, 19, 747398) You have heard every word I said translated fairly accurately in Bengali, your mother tongue.
('31', 327, 4, 20, 747492) I can’t imagine I can drive truth home with greater force, or in clearer words, through the medium of a language which is as foreign to you as it is to me.
('31', 327, 4, 21, 747648) However, I have to do my work and if I convert a few people to the cult of khaddar or convince, if they are not already convinced, a few of them to the truths of non violence through the medium of the English language, I should do so.
