('31', 328, 1, 2, 749080) thinking, that there is nothing before India so efficacious for her many ills as the spinning wheel and khaddar.
('31', 328, 1, 3, 749193) The problems of our dear country are so vast, so complex that nothing but a very simple remedy will solve the riddle.
('31', 328, 1, 4, 749311) The complex character of the education and the training that we have received has confounded our thoughts, paralysed our brains and, unless we have something presented to us in an inexplicable manner, we refuse to see the truth that lies in it.
('31', 328, 1, 5, 749556) But if you tax your brains or, better still, if you retire into your private rooms to bend your knee before God and ask Him to guide you, He will guide your hand and put it unerringly on the spinning wheel.
('31', 328, 1, 6, 749763) We have spoken, we have delivered speeches, we have written in newspapers, we have published books, we have even made researches.
('31', 328, 1, 7, 749893) But the age of speaking, the age of writing, the age of delivering oration is gone, never to return again.
('31', 328, 1, 8, 750000) The age of action has commenced.
('31', 328, 1, 9, 750033) You have to battle not against a race of speakers, but you have to give battle to the race of born workers—a race that has not known what it is to yield, a race that has inflexible determination, a race which is made of some of the finest soldiers in the world.
('31', 328, 1, 10, 750295) No diplomacy that we can call to our aid will be able to do the task that is before everyone of us.
('31', 328, 1, 11, 750395) You want mass consciousness, you want co operation of the masses?
('31', 328, 1, 12, 750461) You want Councillors to speak with power.
('31', 328, 1, 13, 750503) At the present moment there is no power in their words—there is no power in their resolutions— not because they don’t know how to speak.
('31', 328, 1, 14, 750640) Deshbandhu has shown how he can outwit the Government in defeating its resolution, defeating its policy.
('31', 328, 1, 15, 750745) But he can do little unless he has power behind him.
('31', 328, 1, 16, 750798) You and I, everyone of us, can’t go to the Councils.
('31', 328, 1, 17, 750851) I have said repeatedly I don’t believe in Councils.
('31', 328, 1, 18, 750903) But I have granted, those who believe in Councils should go there.
('31', 328, 1, 19, 750970) But I want to arm the Councillors with power.
('31', 328, 1, 20, 751016) I do not want them to become discredited after they have gone there.
('31', 328, 1, 21, 751085) I want them to be listened to with respect and attention by the Government.
('31', 328, 1, 22, 751161) How is that to be done?
('31', 328, 1, 23, 751185) Not by holding mass meetings, not by passing resolutions, not by approving of their policy of resolutions, but by giving some power to them.
('31', 328, 1, 24, 751326) And you will not, cannot, give them power unless you have evolved it for yourselves, in yourselves.
('31', 328, 1, 25, 751426) We have not got power.
('31', 328, 1, 26, 751449) I defy anybody to match the violence of the Government with violence.
('31', 328, 1, 27, 751519) No matter what may have been [done] in other parts of the world, I am positively certain that we should not attain our freedom by violent means.
('31', 329, 0, 1, 751664) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 329, 1, 2, 751706) I have placed, therefore, a non violent programme with full knowledge of what I am doing and not because it is a religion, as it is with me, but because it is expedient.
('31', 329, 1, 3, 751876) It is the only politics for the country.
('31', 329, 1, 4, 751917) And he who has any political wisdom must come to the conclusion that violent means will serve no earthly purpose.
('31', 329, 1, 5, 752031) I understand, I appreciate the impatience of those who are burning to deliver the country from the shackles that bind her.
('31', 329, 1, 6, 752154) I yield to none in my desire to free the country from the shackles.
('31', 329, 1, 7, 752222) But I consider myself to be a sane man.
('31', 329, 1, 8, 752262) I regard myself as having a great deal of common sense.
('31', 329, 1, 9, 752318) I regard myself as a man who has been something of the world.
('31', 329, 1, 10, 752380) I am born a fighter from the earliest days of my youth.
('31', 329, 1, 11, 752436) I am fighting even though it may be with my brothers, friends, wife, children, my co religionists and, if it is Mussalman, with Mussalmans.
('31', 329, 1, 12, 752576) But throughout my fight I have understood that one weapon is common to all these fights and that is the weapon of non violence.
('31', 329, 2, 13, 752704) I could not fight my wife with violence, I could not fight my brothers with violence, I refuse to fight the Mussalmans with violence and I dare not fight the Hindus, some of whom are opposing me on the question of untouchability, with violence.
('31', 329, 2, 14, 752949) I, therefore, deduce from that fund of experience that I cannot fight Englishmen with violence.
('31', 329, 2, 15, 753045) You have seen in one of my writings that I have converted more Englishmen to love India than any single one of the present generation.
('31', 329, 2, 16, 753180) I know it is a large claim, it is a proud claim, but it is the claim of the humble man, who has put forth that claim in all humility.
('31', 329, 2, 17, 753314) I feel, if we are to fight our battle non violently it will not be by mere words.
('31', 329, 2, 18, 753396) Non violence must be expressed in action.
('31', 329, 2, 19, 753438) Action without intermission, without rest, without recreation, without the slightest pause, with continuous determination—action with the fullest faith in its efficacy is the only remedy for India and the only remedy that I can place in the hands of those little girls and boys, in the hands of the grownup people, in the hands of poets and philosophers, in the hands of sannyasins, politicians, learned professors and sweepers, in the hands of women and in the hands of robust men.
('31', 329, 2, 20, 753921) The only universal remedy I can discover today is the spinning wheel.
('31', 329, 2, 21, 753991) Multiply the force of this charkha and spin until it is done by 3 hundred millions of men and then tell me what its power will be, tell me then what it will not do.
('31', 329, 2, 22, 754156) Is there nothing that we can claim to our credit?
('31', 329, 2, 23, 754206) Throughout all this long, dreary forty years of political life, we have not been able to show to the world one simple action done to perfection and to fulfilment.
('31', 329, 2, 24, 754369) We have placed before ourselves many programmes, I place before
('31', 330, 0, 1, 754433) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH,1925 15 JUNE, 1925 331
('31', 330, 1, 2, 754474) the nation only one programme and ask the nation to fulfil that programme before it can dare think of any other.
('31', 330, 1, 3, 754587) Is it an impossible programme that you and I should wear nothing but khaddar, although it may be costly?
('31', 330, 1, 4, 754692) It may be coarse.
('31', 330, 1, 5, 754710) If it is costly, than, tear it into half and do cover your nakedness with half the cloth and it will go to your credit in the book of life.
('31', 330, 1, 6, 754850) If it is coarse, then, for the sake of India, you will wear coarse cloth.
('31', 330, 1, 7, 754924) Understand that the slavery of India is coarser than the coarsest khaddar, understand that the pauperism of India is infinitely coarser than the coarsest khaddar that can be produced in Chittagong.
('31', 330, 1, 8, 755122) If you have heart to think for famishing millions of India, if you have heart to spin, then spin till your hands are paralysed and wear khaddar till you perspire in the coarsest khadi and then you will find that the swaraj of my dream—and of your dream—will break forth in the horizon and then you will dance in joy.

('31', 333, 3, 14, 762057) A little knowledge of the agricultural life will demonstrate the impracticability of such introduction.
('31', 333, 3, 15, 762161) Hand weaving is a long process requiring sustained labour and in itself demanding several processes at which more than one person is required to work at one and the same time.
('31', 333, 3, 16, 762337) This is not possible in a peasant’s cottage.
('31', 333, 3, 17, 762382) Hence, from times immemorial, hands weaving has been a separate occupation and an independent and sole means of livelihood.
('31', 333, 3, 18, 762506) A peasant requires an auxiliary occupation which he can take up or leave at will.
('31', 333, 3, 19, 762588) Such an occupation for the millions is only hand spinning.
('31', 333, 3, 20, 762647) There are, no doubt, other such occupations for utilizing odd moments.
('31', 333, 3, 21, 762718) But no other than hand spinning will be found to serve millions of men and women.
('31', 333, 3, 22, 762800) Hence if the Department of Industries will justify its exis tence and will think in terms of the millions rather than of individuals and of India rather than of England, then it will devote its attention principally to hand spinning, organize it among the villagers and

('31', 336, 14, 23, 767713) such thing as untouchability in the Hindu religion.

('31', 336, 14, 25, 767890) But he was sure that they would make a determined attempt to abolish untouchability.

('31', 336, 14, 27, 768062) Further, he hoped they would explain this matter to washermen.
('31', 336, 15, 28, 768125) Concluding, he said that they were aware that many people had no work for four months in the year and, as a result, they were becoming poorer.
('31', 336, 15, 29, 768268) All over the world, agriculture was supplemented by some work.
('31', 336, 15, 30, 768331) And in Hindusthan, there was nothing like the charkha.
('31', 336, 15, 31, 768386) That is why he called it Annapurna.
('31', 336, 15, 32, 768422) From the fields they
('31', 336, 16, 33, 768443) would get rice, but through the charkha alone they could improve their condition.
('31', 336, 16, 34, 768525) He emphasized that the middle class people should work at least half an hour daily on the charkha wherever they were.
('31', 336, 16, 35, 768643) If they, for the sake of the poor people, worked on the charkha, there was no greater work.
('31', 336, 16, 36, 768735) Hence he had been travelling in various places to emphasize on this point.

('31', 337, 1, 2, 769086) 202. INTERVIEW TO TEACHERS AT NOAKHALI
('31', 337, 2, 3, 769125) May 14, 1925
('31', 337, 3, 4, 769138) On the occasion of Mahatma Gandhi’s visit to Noakhali on the 14th instant, an interview was sought for and granted by him to some representatives of the District Teachers’ Association.
('31', 337, 3, 5, 769323) The deputationists put some searching questions to Mahatmaji regarding the present system of education and asked how, under the existing circumstances, the teachers could render real service to the country.
('31', 337, 3, 6, 769530) Mahatmaji smilingly began by saying, “Spin and spin still more.” He then advised the teachers that they should change the entire moral atmosphere of educational institutions by making impressions upon the minds of boys who are completely under their control by the example of their own character and work.
('31', 337, 3, 7, 769836) If the teachers, he said, were earnest in their efforts, no amount of Government interference through the agency of the Inspectorate could thwart their aims and objects, as the teachers were not Government servants.
('31', 337, 3, 8, 770052) Though the teachers of Bengal, and for the matter that of the whole of India, form a distinct class, yet no united effort at this stage could be expected.
('31', 337, 3, 9, 770207) But individual earnest workers should bear their part manfully.
('31', 337, 3, 10, 770271) Concluding, Mahatmaji remarked that he had in the past pointed out the duties and responsibilities of teachers and would do so more emphatically and definitely through the columns of his paper.

('31', 354, 2, 18, 812156) TO SPINNERS I have frequently stated that spinning does not mean merely drawing out a thread.
('31', 354, 2, 19, 812250) Just as a rotla 1 made somehow from any sort of flour and cooked on any wretched stove is not rotla and may cause indigestion if eaten, so too if we draw out a thread from cotton of any sort carded anyhow, it will not be yarn.
('31', 354, 2, 20, 812477) That alone is yarn which can be easily woven into cloth.
('31', 354, 2, 21, 812534) In this respect our standard is mill yarn.
('31', 354, 2, 22, 812577) Till our yarn is as good as mill yarn, the deficiency will be counted as our failure.
('31', 354, 2, 23, 812663) It is a matter of experience that not only can we equal it but can also excel it.
('31', 354, 2, 24, 812745) Good hand spun yarn is always superior to good mill yarn.
('31', 354, 2, 25, 812803) The softness to be found in cloth woven from the former is never to be found in mill cloth.
('31', 354, 2, 26, 812895) So long as we have not reached that level, there are bound to be complaints against khadi.
('31', 354, 2, 27, 812986) Not only that, but it will also be difficult to get every weaver to weave only khadi.

('31', 360, 1, 2, 824102) 217. TALK TO STUDENTS AT DACCA 1
('31', 360, 2, 3, 824135) May 17, 1925
('31', 360, 3, 4, 824148) At Dacca the students’ meeting was cancelled, but Gandhiji asked the students to come and have a chat after all the public functions were over, and they had more than they could even in their wildest dreams have expected.
('31', 360, 3, 5, 824370) Gandhiji, always at his best when provoked, unbosomed himself when a friend objected that spinning was a waste of energy and time, and another that his advice took no count of the principle of division of labour.
('31', 360, 3, 6, 824583) Do I ask you to do spinning for the whole of the day?
('31', 360, 3, 7, 824637) Do I ask you to take it up as a sbstantive occupation?
('31', 360, 3, 8, 824692) Where, then, is the breach of the principle of division of labour?
('31', 360, 3, 9, 824759) Do you have a division of labour in eating and drinking?
('31', 360, 3, 10, 824816) Just as everyone of us must eat and drink and clothe himself, even so, everyone of us must spin himself.
('31', 360, 3, 11, 824921) And it is a waste, you say?
('31', 360, 3, 12, 824949) Fellow feeling for your countrymen, you say, you have in an abundant measure?
('31', 360, 3, 13, 825027) And what is that fellow feeling without the milk of human kindness?
('31', 360, 3, 14, 825095) Do you feel anything like the love that a cow feels for her calf or a mother for her baby?
('31', 360, 3, 15, 825186) The cow’s udders and the mother’s breast overflow with milk at the sight of their young ones.
('31', 360, 3, 16, 825280) Do your hearts overflow with love at the sight of your famished countrymen?
('31', 360, 3, 17, 825356) By spinning, my friends, you demonstrate your love for them.
('31', 360, 3, 18, 825417) You spin and you make them shake off their idleness.
('31', 360, 3, 19, 825470) A friend goes and beautifully sings before a crowd and affects their hearts.

('31', 364, 4, 12, 833732) May 19, 1925 I am feeling forlorn without either of Ali Brothers.
('31', 364, 4, 13, 833798) For, with them I would have felt absolutely safe, through them I would have easily reached the Mussalman heart.
('31', 364, 5, 14, 833910) Touching upon Hindu Muslim question, he regretted that neither community was willing to surrender, not their vital interest, but little temporary interests.
('31', 364, 5, 15, 834067) At present they were fighting not even for loaves and fishes, but for stones and not for vital interests.
('31', 364, 5, 16, 834173) But he realized that, until they had cleansed their heart and purified their soul, they would not be able to live as brothers.
('31', 364, 5, 17, 834300) He advised them not to endanger their unity on the rock of selfishness.
('31', 364, 5, 18, 834372) After all, he believed the solution of this question did not depend on them.
('31', 364, 5, 19, 834449) Optimistic as he was, he believed that God would show mercy on this blessed land and enable them to live as brothers, in spite of their having fought each other.
('31', 364, 5, 20, 834611) The Hindu and the Mussalman must each add a common article to their creeds, viz., that he can never live without the other.
('31', 364, 5, 21, 834735) God who has placed together 7 crores of Mussalmans with 22 crores of Hindus will have some mercy on us and will make us live as brothers in spite of ourselves.

('31', 366, 1, 2, 837998) 226. A REMARKABLE ADDRESS In the majority of cases, addresses presented to me contain adjectives which I am ill able to carry.
('31', 366, 1, 3, 838125) Their use can do good neither to the writers not to me.
('31', 366, 1, 4, 838181) They unnecessarily humiliate me, for I have to confess that I do not deserve them.
('31', 366, 1, 5, 838264) When they are deserved, their use is superfluous.
('31', 366, 1, 6, 838314) It cannot add to the strength of the qualities possessed by me.
('31', 366, 1, 7, 838378) They may, if I am not on my guard, easily turn my head.
('31', 366, 1, 8, 838434) The good that a man does is more often than not, better left unsaid.
('31', 366, 1, 9, 838503) Imitation is the sincerest flattery.
('31', 366, 1, 10, 838540) I commend it, therefore, to the attention of all admirers.
('31', 366, 1, 11, 838599) If it is my spinning they like, let them admire it by doing it themselves; if it is my regularity they appreciate, let them flatter me by being regular themselves.
('31', 366, 1, 12, 838763) And if it is my truthfulness and non violence they treasure, let them show their appreciation by their conduct.
('31', 366, 1, 13, 838875) But not all the addresses contain a mere recital of my praises.
('31', 366, 1, 14, 838939) On rare occasions they give me valuable information.
('31', 366, 1, 15, 838992) A Chandpur address 1 was remarkable for a frank expression of its limitations.

('31', 367, 1, 2, 840127) Then follows an interesting commentary on most of the items.
('31', 367, 1, 3, 840188) It is wound up as follows :
('31', 367, 2, 4, 840216) We feel we will be failing in our obvious duty, if we do not allude to the terrible poverty and consequent mortality rampant amongst the people of the country.
('31', 367, 2, 5, 840376) They are simply groaning under heavy indebtedness.
('31', 367, 2, 6, 840427) The balance sheet of most of them indicates the hopeless condition of utter bankruptcy.
('31', 367, 2, 7, 840515) This state of things, brought about by the total annihilation of the cottage industries, leads to serious crimes, and we shudder to conceive the final result of this economic depression of the people.
('31', 367, 2, 8, 840716) The record is certainly not a proud one.
('31', 367, 2, 9, 840757) But there is nothing here to despair of.
('31', 367, 2, 10, 840798) We, each one of us, can but do our best.
('31', 367, 2, 11, 840839) We do not, cannot, control results which depend upon so many other circum stances.
('31', 367, 2, 12, 840922) We may feel quite at ease, when we have done our real best.
('31', 367, 2, 13, 840982) Unfortunately, in the majority of cases, we do not work or do it in differently and still complain of poverty of results.
('31', 367, 2, 14, 841104) All is well if we have done the best that is possible for us to do.
('31', 367, 2, 15, 841172) Truly, the problems that face us are enormous and many.
('31', 367, 2, 16, 841228) For one man or many to presume to tackle them all at once is to arrogate omnipotence.
('31', 367, 2, 17, 841314) Any such attempt is foredoomed to failure.
('31', 367, 2, 18, 841357) Our diffi culties are aggravated because we are a subject nation.
('31', 367, 2, 19, 841423) Many can be remedied if we were not.
('31', 367, 2, 20, 841460) But it is equally true that we shall not come to our own unless we tackle as many now.
('31', 367, 2, 21, 841547) Not to handle them till swaraj is obtained is to postpone both swaraj and the solution of the problems.
('31', 367, 2, 22, 841651) He, therefore, who handles the main problems to the best of his ability helps their solution and brings swaraj nearer.
('31', 367, 2, 23, 841770) If, then, the workers in Chandpur have exerted their utmost, results shown by them need not be considered discouraging.
('31', 367, 2, 24, 841890) Time must work in their favour, for it always does in favour of honest and industrious workers.
('31', 367, 2, 25, 841986) Better to have even 10 “A” class members than none, and for me, it is any day better to have 10 working members than to have ten thousand members who will pay four annas per year and then no more think about the Congress than miss their four annas.
('31', 367, 2, 26, 842235) The ten, if they will remain faithful to their trust, will soon convert themselves into one hundred.
('31', 367, 2, 27, 842336) I know no alternative to the wheel.
('31', 367, 2, 28, 842372) Those who do must set it up.
('31', 367, 2, 29, 842401) Till then the ten who work the wheel must hold the field undaunted.

('31', 367, 2, 33, 842688) One of the resolutions makes spinning by volunteers obligatory.

('31', 368, 1, 4, 843056) An unskilled surgeon is worse than no surgeon.
('31', 368, 1, 5, 843103) An indifferent volunteer is often a hindrance [rather] than a help.

('31', 368, 1, 8, 843272) But I want not personal service and attachment, precious as both are; I want national service and national attachment.
('31', 368, 1, 9, 843391) I want strictest devotion to duty and scrupulous fulfilment of all obligations imposed and accepted.
('31', 368, 1, 10, 843492) The address mentions increase in the liquor traffic.

('31', 368, 1, 13, 843774) The concluding commentary is a statement of our general con dition.
('31', 368, 1, 14, 843842) Revival of the cottage industry, and not cottage industries, will remove the growing poverty.

('31', 376, 3, 12, 864508) I have often walked through the streets of Calcutta.

('31', 376, 3, 14, 864647) The writer’s indictment of owners is not an exaggeration, though my own opinion is that the owners are more indifferent than calcula tedly cruel.
('31', 376, 3, 15, 864793) They too are amenable to reason as are the carriers and drivers.
('31', 376, 3, 16, 864858) How to reach them is the question.
('31', 376, 3, 17, 864893) To look after the condition of animals used within municipal jurisdiction is the function of the municipality concerned.

('31', 376, 3, 21, 865428) Much of the cruelty practised by men on dumb creation can be dealt with by a proper mobilization of the humane forces.
('31', 376, 3, 22, 865547) The Bengal Presidency Council of Women can depute volunteers to note all the cases that come under their observation and report them to the Corporation or the individual owners concerned.

('31', 380, 1, 2, 873270) 233. SPEECH AT WORKERS’ SCHOOL, BOGRA 1
('31', 380, 2, 3, 873310) May 22, 1925 I shall not speak to you on the charkha.
('31', 380, 2, 4, 873364) You know what I have been saying elsewhere.
('31', 380, 2, 5, 873408) I shall, however, tell you something about ahimsa in order to strengthen your faith in it.
('31', 380, 2, 6, 873499) A student at Dacca told me that he would more willingly face the gallows than ply the wheel which afforded no excitement.
('31', 380, 2, 7, 873621) 2 I have no doubt that he believed neither in ahimsa nor brahmacharya.
('31', 380, 2, 8, 873692) For the wheel is an emblem of peace and ahimsa, and I have pinned my faith to it, because ahimsa is not a policy with me, but a creed, a religion.
('31', 380, 2, 9, 873839) Why do I regard it as such?
('31', 380, 2, 10, 873867) Because I know that it is not himsa or destructive energy that sustains the world, it is ahimsa, the creative energy.
('31', 380, 2, 11, 873985) I do admit that the destructive energy is there, but it is evanescent, always futile before the creative which is permanent.
('31', 380, 2, 12, 874110) If the destructive one had the upper hand, all the sacred ties—love between parents and child, brother and sister, master and disciple, rulers and the ruled, would be snapped.
('31', 380, 2, 13, 874286) Ahimsa is like the sun whose worship, as the symbol of God, our rishis immortalized in the Gayatri.
('31', 380, 2, 14, 874386) As the sun “keeps watch over man’s mortality”, going his eternal rounds and dispelling darkness and sin and gloom, even so does ahimsa.
('31', 380, 2, 15, 874522) Ahimsa inspires you with love than which you cannot think of a better excitement.
('31', 380, 2, 16, 874604) And that is why my faith in the wheel, which is a symbol of peace and love, is increasing as I grow older.
('31', 380, 2, 17, 874711) And that is why I do not think I am committing an impropriety in spinning whilst I am talking to you.
('31', 380, 2, 18, 874813) As I am turning the wheel, I am saying to myself : “Why does God give me my daily bread, whilst He starves multitudes of men?
('31', 380, 2, 19, 874939) Let Him starve me also, or enable me to do something to remove their starvation.” And as I turn it, I am practising ahimsa and truth which are the obverse and reverse of the same coin.
('31', 380, 2, 20, 875124) Ahimsa is my God, and Truth is my God.
('31', 380, 2, 21, 875163) When I look for Ahimsa, Truth says, ‘Find it out through me.’ When I look for Truth, Ahimsa says, ‘Find it out through me.’ So the rhapsody easily became one on charkha and ahimsa instead of that on ahimsa alone.

('31', 382, 8, 15, 878282) 237. BENGAL’S SACRIFICE I overflow with joy to see examples of purest sacrifice in Bengal.
('31', 382, 8, 16, 878373) The whole family of a zamindar has taken to khadi.
('31', 382, 8, 17, 878424) All the women spin.
('31', 382, 8, 18, 878444) The men and women wear khadi exclusively.
('31', 382, 8, 19, 878486) The zamindar has made over his house and his land for the use of Khadi Pratishthan.
('31', 382, 8, 20, 878570) The sacrifice made by Satish Babu, who is the life of Khadi Pratishthan, is something extraordinary.
('31', 382, 8, 21, 878671) He used to earn a monthly salary of Rs. 1,500 in the Chemical Works of Dr. Ray.
('31', 382, 8, 22, 878751) He had been provided with a bungalow too.
('31', 382, 8, 23, 878793) He could have got more if he had asked for it.
('31', 382, 8, 24, 878840) He was doing khadi work even then, but he was not satisfied with that.
('31', 382, 8, 25, 878911) His tender heart felt that, if he attempted two tasks at a time, both might suffer in consequence.
('31', 382, 8, 26, 879010) He was the very life of the Chemical Works and, if he did not give his full time to it, it would certainly suffer.
('31', 382, 8, 27, 879125) But, then, khadi meant service of the poor, and he did not think it right that he should do that work in his spare time.
('31', 382, 8, 28, 879246) Just as it is a sin for a man to have two wives, so also it is wrong for a man to make two things his life’s mission.
('31', 382, 8, 29, 879364) Moreover, no sacrifice is too great in the cause of khadi.
('31', 382, 8, 30, 879423) Arguing thus with himself he decided in an instant to leave the Works which he himself had built up.
('31', 382, 8, 31, 879524) And now he meets his household expenses from the income from his meagre savings and devotes all the 24 hours of the day to the cause of khadi.
('31', 382, 8, 32, 879667) He has by now opened eleven branches of his centre, out of which five are already in production, and he is thinking of opening more still.

('31', 384, 1, 2, 882652) 238. MY NOTES
('31', 384, 2, 3, 882666) IF ONE IS BOYCOTTED?
('31', 384, 3, 4, 882687) A gentleman writes : 1
('31', 384, 4, 5, 882710) To this there is only one reply I can give.
('31', 384, 4, 6, 882754) However unjustly mahajans 2 act, we should not take them to courts.
('31', 384, 4, 7, 882822) Let them inflict any punishment they choose.
('31', 384, 4, 8, 882867) If we submit to it, their hearts will melt and they will repent.
('31', 384, 4, 9, 882932) Moreover, when a mahajan acts unjustly one should especially welcome being ostracized by it.
('31', 384, 4, 10, 883025) There is nothing to be gained by remaining in a community in which people sell girls in marriage, in which the atmosphere is vitiated by hypocrisy and whose mahajan connives at its members eating meat and drinking.
('31', 384, 4, 11, 883240) The institution of caste is only a tradition and not an essential part of dharma.
('31', 384, 4, 12, 883322) Membership of a community confers some advantages.
('31', 384, 4, 13, 883373) When, however, the institution becomes an instrument of immorality, the best course is to defy it.
('31', 384, 4, 14, 883472) The principle on which we have acted in resorting to non co operation with the Government should also be applied to one’s caste and one can non co operate with it.
('31', 384, 4, 15, 883636) But in this case there is no need at all to do anything of that kind.
('31', 384, 4, 16, 883706) Here it is the community which ostracizes a member.
('31', 384, 4, 17, 883758) The latter should welcome this as a happy event.
('31', 384, 4, 18, 883807) But this can be done only by one who has followed dharma in his conduct, who has served the community and willingly obeyed its rules which promote morality.
('31', 384, 4, 19, 883964) Only a man of self control will welcome ostracism, the man who lives for pleasure will be hurt by it.
('31', 384, 4, 20, 884066) But, then, it is not for a person of the latter type to interest himself in the abolition of untouchability, it is work which should be taken up only by a man of self control.
('31', 384, 4, 21, 884242) This movement is not intended to enlarge the scope of enjoyment in life; it is meant to increase opportunities for service, to see that no one is excluded from the scope of our service.
('31', 384, 5, 22, 884428) INDIAN STATES A gentleman has asked me this question.
('31', 384, 5, 23, 884482) 3 There is some truth in what he says, but there is also another side to the question.

('31', 386, 2, 4, 887952) JAIN “ MUNIS” 1 AND SPINNING WHEEL I have received several let ters about the report which appeared in Navajivan of the conversation I had in Palitana on the spinning wheel.
('31', 386, 2, 5, 888126) 2 I do not wish to be drawn into a discussion on this subject; it may not, however, be out of place to clarify a few points.
('31', 386, 2, 6, 888251) I have studied Jain Shastras according to my lights, but I know that I am not at all qualified to explain their meaning.
('31', 386, 2, 7, 888372) In the conversation referred to, I only explained the meaning of ahimsa and of being a muni.
('31', 386, 2, 8, 888465) It is possible that Jain philosophy does not accept my meaning.
('31', 386, 2, 9, 888529) I would be sorry if that was so, and admit that my view was different from the accepted Jain view.
('31', 386, 2, 10, 888628) Even so, I should have the right to state what appeals to my reason and my heart.
('31', 386, 2, 11, 888710) I may be mistaken in my view and, if I am, I am bound to suffer for my error; if I have erred through ignorance, I must correct my error as soon as I realize it.
('31', 386, 2, 12, 888872) My explanation of the meaning of ahimsa and of being a muni ought not hurt any Jain.
('31', 386, 2, 13, 888957) Why should anyone feel hurt when there was no intention on my part at all to cause any pain?
('31', 386, 2, 14, 889050) If someone does not agree with our view and we are convinced that we are right, we may by all means think that the other person is a fool, but why should we feel hurt?
('31', 386, 2, 15, 889218) Having said this, I repeat in all humility that at this time it is the sacred duty even of munis to work at the spinning wheel for general welfare.
('31', 386, 2, 16, 889366) As they are entitled to have food and drink in order that they may live and serve others, so it is their duty to spin for the service of others.
('31', 386, 2, 17, 889511) In my humble view, therefore, a muni who refuses to do work which may save even one soul does not deserve to be called a muni.

('31', 387, 1, 2, 889791) 239. NEEDLESS EXPENDITURE A long letter lies before me.
('31', 387, 1, 3, 889847) It contains a well deserved but gentle criticism of our present movement and of the workers engaged in it.
('31', 387, 1, 4, 889954) I reproduce below extracts from it which one should read : 1
('31', 387, 2, 5, 890015) I have given a summary of the 25 page letter almost in the correspondent’s own words.
('31', 387, 2, 6, 890101) The writer is a thoughtful person and has said everything with a good motive.
('31', 387, 2, 7, 890179) I know nothing about some of his allegations, but it is indeed my experience that public funds are being misused a great deal.
('31', 387, 2, 8, 890306) I have even criticized this from time to time.
('31', 387, 2, 9, 890353) I have known many instances of more money than was necessary having been spent on the comforts of workers.
('31', 387, 2, 10, 890460) This practice is very much less prevalent now, but I must admit that there is still room for reform.
('31', 387, 2, 11, 890561) There is certainly some substance in the complaint that ex penses on conveyance are incurred much too readily.
('31', 387, 2, 12, 890672) We now wish to serve the poorest of the poor and to be their representatives.
('31', 387, 2, 13, 890750) I have no doubt, therefore, that there should be much greater simplicity in our lives than there is at present.
('31', 387, 2, 14, 890862) A carriage must not be hired so long as one can walk the distance.
('31', 387, 2, 15, 890929) Public workers arriving as one’s guests need not be treated to banquets.
('31', 387, 2, 16, 891002) Workers come together not to enjoy dinners but to render service.
('31', 387, 2, 17, 891068) I have not understood what the correspondent has in mind in the veiled reference he has made to the subject of association with women.
('31', 387, 2, 18, 891203) The point did not become clear to me even after I had read the whole letter.
('31', 387, 2, 19, 891280) But one can guess a little from the analogy the writer has used.
('31', 387, 2, 20, 891345) I have no doubt that seeking women’s company for its own sake is sinful and reprehensive.
('31', 387, 2, 21, 891435) Workers who are guilty of this can render little service to the people.
('31', 387, 2, 22, 891507) But association with women in the ordinary course of public work is unavoidable and, therefore, to be accepted.
('31', 387, 2, 23, 891619) We have kept women very much suppressed.
('31', 387, 2, 24, 891660) They have lost their womanhood.
('31', 387, 2, 25, 891692) A woman has a right to go out of her home in order to serve, it is her duty to do so.

('31', 387, 2, 27, 891911) This seems to me quite a normal situation.

('31', 400, 1, 2, 920446) CART AND CHARKHA During my tour in Bengal, I meet with all kinds of ingenious arguments against the wheel from the ingenious Bengalis.
('31', 400, 1, 3, 920581) Most of them have been examined in these pages.
('31', 400, 1, 4, 920629) But as readers never remember what they read in journalistic literature, a journalist is always safe in repeating the same thing so long as perhaps he takes care to repeat at fair intervals.
('31', 400, 1, 5, 920820) One of these friends asked me whether I propose to replace the railways with country carts, and if I did not, how I expected to replace mills with wheels.
('31', 400, 1, 6, 920975) I told him that I did not propose to replace railways with carts, because I could not do so even if I wished.
('31', 400, 1, 7, 921085) Three hundred million carts could not destroy distance.
('31', 400, 1, 8, 921141) But I could replace mills with wheels.
('31', 400, 1, 9, 921180) For railways solved the question of speed.
('31', 400, 1, 10, 921223) With mills it was a question of production in which the wheel could easily compete if there were enough hands to work as there were in India.
('31', 400, 1, 11, 921365) I told him that as a matter of fact a villager could manufacture for himself sufficient cloth cheaper than mills if he did not count the value of his labour.
('31', 400, 1, 12, 921523) And he did not need to do so as he would spin or even weave during his spare hours.
('31', 400, 1, 13, 921607) It is remarkable how false or incomplete analogies deceive people.
('31', 400, 1, 14, 921674) In the case in point, the difference between mills and railways on the one hand and wheels and country carts on the other, is so obvious that the comparison should never have been made.
('31', 400, 1, 15, 921860) But probably the friend thought I was against all machinery in every conceivable circumstance.
('31', 400, 1, 16, 921955) Probably he had in mind my objections to railways stated in my Indian Home Rule though I have repeatedly said that I am not working out the different fundamental problems raised in that booklet.
('31', 400, 1, 17, 922150) WASTE OF EFFORT?
('31', 400, 1, 18, 922167) Another argument advanced was that the spinning wheel was a waste of effort.
('31', 400, 1, 19, 922244) It was an astounding argument advanced without any thought given to it.
('31', 400, 1, 20, 922316) I showed that anything done with a purpose could not be regarded as waste of effort.
('31', 400, 1, 21, 922401) The spinning wheel was presented to the nation for giving occupation to the millions who had, at least, for four months in the year, nothing to do.
('31', 400, 1, 22, 922549) I told the objector, too, that seeing that the wheel produced at least 100 yards of yarn per every half hour it could not be regarded as waste of effort.
('31', 400, 1, 23, 922703) Moreover, it not only was not a waste of effort, but a sound economic proposition.
('31', 400, 1, 24, 922786) For, what was required for the millions was a universal productive occupation which could be taken up during odd moments and which did not require any special talent or long course of training to learn.
('31', 400, 1, 25, 922989) Such an occupation was only hand spinning and no other.
('31', 400, 2, 26, 923045) RISE AND FALL The District of Noakhali is a promising centre of khaddar work.
('31', 401, 0, 1, 923123) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 401, 1, 2, 923165) It had evidently much work to its credit when the khaddar movement first started.
('31', 401, 1, 3, 923247) The following report of its rise and fall, handed to me at Noakhali, cannot fail to be of general interest : 1
('31', 401, 2, 4, 923358) The moral is obvious.
('31', 401, 2, 5, 923380) Workers must not lose heart.
('31', 401, 2, 6, 923409) They must continue their work in the face of all odds even as a re sourceful merchant does.
('31', 401, 2, 7, 923501) Till khaddar becomes current coin, we must become voluntary merchants, not for personal but for the country’s gain.
('31', 401, 2, 8, 923617) Khaddar work must be above the shifting party politics of the Congress.
('31', 401, 2, 9, 923689) It may change its programme fifty times but never its programme of the charkha and khaddar, on which depends the fortune of the poor and dumb millions.
('31', 401, 2, 10, 923841) FALLEN SISTERS SPINNING At Noakhali, I was told that two fallen sisters were not only spinning, but that they were entirely supporting themselves by spinning.
('31', 401, 2, 11, 924000) These were not young girls but women over forty who could no longer sell their shame but who would, but for spinning, have lived on begging.
('31', 401, 2, 12, 924141) They were, therefore, strictly speaking, weaned from begging and not from their original trade.
('31', 401, 2, 13, 924237) It is, however, a great thing for Noakhali to come in touch with these sisters and interest itself in their welfare.
('31', 401, 2, 14, 924354) I was also told that some of them, though they had not given up their calling, had taken to spinning.
('31', 401, 2, 15, 924456) I do not know if it could be considered a gain for such sisters to spin if they would not give up their calling.
('31', 401, 2, 16, 924569) It may well be used to cover their shame.
('31', 401, 2, 17, 924611) At the same time there is no doubt that spinning could not be recommended to them as a means of livelihood.

('31', 409, 4, 23, 943729) SANTINIKETAN, Jeth Sud 7 [May 30, 1925] 1
('31', 409, 5, 24, 943771) JAMNALAL, I have your letter.
('31', 409, 5, 25, 943801) I had put off writing to you as I thought you would be coming for the Committee meeting and we would then talk about everything personally.
('31', 409, 5, 26, 943941) I was not at all worried that you did not come.
('31', 409, 5, 27, 943989) I had inferred from Girdhari’s letter that you would definitely come.
('31', 409, 5, 28, 944059) I am constantly on the look out for someone or other for the College 2; but none has appealed to me.
('31', 409, 5, 29, 944160) If Jugalkishore 3 comes, it would in a way solve the problem.
('31', 409, 5, 30, 944222) He is without doubt a man of character.
('31', 409, 5, 31, 944262) From his letters to Gidwani, I am not fully satisfied.
('31', 409, 5, 32, 944317) If Gidwani thinks of coming and can come, it would be all right.
('31', 409, 5, 33, 944382) For the present there is none else I can think of.
('31', 409, 5, 34, 944433) I always think that it would be better if we found someone from the South.

('31', 411, 0, 1, 946701) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 411, 1, 2, 946743) 254. INTERVIEW WITH RABINDRANATH TAGORE 1
('31', 411, 2, 3, 946785) May 30, 1925
('31', 411, 3, 4, 946798) Mr. Gandhi explained very carefully his own meaning, showing that he did not believe in the sub divisions of castes of modern days, but believed that the division into the main vocational castes was scientifically correct.
('31', 411, 3, 5, 947021) But he did believe in a vocational division of manhood in which there was no question of inferior or superior but rather of different functions being performed in the body corporate of humanity.
('31', 411, 4, 6, 947216) The Poet doubted if even such vocational divisions, when perpetuated, led to anything else but sterility in the long run.
('31', 411, 4, 7, 947338) The Poet contended that to make this depend on birth was unscientific and unnatural because in mankind nature aimed at variety and personal choice and freedom.
('31', 411, 5, 8, 947498) Mr. Gandhi again explained with great earnestness and elaboration his own
('31', 411, 6, 9, 947572) position.
('31', 411, 6, 10, 947582) In the end the Poet asked him to explain at length his charkha and khaddar
('31', 411, 7, 11, 947657) programme.
('31', 411, 8, 12, 947668) Mr. Gandhi described his own experience in East Bengal, and how the revival of spinning had already put new life into the villages there.
('31', 411, 8, 13, 947806) The Poet was evidently deeply impressed because his own heart has ever been touched by the sufferings of the villagers.
('31', 411, 8, 14, 947926) Mr. Gandhi explained clearly that he did not wish the educated classes to do anything else, except to spin for a very limited time every day, in order to represent in a living way, their sympathy with the poor and the oppressed, and the brotherhood of man.
('31', 411, 8, 15, 948183) He asked the Poet for his own invaluable help in the great enterprise which he had undertaken.
('31', 411, 8, 16, 948278) After the most cordial greeting the interview came to a close.
('31', 411, 9, 17, 948341) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 2 6 1925

('31', 413, 1, 2, 951616) is, as a holiday.
('31', 413, 1, 3, 951634) This practice does not reduce the output of work.
('31', 413, 1, 4, 951684) On the contrary, the common experience is that the work is done better and better.
('31', 413, 1, 5, 951767) A friend from Bombay, who thinks that it would be good if private firms in India followed this practice and observed one day in the week as holiday, writes : 1
('31', 413, 2, 6, 951927) I do not know whether anyone will attach weight to my advice.
('31', 413, 2, 7, 951989) But I fully support this suggestion.
('31', 413, 2, 8, 952026) I have no doubt at all that if the mer chants take time off and allow the same privilege to their employees, even at the risk of less work and less income in a month, both the merchants and their assistants would benefit in a number of ways.
('31', 413, 2, 9, 952268) The Government departments do observe Sunday as a holiday, but we cannot say that the people have lost anything thereby.
('31', 413, 2, 10, 952389) English firms are closed every Sunday, but we do not know of any loss suffered by them on that account.
('31', 413, 2, 11, 952493) I have not heard of big profits made by shops which remain open from morning and do business till late in the evening, with the help of lights.
('31', 413, 2, 12, 952637) The disadvantages of the practice are obvious enough.
('31', 413, 2, 13, 952691) Neither the shopkeeper nor his assistants get even breathing time.
('31', 413, 2, 14, 952758) Those who spend almost their whole day in the shop and are at home only when they eat and sleep cannot be regarded as house holders but should be looked upon as living in their shops.
('31', 413, 2, 15, 952942) They cannot look after their children, let alone give them their company.
('31', 413, 2, 16, 953016) Moreover, they must have medicines daily to keep them healthy.
('31', 413, 2, 17, 953079) The assistants are in a worse plight still.
('31', 413, 2, 18, 953123) The proprietor attends the shop of his own free will and it is, therefore, natural that he may be able to take interest in the work then.
('31', 413, 2, 19, 953261) He may even absent himself if he so desires.
('31', 413, 2, 20, 953306) An assistant passes the whole day thinking “When shall I be able to leave?” No wonder, in these circumstances, he does not keep good health.
('31', 413, 2, 21, 953447) Instead of this, if he gets a Sunday or any other day as an off day every week and if he has to work only for a fixed number of hours every day, he would remain contented and be more ready to regard his employer’s work as his own.
('31', 413, 2, 22, 953678) Many reforms like these do not come about because no one is wil ling to take the lead.
('31', 413, 2, 23, 953765) Even if one trader from among many gives the lead, the other traders will follow suit.
('31', 413, 2, 24, 953852) If shop assistants, too, think about the matter with some sense of responsibility and place a plan or proposal respectfully before their employers, there is a chance of its being accepted.

('31', 414, 1, 2, 954302) FRANCHISE REDUCED TO MOCKERY A volunteer gives expression to his feelings as follows : 1
('31', 414, 2, 3, 954391) I have deliberately refrained from giving the name of the village or the taluka.
('31', 414, 2, 4, 954472) It is in Gujarat.
('31', 414, 2, 5, 954490) I state this lest someone should think that I have translated a Hindi or English letter.
('31', 414, 2, 6, 954579) Since I am always outside Gujarat, touring, I only see from a distance the bright side of things.
('31', 414, 2, 7, 954677) I had been telling myself that the 2,000 voters in Gujarat were hundred per cent sincere.
('31', 414, 2, 8, 954767) And now I have the above letter.
('31', 414, 2, 9, 954800) I assume that the facts as reported in the letter above are true; and since generally it happens that what is true in one place will also be true in other places, how if the same state of affairs obtains elsewhere?
('31', 414, 2, 10, 955015) If it does, we shall have frankly to admit the fact.
('31', 414, 2, 11, 955068) Gujarat will shine with two instead of 2,000 such spinner voters, but two lakhs of papersoldiers in place of 20,000 will be of no service.
('31', 414, 2, 12, 955207) Necessary facilities should certainly be provided but, even in spite of them and in spite of our appeals, if people are not willing to spin and give yarn, we cannot force them to do so and need not maintain their names on muster.
('31', 414, 2, 13, 955437) What would then happen to the franchise clause?
('31', 414, 2, 14, 955485) As long as I attach importance to spinning and visualize no improvement in India’s economic condition without it, I shall stick to it as the qualification for the franchise.
('31', 414, 2, 15, 955659) Mine is the beautiful condition of the mother who hugs her child more closely to her bosom the more the others dislike and slight it.
('31', 414, 2, 16, 955793) As others’ ill opinion does not make a mother doubt the value or promise of her child, I too cannot entertain any doubt about the value of the franchise qualification or about the beneficial results likely to follow from the adoption of spinning.
('31', 414, 2, 17, 956040) I will, therefore, cling to the spinning wheel and advise my co workers to do likewise.
('31', 414, 2, 18, 956128) It is also my view that we should see that spinning for social benefit does not prove costly instead of helping to make khadi less costly, that we need not flatter anyone too much and provide facilities which are expensive.
('31', 414, 2, 19, 956352) If the cost of inducing others to go on spinning is greater than that of the yarn produced, such spinning serves no useful purpose.
('31', 414, 2, 20, 956484) For that means that in inducing someone to spin, we give him something instead of receiving something from him.
('31', 414, 2, 21, 956596) This kind of business means bankruptcy.
('31', 414, 2, 22, 956636) It does not bring the benefit which spinning is supposed to do.

('31', 415, 2, 5, 957378) 256. ENTERING VILLAGES Wherever I go I observe more suffering than happiness and also discover that we ourselves are the cause of that suffering.
('31', 415, 2, 6, 957524) Most of the welcome addresses which I received in Bengal mentioned the ravages of Kalaazar and other diseases.
('31', 415, 2, 7, 957635) The workers in Bengal have responded admirably to my appeal.
('31', 415, 2, 8, 957696) I had asked that welcome addresses should contain information about the people’s condition rather than praise of me.
('31', 415, 2, 9, 957813) I find my suggestion fully acted upon in most welcome addresses and I have by now plenty of information.
('31', 415, 2, 10, 957918) In some places the population is dwindling because the people have been dying of various diseases.
('31', 415, 2, 11, 958017) Now to the diseases of the body has been added the curse of a plant called water hyacinth, that plays havoc with cereal crops.
('31', 415, 2, 12, 958144) I do not know its Indian name.
('31', 415, 2, 13, 958175) It is said that some person unwittingly brought it from the West.
('31', 415, 2, 14, 958241) From wherever it was introduced, it is to be seen stretching for miles in the waters of the Padma river.
('31', 415, 2, 15, 958346) This plant destroys cereal crops.
('31', 415, 2, 16, 958380) Wherever it is seen growing, the paddy crops in the fields on the banks of the river in those parts have been almost completely destroyed.
('31', 415, 2, 17, 958519) The Government has of course launched measures to destroy this poisonous weed, but so far none of them is known to have proved effective.
('31', 415, 2, 18, 958657) Who will help regions suffering from such hardships?
('31', 415, 2, 19, 958710) And how?
('31', 415, 2, 20, 958719) Without knowing the problems of villages, no remedies can be devised.
('31', 415, 2, 21, 958789) The condition will improve only when the prevailing state of ignorance in rural areas is replaced by the light of knowledge.
('31', 415, 2, 22, 958914) The people do not know the rules of healthy living.
('31', 415, 2, 23, 958966) They bathe in and drink from the same tank in which they clean their bodies, scrub utensils and from which cattle drink.
('31', 415, 2, 24, 959087) It simply does not occur to anyone to drain away stagnant water from marshy swamps by means of a shallow canal; even if it does, it is nobody’s job and, therefore, no one does it.
('31', 415, 2, 25, 959267) The people are too poor to afford wholesome and nutritious food, which they need, let alone being able to pay for medicines.
('31', 415, 2, 26, 959392) Villagers, it is assumed, do not require change of air.
('31', 416, 0, 1, 959448) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 417
('31', 416, 1, 2, 959490) Some customs too are so cruel that they kill both the body and the soul.
('31', 416, 1, 3, 959563) Girls of very tender age are married off!
('31', 416, 1, 4, 959605) A girl of 13 becomes a mother!
('31', 416, 1, 5, 959636) A seven year old girl becomes a widow!
('31', 416, 1, 6, 959675) Some of them do not know their husbands.
('31', 416, 1, 7, 959716) How can a seven year old girl know what a husband is?
('31', 416, 1, 8, 959770) Should we look to the Government for a remedy for this?
('31', 416, 1, 9, 959826) Will a cure for these customs be found when we have swaraj; is it not, rather, that swaraj will never come till we find a cure for them?
('31', 416, 1, 10, 959963) There is, of course, one easy remedy.
('31', 416, 1, 11, 960001) The educated classes should, in a spirit of humble service, go into villages and study the condition of the people.
('31', 416, 1, 12, 960117) In doing so, many will fall ill and many will die.
('31', 416, 1, 13, 960168) We shall find the remedy when we have learnt to bear all this.
('31', 416, 1, 14, 960231) It is only then that the people will understand and adopt the remedy that has been found.
('31', 416, 1, 15, 960321) I certainly believe it will be difficult, if not impos sible, to convince people with arguments addressed to their reason.
('31', 416, 1, 16, 960444) The people will understand only through their heart, and they alone can speak through their hearts who have won the people’s confidence through service, love and sacrifice.
('31', 416, 1, 17, 960617) We shall find it written on every page of the history of the world, and especially of the history of India, that the people are guided by their emotions and that reason is helpless before them.
('31', 416, 1, 18, 960811) May it be that the heart always takes precedence over reason?
('31', 416, 1, 19, 960873) Can it be that where reason is not purified by the Ganga, the heart is unavailing?
('31', 416, 1, 20, 960956) Ravana’s reason, being untouched by the heart, was of no service to him despite its command of magic, whereas Rama’s, purified by the sacred influences of the heart, easily remained invincible.
('31', 416, 1, 21, 961150) The Deshbandhu says that there can be no swaraj unless the villages are properly organized.
('31', 416, 1, 22, 961242) Others too say the same thing.
('31', 416, 1, 23, 961273) My experiences in Bengal also teach this very lesson, that till we enter the villages we shall never know India.

('31', 416, 2, 25, 961423) 257. SPINNING IN BENGAL The first lap of my tour of Bengal has concluded without any mishap.
('31', 416, 2, 26, 961516) I say “without mishap” because many of my friends had doubts whether my health would be able to stand its strain.
('31', 416, 2, 27, 961630) What I saw in Bengal has surpassed my expectations and inspires hope for the future.
('31', 416, 2, 28, 961715) There are big zamindars here who spin along with members of their families.
('31', 416, 2, 29, 961791) Here I saw in Dinajpur and other places zamindars, lawyers, barristers, untouchables, Hindus and Muslims, all sitting together in big meetings and spinning.
('31', 416, 2, 30, 961948) I saw here in Bengal hundreds
('31', 417, 0, 1, 961978) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 417, 1, 2, 962020) of well to do men and women spinning beautifully.
('31', 417, 1, 3, 962070) They do not spin daily, but the very fact that so many men and women are skilled in spinning and occasionally sit down to spin pleases me.
('31', 417, 1, 4, 962209) I have not seen such skill anywhere else in India.
('31', 417, 1, 5, 962260) What men and women learn with effort elsewhere, I found people doing naturally here.
('31', 417, 1, 6, 962345) Just as people generally have a separate dress for weddings, etc., as also separate dresses for wearing at home and in the office, so also many people have included khadi too in their wardrobe.
('31', 417, 1, 7, 962539) There is hardly any other part of India in which we shall see this.
('31', 417, 1, 8, 962607) Here I did not find a climate of opposition to khadi.
('31', 417, 1, 9, 962661) The No changers and Swarajists both use khadi, some more some less.
('31', 417, 1, 10, 962729) I came across only three persons who said that the spinning wheel would not help, and they too were not leading men.
('31', 417, 1, 11, 962846) Here Moderates and extremists all use khadi a little more or a little less.
('31', 417, 1, 12, 962922) No other province can beat the slivers made here.
('31', 417, 1, 13, 962972) No particles of dust and wool are ever found in them.
('31', 417, 1, 14, 963026) In some places cotton called devkapas is being used for spinning.
('31', 417, 1, 15, 963092) This does not need carding at all, nor ginning.
('31', 417, 1, 16, 963140) The cotton easily comes out when removed with the fingers; it is made into slivers by arranging together the fibre lengths and then spun into the finest yarn.
('31', 417, 1, 17, 963299) Another variety of cotton which is grown in the hills is of a very inferior quality.
('31', 417, 1, 18, 963384) Its fibres are extremely short, and it is not smooth.
('31', 417, 1, 19, 963438) This cotton certainly needs to be carded, but when that is done no particles of dust and wool remain.
('31', 417, 1, 20, 963540) The standard of its carding is inferior but, since the people are accustomed to careful carding, no one does the work in a slipshod manner.
('31', 417, 1, 21, 963680) The yarn too which we see in the market does not contain dust and wool particles.
('31', 417, 1, 22, 963762) It is rarely of a count under ten.

('31', 419, 6, 16, 966445) No one has till now advanced the excuse that he does not have even half an hour to spare.
('31', 419, 6, 17, 966535) The charkha will help us overcome our narrowness.
('31', 419, 6, 18, 966585) Today a North Indian visiting Bengal has to tell others that he is an Indian.
('31', 419, 6, 19, 966663) Bengalis living in other provinces regard themselves as foreigners.
('31', 419, 6, 20, 966731) Similarly, South Indians become foreigners as soon as they set foot in North India.
('31', 419, 6, 21, 966815) The charkha is the only device which makes us all feel that we are children of the same land.
('31', 419, 6, 22, 966909) We have so far accomplished nothing.
('31', 419, 6, 23, 966946) Let us accomplish some little thing at any rate.
('31', 419, 6, 24, 966995) Boycott of foreign cloth is something which all can equally further, towards which all can contribute equally.
('31', 419, 6, 25, 967106) Untouchability hurts Hindus alone; the quarrels between the Hindus and Muslims will also be over some time or other; but if there is no khadi, the whole country will remain sunk in utter poverty.

('31', 420, 2, 5, 967866) 262. INTERVIEW TO DR.
('31', 420, 2, 6, 967888) H. W. B. MORENO
('31', 420, 3, 7, 967904) SANTINIKETAN, May 31, 1925
('31', 420, 4, 8, 967931) The Anglo Indian question was gone into fully with Mahatma Gandhi on his being again interviewed by Dr. H. W. B. Moreno.
('31', 420, 4, 9, 968052) At the outset Dr. Moreno pointed out the difficulties involved in Mr. Gandhi’s advice as to spinning and wearing khaddar; Anglo Indians would find such difficulties insurmountable in adopting this peculiar method of employment even assuming that the arguments in favour of khaddar as advanced by Mr. Gandhi were correct.
('31', 420, 5, 10, 968373) Mr. Gandhi admitted that it was not easy to win over an entire community, such as the Anglo Indians were, to the way of adopting such methods of occupation, but he was prepared to exercise his patience on their behalf.
('31', 420, 5, 11, 968592) He would be satisfied for the present if only the favourable mental attitude was achieved by Anglo Indians as regards his spinning programme.
('31', 420, 5, 12, 968734) Spinning was meant principally to relieve the distress of the suffering masses; spinning was the common bond of union between rich and poor and he would advise even Englishmen, resident in India and eating up the salt of India, to be true to the land of their adoption and to take to spinning.
('31', 420, 6, 13, 969028) Dr. Moreno pointed out that at present Anglo Indians had some definite representation in the Councils, in the Assembly and in other public bodies.
('31', 420, 6, 14, 969175) What would be the fate of this minority community, if swaraj should come in?
('31', 420, 6, 15, 969252) What place would they occupy along with the greater communities of India?
('31', 420, 7, 16, 969326) Mr. Gandhi replied that he could foresee no disastrous consequence if the
('31', 420, 8, 17, 969400) Anglo Indians were to come in, along with the other communities.
('31', 420, 8, 18, 969465) He held that the
('31', 420, 9, 19, 969482) Hindu and Muslim communities should go out of their way and grant Anglo Indians
('31', 420, 10, 20, 969562) even preference in India’s representative institutions, for the simple reason that they
('31', 420, 11, 21, 969650) were minorities and required greater protection.
('31', 420, 11, 22, 969699) I think that I am giving undue preference to it.
('31', 420, 11, 23, 969748) I alone know that I am performing what I consider to be my parental duty towards this child, irrespective of what others may say.
('31', 420, 12, 24, 969878) Dr. Moreno pointed out that Anglo Indians at present, by virtue of long association and by their particular mode of living were eminently suited for the positions they now held in the Railways, in the Customs Service, and in other such
('31', 421, 0, 1, 970114) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 421, 1, 2, 970156) departments of employment in India.
('31', 421, 1, 3, 970192) Did “Indianization” mean the taking away of these posts from Anglo Indians and giving them to Indians?
('31', 421, 1, 4, 970295) That was a grave foreboding the Anglo Indian had in his mind, now for some time.
('31', 421, 2, 5, 970376) Mr. Gandhi replied that the great test for all service should be efficiency.
('31', 421, 2, 6, 970453) If Anglo Indians were suited for such posts, by all means let them retain them for some time to come.
('31', 421, 2, 7, 970555) When Indians would in time qualify for these posts, on the grounds of efficiency, they could not be restricted from holding them, but by that time there might be other avenues of employment that could be open for Anglo Indians.
('31', 421, 2, 8, 970783) He did not want a levelling down so far as the communities of India were concerned, it should be a levelling up.
('31', 421, 2, 9, 970896) He preferred to go in a railway carriage which was propelled by a locomotive driver of a qualified European or Anglo Indian type, such as now were to be seen, rather then have an indifferent Indian driver at the engine.
('31', 421, 3, 10, 971116) Dr. Moreno touched on the woeful condition of Anglo Indian education and referred to the attempts sometimes made in the Legislative Councils to cut down the grants for European education, on the grounds that they were too liberal as compared to the educational grants given to other communities and the taking away of them meant social ruin for the community in the near future.
('31', 421, 3, 11, 971495) Mr. Gandhi said : There lies the mistake.
('31', 421, 3, 12, 971537) I should go out of my way to placate Anglo Indians because they are in the minority and need special protection.
('31', 421, 3, 13, 971650) When the riots broke out in Bombay in which Anglo Indians and Parsis alike were brutally assaulted, I spoke words of fire to my Indian brethren.
('31', 421, 3, 14, 971795) In the unity of all parties in India, I always refer to and include Anglo Indians, Parsis, Jews, and so forth; without these there could be no unity, except the tyranny of the great over the small.
('31', 421, 3, 15, 971993) The greater communities of India, such as the Hindus and Muslims, had solemn obligations to perform towards the lesser communities.
('31', 421, 4, 16, 972125) Referring to the education of Anglo Indians, he would say that it did not improve much their morals, for while travelling he often noticed that Anglo Indians, instead of having the virtues of the European and Indian communities, had the vices of both.
('31', 421, 4, 17, 972377) The worst expressions of abuse in the Indian vocabulary and the vilest words of the English language were mingled in their common speech.
('31', 421, 4, 18, 972515) Such depraved tastes had to be rectified by the Anglo Indians themselves.
('31', 421, 4, 19, 972589) The reason why this still continued with the community was because they isolated themselves and had ceased to assimilate what was best in their neighbours.
('31', 421, 4, 20, 972745) On railway platforms he had even noticed that their physical tastes were becoming depraved; and stealthily they would purchase and consume unnoticed the most unwholesome trash exhibited for sale in the way of foodstuffs.
('31', 421, 4, 21, 972966) The physical taste was an index of the mental taste.
('31', 421, 5, 22, 973019) Dr. Moreno pointed out that it was a patent fact that up to now Anglo Indians had taken little or no interest in Congress activities.
('31', 421, 5, 23, 973153) During the time of Surendranath Banerjea’s leadership of Bengal, Dr. J. R. Wallace, the then leader of the community,
('31', 422, 0, 1, 973271) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 423
('31', 422, 1, 2, 973313) was invited to join the Congress, but when this idea spread in the community Dr. Wallace was ostracized for some time.
('31', 422, 1, 3, 973432) We should welcome you in the Congress.
('31', 422, 1, 4, 973471) Why do you not come in?
('31', 422, 1, 5, 973495) Whose fault is it, if you stand outside?
('31', 422, 1, 6, 973536) I for one would welcome you with outstretched arms, as I would welcome the Jews or Parsis.
('31', 422, 1, 7, 973627) The Congress is no true national institution if it does not embrace all parties.
('31', 422, 1, 8, 973708) As regards the yarn franchise Anglo Indians could get over the difficulty, as others at present did, by purchasing yarn locally and forwarding it on.
('31', 422, 2, 9, 973858) Dr. Moreno said there was a tendency in the community to divide itself into two classes, one leaning towards the European side, the other to the Indian side, but opinions were fast veering round.
('31', 422, 3, 10, 974054) Mr. Gandhi stated that he himself had noted the change of opinion of Anglo Indians towards the idea of classing themselves as Indians.
('31', 422, 3, 11, 974189) He gathered this from his talks with his many Anglo Indian friends.
('31', 422, 3, 12, 974257) He deprecated such a vain expression of sentiment found among certain Anglo Indians based on a mere theorizing of the pigmentation of the skin.
('31', 422, 3, 13, 974401) The real difficulty lies when you consider the poor of your community.
('31', 422, 3, 14, 974472) They are degenerating and are adopting the vices of the lowest classes of Indians, because the breach is becoming wider between them and their more affluent brethren.
('31', 422, 3, 15, 974639) For the richer Anglo Indian there is no communal problem, he is receiving more than he deserves.
('31', 422, 3, 16, 974736) The problem of the poorer classes is the problem for Anglo Indian thinker to solve.
('31', 422, 3, 17, 974820) We have our problem of the untouchables.
('31', 422, 3, 18, 974861) You have the same problem in another form.
('31', 422, 4, 19, 974904) He decried the false mode of existence adopted by an Anglo Indian railway station master in South India whose friendship he enjoyed.
('31', 422, 4, 20, 975037) After twenty years of service this man secured a salary of Rs. 300 a month, but as he had to live up to European standards he could not save a pice after providing for the wants of his wife and his four children and giving the family the advantages of a suitable education.
('31', 422, 4, 21, 975311) This Anglo Indian had told him that he was forced to maintain such a standard of existence, although he felt it was ruinous, simply because he knew that if he adopted any other standard, his future promotion in the railway would cease for all time.
('31', 422, 5, 22, 975560) Dr. Moreno said that he was but voicing some of the difficulties the community laboured under and sought Mr. Gandhi’s advice as a true friend of India.
('31', 422, 5, 23, 975712) His community was a community of the soil and had permanent interests in the country.
('31', 422, 6, 24, 975798) Mr. Gandhi said in reply that he appreciated such sentiments.
('31', 422, 6, 25, 975860) The abid ing interest of the Anglo Indian community was eulogized by all Indians alike.
('31', 422, 6, 26, 975948) There was little to separate the Anglo Indian from the Indian.
('31', 422, 6, 27, 976011) He was glad that Dr. Moreno had so freely talked the matter over with him.
('31', 422, 6, 28, 976086) He had seen many other Anglo Indians as well in his travels all over the country.
('31', 422, 6, 29, 976168) They came and sought his advice from time to
('31', 423, 0, 1, 976213) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 423, 1, 2, 976255) time; scores of such Anglo Indians came to see him privately and consulted him on all communal affairs, but though they admitted the justice of his arguments, they failed to carry them out into practice.
('31', 423, 1, 3, 976459) They lacked the moral courage of action.
('31', 423, 1, 4, 976500) He advised Dr. Moreno not to slacken in his mission in life, which was the only policy of future salvation to the community.
('31', 423, 1, 5, 976625) He asked him not to be disconcerted by the criticisms and think and move in narrow circles.
('31', 423, 1, 6, 976717) The intelligentsia of Bengal and the toiling masses of the country was a case in point.
('31', 423, 2, 7, 976805) At the conclusion of the interview Dr. Moreno asked Mr. Gandhi to allow him to ask a series of set questions affecting the Anglo Indian community in Mr. Gandhi’s paper, with a view to securing studied answers on the issues involved.
('31', 423, 2, 8, 977038) Mr. Gandhi said : I shall welcome such questions as a friend of your community, as indeed of all those who are born or resident in India.
('31', 423, 2, 9, 977176) I shall be glad to do what I can do to clear the issue so that we may have a better vision of the future.
('31', 423, 2, 10, 977282) After all, we are both working for a common purpose : the uplift of India, your country and mine.
('31', 423, 3, 11, 977380) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 2 6 1925

('31', 424, 7, 10, 978027) 265. LETTER TO S. A. VAZE 1
('31', 424, 8, 11, 978055) SANTINIKETAN, June 1, 1925 I have carefully gone through your memorandum 2. It is very valu able and closely reasoned.
('31', 424, 8, 12, 978174) But there is a chance of its being understood to mean that you will favour if there was to be a choice legislative discrimination.
('31', 424, 8, 13, 978305) So far as I can see, you will make no such choice.
('31', 424, 8, 14, 978356) A statute is a difficult thing to amend.
('31', 424, 8, 15, 978397) A regulation or mere practice without regulation can be easily varied.
('31', 424, 8, 16, 978468) Only some of us can become judges, but how would we relish the idea of a whole class being statutorily excluded?
('31', 424, 8, 17, 978581) The proposed legal bar would not affect perhaps a single Asiatic.
('31', 424, 8, 18, 978647) Nevertheless it must be resisted.
('31', 424, 8, 19, 978681) The formula is : no legal bar and no stiffening of the administrative distinction, but on the contrary a relaxation of administrative inequality.
('31', 424, 8, 20, 978827) I know all the parties on the stage.
('31', 424, 8, 21, 978864) In spite of the proverbial slimness of Smuts, he is more equitable than Hertzog or Beyer or Cresswell.
('31', 424, 8, 22, 978967) I tell you these things merely to help you to make your position clearer.
('31', 424, 8, 23, 979041) If, however, you are of opinion that in any event if discrimination has to be made, it must be solidified into legislation, I have nothing to say.
('31', 424, 9, 24, 979188) 1 Secretary, Imperial Citizenship Association and member, Servants of India Society; worked for the benefit of Indians living abroad 2 This is not available.

('31', 425, 5, 8, 979686) 266. SPEECH AT BHOWANIPUR, CALCUTTA 1
('31', 425, 6, 9, 979724) June 2, 1925
('31', 425, 7, 10, 979737) Mr. Gandhi said that the spinning wheel was near to his heart and he was glad to learn that it had found a place in the curriculum of the National School.
('31', 425, 7, 11, 979892) He hoped that boys would apply themselves to it and become expert spinners.
('31', 425, 7, 12, 979968) He expected every man, woman and child, who felt for the masses, to ply the charkha for at least half an hour a day.
('31', 425, 7, 13, 980085) Mr. Gandhi declared that the charkha was the one visible link between the masses and the classes.
('31', 425, 8, 14, 980183) Mr. Gandhi also dwelt on untouchability and Hindu Muslim unity.
('31', 425, 8, 15, 980247) The Hindu, 4 6 1925
('31', 425, 9, 16, 980267) 267. VYKOM The public must not be allowed to forget the Vaikom struggle.
('31', 425, 9, 17, 980340) 2 Let them understand that the satyagrahis are, at the present moment, undergoing a higher form of discipline than they were doing before.
('31', 425, 9, 18, 980479) Formerly they were plying their wheels in front of a physical obstacle to their further progress.
('31', 425, 9, 19, 980577) It was barred by a barricade guarded by the police.
('31', 425, 9, 20, 980629) Now, as the reader is aware, the barricade has been removed, the guard withdrawn and so is the notice of prohibition.
('31', 425, 9, 21, 980747) The satyagrahis are, therefore, voluntarily submitting to the self imposed moral restraint, no doubt, in the clearly expressed hope that the savarna Hindus directly concerned will relent and that the Government will themselves make an early declaration that the roads are open to the so called unapproachables as they are to every other human being and even to cats and dogs.
('31', 425, 9, 22, 981123) The Hindu Government of Travancore owes the suppressed classes a double duty, the one that every humane government owes to suppressed humanity under its care, and the other, a Hindu Government owes to Hinduism, that the
('31', 425, 10, 23, 981343) 1 Gandhiji was presented with addresses on behalf of the National School and Sevak Samiti at Bhowanipur in South Calcutta.
('31', 425, 10, 24, 981466) 2 Ezhavas and other backward class Hindus were not allowed access to a temple and the roads leading to it at Vykom (also spelt as Vaikom) in Travancore, now a part of Kerala State.
('31', 425, 10, 25, 981647) Satyagraha was organized against this discrimination in 1924
('31', 426, 0, 1, 981708) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 427
('31', 426, 1, 2, 981750) State will lend no countenance to an inhuman superstition that has crept into Hinduism.
('31', 426, 1, 3, 981838) So far for the State.
('31', 426, 1, 4, 981860) The savarna Hindus of Travancore promised, and they owe it to themselves without the necessity of any promise to me, that they would not allow any rest to the Government till the roads in question were thrown open to the ‘unapproachables’.
('31', 426, 1, 5, 982100) They assured me that they would hold meetings throughout Travancore showing clearly to the Government that they regarded the prohibition as inconsistent with Hinduism and intolerable.
('31', 426, 1, 6, 982284) Besides holding public meetings, they were to promote a monster petition signed by savarna Hindus demanding the opening of the roads.
('31', 426, 1, 7, 982418) I wonder if those gentlemen who gave me the assurance are keeping their promise?
('31', 426, 1, 8, 982499) And now for the ‘unapproachables’ miscalled.
('31', 426, 1, 9, 982544) I understand that they are getting restive.
('31', 426, 1, 10, 982588) They have a right to do so.
('31', 426, 1, 11, 982616) I am further told that they are losing faith in satyagraha.
('31', 426, 1, 12, 982676) If so, their want of faith betrays ignorance of the working of satyagraha.
('31', 426, 1, 13, 982751) It is a force that works silently and apparently slowly.
('31', 426, 1, 14, 982808) In reality, there is no force in the world that is so direct or so swift in working.
('31', 426, 1, 15, 982893) But sometimes apparent success is more quickly attained by brute force.
('31', 426, 1, 16, 982965) To earn one’s living by body labour is a method of earning if by satyagraha.
('31', 426, 1, 17, 983042) A gamble on the stock exchange or house breaking, either of which is the reverse of satyagraha, may apparently lead to an instantaneous acquisition of wealth.
('31', 426, 1, 18, 983201) But the world has by now, I presume, realized that house breaking and gambling are no methods of earning one’s livelihood and that they do harm rather than good to the gambler or the thief.
('31', 426, 1, 19, 983391) The ‘unapproachables’ may force their way by engaging in a free fight with the superstitious savarnas but they will not have reformed Hinduism.
('31', 426, 1, 20, 983535) Theirs will be a method of forcible conversion.
('31', 426, 1, 21, 983583) But I am further told that some of them even threaten to seek shelter in Christianity, Islam or Buddhism if relief is not coming soon.
('31', 426, 1, 22, 983718) Those who use the threat do not, in my humble opinion, know the meaning of religion.
('31', 426, 1, 23, 983803) Religion is a matter of life and death.
('31', 426, 1, 24, 983843) A man does not change religion as he changes his garments.
('31', 426, 1, 25, 983902) He takes it with him beyond the grave.
('31', 426, 1, 26, 983941) Nor does a man profess his religion to oblige others.
('31', 426, 1, 27, 983995) He professes a religion because he cannot do otherwise.
('31', 426, 1, 28, 984051) A faithful husband loves his wife as he would love no other woman.
('31', 426, 1, 29, 984118) Even her faithlessness would not wean him from his faith.
('31', 426, 1, 30, 984176) The bond is more than blood relationship.
('31', 426, 1, 31, 984218) So is the religious bond if it is worth anything.
('31', 426, 1, 32, 984268) It is a matter of the heart.
('31', 426, 1, 33, 984297) An untouchable who lives his Hinduism in the face of persecution at the hands of those Hindus who arrogate to themselves a superior status is a better Hindu than the self styled superior Hindu who, by the very act of claiming superiority,
('31', 427, 0, 1, 984536) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 427, 1, 2, 984578) denies his Hinduism.
('31', 427, 1, 3, 984599) Therefore, those who threaten to renounce Hinduism are, in my opinion, betraying their faith.
('31', 427, 1, 4, 984693) But the satyagrahi’s course is plain.
('31', 427, 1, 5, 984731) He must stand unmoved in the midst of all these cross currents.

('31', 436, 0, 1, 1008932) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 437
('31', 436, 1, 2, 1008974) successful manner in which he demonstrated the efficacy of the Charkha as an instrument of relief and an insurance against future distress.
('31', 436, 1, 3, 1009114) If the villagers were well instructed in the methods of dealing with floods and famine and were also accustomed to an occupation besides agriculture which is impossible in times of flood or famines, much time, money and labour that are generally required on such occasions could be saved.
('31', 436, 1, 4, 1009403) When people are taught at such times to depend upon charity for their sustenance, they lose their self respect and also the use of their limbs.
('31', 436, 1, 5, 1009547) Demoralization then sets in and at last such people are reduced to a state worse than that of mere lower animals.

('31', 436, 1, 7, 1009710) The former are dead to life.
