('31', 451, 1, 2, 1045750) 279. KHADI IN KATHIAWAR
('31', 451, 2, 3, 1045774) From the letters I receive from Kathiawar I find that those who had undertaken to enlist farmers and members of poor classes who would spin by hand seem to have succeeded.
('31', 451, 2, 4, 1045946) Devchandbhai 1 is very hopeful about this.
('31', 451, 2, 5, 1045989) It seems the workers are succeeding in finding such families without much effort.
('31', 451, 2, 6, 1046071) Devchandbhai believes that many more families would come forward [for spinning] if we had more workers and were in a position to supply more slivers at half price.
('31', 451, 2, 7, 1046235) But the question is whether it would be better to serve the families we have already enlisted or to welcome more families than we had provided for and meet their needs.
('31', 451, 2, 8, 1046404) Serving these families means strengthening the intermediate agencies, improving the spinning wheel and helping the families to improve the quality of spinning and teaching them carding, etc.
('31', 451, 2, 9, 1046595) I cannot offer, and hold that I have no right to offer, any advice from this distance.
('31', 451, 2, 10, 1046682) I consider it dangerous to give advice without regard to the changing circumstances.
('31', 451, 2, 11, 1046767) I, therefore, wish to place before the workers my experiences in Bengal.
('31', 451, 2, 12, 1046840) I find here that hardly at any place do they supply slivers [to the spinners].
('31', 451, 2, 13, 1046919) In fact they are supplied nowhere except in Calcutta, instead they supply only cotton.
('31', 451, 2, 14, 1047006) Thousands of women spinners ask only for cotton, which they gin with their own hands.
('31', 451, 2, 15, 1047092) Those who know anything about spinning will see that persons who do the ginning and carding themselves naturally earn more.
('31', 451, 2, 16, 1047216) Anyone who has done these things will know that it is not difficult to attend to all these processes at home.
('31', 451, 2, 17, 1047326) In Bengal people have still not forgotten the old days and, therefore, they readily respond to these ideas.
('31', 451, 2, 18, 1047434) No one can surpass the slivers available in Bengal.
('31', 451, 2, 19, 1047486) One will never find any particle in them.
('31', 451, 2, 20, 1047528) Even if everyone who spins cannot do ginning in his home, why cannot he do carding?
('31', 451, 2, 21, 1047612) The carding instruments here are very simple and hardly cost four to six annas.
('31', 451, 2, 22, 1047692) They moisten a bamboo rod and bend it, and in many cases make the bowstring out of banana fibre.
('31', 451, 2, 23, 1047789) The striker, of course, they never use.
('31', 451, 2, 24, 1047829) Instead, they work with a finger.
('31', 451, 2, 25, 1047863) We may not go so far, it may not even be necessary to do so.
('31', 451, 2, 26, 1047924) But it is certainly necessary for those who are regular spinners to learn carding forthwith.
('31', 451, 2, 27, 1048017) I think it will be difficult to go on supplying slivers for ever.
('31', 451, 2, 28, 1048083) Another thing I observed here is that hardly anyone spins yarn of less than ten counts.
('31', 451, 2, 29, 1048171) The yarn available in the market is mostly of more than ten counts.
('31', 451, 3, 30, 1048239) 1 Devchand Parekh
('31', 452, 0, 1, 1048257) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 453
('31', 452, 1, 2, 1048299) Leaving out devkapas, the cotton here is of an inferior quality to that of our mathia.
('31', 452, 1, 3, 1048386) The implements used on this side are cheaper than ours.
('31', 452, 1, 4, 1048442) I wonder if cheap instruments do no ultimately prove costly.

('31', 453, 3, 7, 1049832) 283. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, JALPAIGURI
('31', 453, 4, 8, 1049874) June 10, 1925
('31', 453, 5, 9, 1049888) Addressing a public meeting Mr. Gandhi requested the merchants and businessmen to utilize their wealth and their business talent for the welfare of India.
('31', 453, 5, 10, 1050043) The educated classes, he said, had exclusively served India up to now.
('31', 453, 5, 11, 1050114) It was now the turn of the mercantile classes and masses to enter the field of constructive work before the country demanded all their business skill and farsightedness which, if they were devoted to the welfare of the country, would result in an annual saving of sixty crores of rupees, exclusion of all foreign cloth and production of khaddar enough to clothe the country.
('31', 453, 5, 12, 1050489) Everyone of seven hundred thousand villages in India was, in the opinion of the speaker, like a spinning and weaving mill thoroughly self contained in the matter of machinery, labour and capital.

('31', 454, 1, 2, 1051604) 285. NOTES ONE MORE RECRUIT The army of my sweet hearts is daily increasing.
('31', 454, 1, 3, 1051681) The princess among them is, of course, Gulnar, my deputy who was to occupy the autocratic chair in my absence as His Majesty’s guest as often as I received the invitation.
('31', 454, 1, 4, 1051853) But the lesser stars are too numerous to mention.
('31', 454, 1, 5, 1051903) The latest recruit is Ranibala of Burdwan, a darling perhaps 10 years old.
('31', 454, 1, 6, 1051978) I dare not ask her age.
('31', 454, 1, 7, 1052002) I was playing with her as usual and casting furtive glances at her six heavy gold bangles.
('31', 454, 1, 8, 1052093) I gently explained to her that they were too heavy a burden on her delicate little wrists and down went her hand on the bangles.
('31', 454, 1, 9, 1052222) “Yes, yes, give up the bangles to Mahatmaji”, said her grandfather, Shyam Babu of the Servant fame.
('31', 454, 1, 10, 1052322) I thought this was generosity at somebody else’s expense.
('31', 454, 1, 11, 1052380) “Oh, you do not know my daughter and my son in law.
('31', 454, 1, 12, 1052432) My daughter will be glad to hear that the girl has given her bangles to you and my son in law can well afford to do without them.
('31', 454, 1, 13, 1052562) He is a most generous hearted man.
('31', 454, 1, 14, 1052597) He helps the poor.” All the while he was speaking, he was helping Ranibala to remove the bangles and encouraging her.
('31', 454, 1, 15, 1052715) I must confess I was embarrassed.
('31', 454, 1, 16, 1052749) I was merely joking as I always do when I see little girls and jokingly create in them a distaste for much ornamentation and a desire to part with their jewellery for the sake of the poor.
('31', 454, 1, 17, 1052938) I tried to return the bangles.
('31', 454, 1, 18, 1052969) But Shyam Babu cut short all such attempt by telling me that her mother would regard it as an ill omen to take back the bangles.
('31', 454, 1, 19, 1053098) I had made known my condition of acceptance, viz., that the girl should not ask for new gold bangles in the place of those given to me.
('31', 454, 1, 20, 1053234) She might have the beautiful snow white conch shell bangles if she liked.
('31', 454, 1, 21, 1053308) The girl and the grandfather accepted the condition.
('31', 454, 1, 22, 1053361) Well, whether the gift was a good omen for the family or not, I do not know.
('31', 454, 1, 23, 1053438) It proved one for the poor and me.
('31', 454, 1, 24, 1053473) For, the example proved contagious and at the ladies’ meeting I addressed at Burdwan I got quite a dozen bangles and two or three pairs of earrings all unasked.
('31', 454, 1, 25, 1053634) Needless to say, these will be utilized for khaddar and charkha prachar 1 in Bengal.
('31', 454, 1, 26, 1053719) I notify to all the young girls and their parents and grand parents that I am open to have as many sweet hearts as would come to me on Ranibala’s terms.
('31', 454, 1, 27, 1053872) They will be handsomer for the thought that they gave their prized ornaments to be used for the service of the poor.

('31', 456, 1, 13, 1057546) SPINNING IN SCHOOLS The brilliant success that has attended the introduction of spinning in the Allahabad Municipal schools has been adverted to in the columns of Young India already.
('31', 456, 1, 14, 1057730) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru now reports :
('31', 456, 2, 15, 1057768) The Municipal Boards of Lucknow, Farrukhabad, Banaras, Cawnpore and Mirzapur, and the District Boards of Jhanshi, Banda, Basti and Azambag have introduced or are introducing spinning in their schools.
('31', 456, 2, 16, 1057969) It appears that many other local boards in U.P. are considering the matter and are communicating with the U.P., P.C.C. in regard to it.
('31', 456, 2, 17, 1058105) I venture to congratulate these municipalities on their lauda ble resolve.
('31', 456, 2, 18, 1058180) A serious obstacle in the way of introducing spinning in its schools that was complained of by the municipal education department of Allahabad, in its report, was the frequency with which the wheels got out of order and want of space.
('31', 456, 2, 19, 1058415) With care ful handling, no spinning wheel need go out of repair.
('31', 456, 2, 20, 1058480) But the complaint about space is a serious handicap in all cities.
('31', 456, 2, 21, 1058547) I commend to the attention of the school authorities the beautiful takli.
('31', 456, 2, 22, 1058621) It is carried in one’s pocket.
('31', 456, 2, 23, 1058652) All the children can work it simultaneously.
('31', 456, 2, 24, 1058697) It can be used anywhere and everywhere.
('31', 456, 2, 25, 1058737) In the Allahabad municipal schools, for instance, there were only 334 wheels for 3,400 boys and girls to work at but of these one half remained idle for want of repair.
('31', 456, 2, 26, 1058906) I am sure that the wheels did not give more than 150 yards per boy or girl per 45 minutes.
('31', 456, 2, 27, 1058997) That means 47,250 yards daily at the most.
('31', 456, 2, 28, 1059040) A takli will not
('31', 457, 0, 1, 1059057) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 457, 1, 2, 1059099) yield more than 30 yards in the same time.
('31', 457, 1, 3, 1059142) But all the 3,400 can work at the same time.
('31', 457, 1, 4, 1059187) Therefore, one would get, through the use of the takli, 10,200 yards per day, i.e., more than double the quantity yielded by the wheels.
('31', 457, 1, 5, 1059324) The takli, therefore, is the best spinning instrument in the long run for schools and such groups.

('31', 457, 3, 10, 1059739) 286. NOT MAN’S WORK?
('31', 457, 3, 11, 1059760) Thus writes a professor :
('31', 457, 4, 12, 1059786) Personally, I have full faith in the spinning wheel and khaddar.
('31', 457, 4, 13, 1059851) I fully understand that without khaddar there can be no common bond between the classes and the masses of India.

('31', 457, 4, 16, 1060202) Khaddar programme must be worked out to a success, if India is to achieve freedom.

('31', 457, 5, 18, 1060343) To ask able bodied men to sit for spinning, like women, is what appears odd in the eyes of most of the people.
('31', 457, 5, 19, 1060454) I quite appreciate the reflection that we, at present, are no better than women.

('31', 457, 5, 21, 1060669) Again, I would have consented to shake off this acquired notion, could I be persuaded to believe that at least the female population of the country have taken up the cause of spinning and that it still requires further support from the male population.
('31', 457, 5, 22, 1060922) To ask men to ply the spinning wheel, while the female folk strut about in fine foreign saris, is putting the cart before the horse.
('31', 457, 5, 23, 1061055) Besides, the question of foreign cloth in India is not so much of men’s creation as of women’s and therefore, I think, to press the use of the spinning wheel and khaddar on men, instead of women, is to begin the solution at the wrong end.
('31', 457, 6, 24, 1061294) In my humble opinion, you should have left men alone, busy with their various sorts of political propagandas and should have taken your message direct to the women of the land.

('31', 459, 2, 7, 1064889) 287. AYURVEDIC SYSTEM Kaviraj Gananath Sen writes :
('31', 459, 3, 8, 1064941) I take this opportunity of drawing your attention to the fact that the speech you delivered when laying the foundation stone of the Ashtanga Ayurveda Vidyalaya 1 has been greatly misconstrued both by the public and by the Ayurvedic physicians of Calcutta.
('31', 459, 3, 9, 1065197) May I suggest that you will kindly explain that you did not mean to condemn Ayurveda itself or its conscientious votaries but only a certain section of them who lived by fraud?
('31', 459, 3, 10, 1065374) To me such an explanation appears to be urgently required in view of the fact that almost all Bengali papers are misinterpreting your speech and condemning us for not contradicting it.
('31', 459, 3, 11, 1065559) I gladly comply with the request, the more so as it enables me to express my views about Ayurvedic medicine.
('31', 459, 3, 12, 1065668) I must say at the outset that I was reluctant to perform the ceremony referred to as I was reluctant even to perform the ceremony of opening the Tibbia College by reason of the views I hold on Medicine in general as expressed in my booklet Indian Home Rule.
('31', 459, 3, 13, 1065926) Seventeen years’ observation has made no material change in them.
('31', 459, 3, 14, 1065992) If I rewrote the book, it is just possible that I should state the views in a different language.
('31', 459, 3, 15, 1066090) But I could no more resist the organizers of my tour than I could a bosom friend like Hakim Saheb.
('31', 459, 3, 16, 1066189) But I told them that my speech might prove embarrassing.
('31', 459, 3, 17, 1066246) Had I been absolutely hostile to the movement, I should, of course, have declined the honour at any cost.
('31', 459, 3, 18, 1066352) But I could reconcile myself to the performance subject to the conditions I named at the meeting.
('31', 459, 3, 19, 1066450) I hope that the college of which I laid the foundation and to which I understand the founder, himself a Kaviraj, had devoted a princely sum, will contribute to the alleviation of real suffering and make discoveries and researches in Ayurveda that will enable the poorest in the land to know and use the simple indigenous drugs and teach people to learn the laws of preventing disease rather than curing them.
('31', 459, 3, 20, 1066859) My quarrel with the medical profession in general is that it ignores the soul altogether and strains at nothing in seeking merely to
('31', 459, 4, 21, 1066992) 1 Vide “Speech at Ashtanga Ayurveda Vidyalaya”, 6 5 1925.
('31', 460, 0, 1, 1067050) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1925 15 JUNE, 1925 461
('31', 460, 1, 2, 1067092) repair such a fragile instrument as the body.
('31', 460, 1, 3, 1067138) Thus ignoring the soul, the profession puts men at its mercy and contributes to the diminution of human dignity and self control.
('31', 460, 1, 4, 1067268) I note with thankfulness that in the West a school of thought is rising slowly but surely which takes count of the soul in trying to repair a diseased body and which, therefore, relies less on drugs and more on nature as a powerful healing agent.
('31', 460, 1, 5, 1067515) My quarrel with the professors of Ayurvedic system is that many of them, if not indeed a vast majority of them, are mere quacks pretending to know much more than they actually do, arrogating to themselves an infallibility and ability to cure all diseases.
('31', 460, 1, 6, 1067771) These gentlemen have no humility in them.
('31', 460, 1, 7, 1067813) They will not study the Ayurvedic system and wrest from it the secrets which appear at present to be completely hidden from the world.
('31', 460, 1, 8, 1067948) They impute to Ayurveda an omnipotence which it does not possess, and in so doing they have made it a stagnant system instead of a gloriously progressive science.
('31', 460, 1, 9, 1068111) I know of not a single discovery or invention of any importance on the part of Ayurvedic physicians as against a brilliant array of discoveries and inventions which Western physicians and surgeons boast.
('31', 460, 1, 10, 1068315) In fact, Ayurvedic physicians’ diagnosis, as a rule, consists in feeling the pulse which, I have known many to claim, enables them to know even whether the patient is suffering from appendicitis.
('31', 460, 1, 11, 1068511) Whether the science of the pulse ever enabled ancient physicians to diagnose every known disease no one can tell.
('31', 460, 1, 12, 1068625) But it is certain that the claim cannot be sustained at the present moment.
('31', 460, 1, 13, 1068701) The only thing Ayurvedic physicians can safely claim is a knowledge of some vegetable and metallic drugs of great potency which some of them succeed in administering for disease they only guess and, therefore, often with much harm to their poor patients.
('31', 460, 1, 14, 1068956) The advertisements of medicine that excite animal passions add immorality to incapacity and make those who resort to these practices a real danger to society.
('31', 460, 1, 15, 1069115) I know of no association of Ayurvedic physicians that protests against or endeavours to check this ceaseless flow of immorality which is sapping Indian manhood and making of many old men monsters living merely to satisfy their lust.
('31', 460, 1, 16, 1069348) Indeed, I have known such physicians enjoying a status of respectability in medical society.
('31', 460, 1, 17, 1069441) Whenever, therefore, I get an opportunity I seize it to drive the truth home to the physicians Ayurvedic and Unani and plead for truth, humility and patient research.
('31', 460, 1, 18, 1069608) I am a lover of all that is ancient and noble.
('31', 460, 1, 19, 1069655) I believe that there was a time when Ayurvedic and Unani medicine served a noble purpose and was progressive.
('31', 460, 1, 20, 1069765) There was a time when I actively helped these physicians and believed in them.
('31', 460, 1, 21, 1069844) But experience has undeceived me.
('31', 460, 1, 22, 1069878) I have been grieved to find arrogance and ignorance among many such physicians.
('31', 460, 1, 23, 1069958) It hurts me to find a
('31', 461, 0, 1, 1069980) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 461, 1, 2, 1070022) noble profession being prostituted for making money.
('31', 461, 1, 3, 1070075) I have written this not to condemn individuals.
('31', 461, 1, 4, 1070123) I have merely reduced to writing the impression that has been left on my mind by a long course of observation of the practice of Ayurvedic physicians.
('31', 461, 1, 5, 1070274) It is no answer to say, as has been said, that Ayurvedic physicians have copied the evils I have named from their Western brethren.
('31', 461, 1, 6, 1070406) A wise man copies not what is bad but that which is good.
('31', 461, 1, 7, 1070464) Let our Kavirajas, Vaidyas and Hakims apply to their calling a scientific spirit that Western physicians show, let them copy the latter’s humility, let them reduce themselves to poverty in investigating the indigenous drugs and let them frankly acknowledge and assimilate that part of Western medicine which they at present do not possess.
('31', 461, 1, 8, 1070804) Let them shun the irreligion of the Western scientists, which, in order to heal the body and in the name of science, subjects the lower animal kingdom to the hideous tortures which pass muster under the name of vivisection.
('31', 461, 1, 9, 1071028) Some will retort that there is warrant for vivisection in Ayurveda.
('31', 461, 1, 10, 1071096) If there is, I am sorry.
('31', 461, 1, 11, 1071121) No warrant even in the four Vedas can sanctify sacrilege.
('31', 461, 1, 12, 1071179) Young India, 11 6 1925

('31', 462, 7, 17, 1073042) 290. SPEECH TO STUDENTS, NAWABGANJ 2
('31', 462, 8, 18, 1073079) June 11, 1925 You all spin and wear khaddar but tell me how many of you always speak the truth and never lie?
('31', 462, 9, 19, 1073189) A few boys raised their hands.
('31', 462, 9, 20, 1073220) Well, now tell me how many of you occasionally happen to lie?
('31', 462, 9, 21, 1073282) Two boys immediately raised their hands, then three, then four and finally, almost all.
('31', 462, 9, 22, 1073370) Thank you, there will be always hope for those of you who know and own that they occasionally lie.
('31', 462, 9, 23, 1073469) The path of those who think they never lie is difficult.
('31', 462, 9, 24, 1073526) I wish both success.
('31', 462, 9, 25, 1073547) Young India, 25 6 1925
('31', 462, 10, 26, 1073570) 291. REMARKS IN VISITORS’ BOOK 3
('31', 462, 11, 27, 1073603) I was much pleased to note that spinning has been compulsory for the past four years.
('31', 462, 11, 28, 1073689) I have read the remarks of the Inspector about
('31', 462, 12, 29, 1073736) 1 From the postmark.
('31', 462, 12, 30, 1073757) The tithi (date) according to Vikram Calendar should be Jeth Vad 5, not Jeth Sud 5.
('31', 462, 13, 31, 1073841) 2 Extracted from Mahadev Desai’s account of Gandhiji’s tour in Bengal 3 This was at the Bijhari School, Upashi, in the Nawabganj District.
('31', 462, 13, 32, 1073980) The school was experimenting with compulsory weaving of khaddar and spinning.
('31', 463, 0, 1, 1074058) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 463, 1, 2, 1074100) failure of spinning.
('31', 463, 1, 3, 1074121) I hold totally contrary views, but I know that it is possible to make spinning absolutely self supporting, if not profitable.
('31', 463, 1, 4, 1074247) To that end I venture to suggest the following : (1) Existing teachers should be induced to learn the art and the science of spinning, on promise of a prize or even a slight increment in pay.
('31', 463, 1, 5, 1074439) (2) The yarn spun by the boys should be always tested and tickets attached giving the strength and count.
('31', 463, 1, 6, 1074545) (3) Boys should be encouraged to improve the quality of their yarn from day to day.
('31', 463, 1, 7, 1074629) (4) Yarn should be sold to the existing spinning organizations, such for instance as Khadi Pratishthan, at agreed prices always above the price of cotton.
('31', 463, 1, 8, 1074784) To this end cotton may be taken from the same organization.
('31', 463, 1, 9, 1074844) (5) Weaving department I do not hold as a necessity, and should be kept up only if the salary of the weaving master is earned from it.
('31', 463, 1, 10, 1074979) I am glad in this connection to have the promise that all foreign or mill yarn will be henceforth dispensed with.
('31', 463, 1, 11, 1075093) (6) Special attention should be paid to carding which the boys must be taught to do for themselves.
('31', 463, 1, 12, 1075193) (7) The charkhas make a great deal of sound foreign to them.
('31', 463, 1, 13, 1075254) This must interfere with good spinning.
('31', 463, 1, 14, 1075294) They can be and should be made noiseless.
('31', 463, 1, 15, 1075336) This is possible only when the spinning master knows the science of spinning which necessarily includes a knowledge of charkha repair.
('31', 463, 1, 16, 1075471) When the charkhas work well, they produce a musical sound which is soothing to the ear.
('31', 463, 1, 17, 1075559) They can be made a positive delight to the boys, besides being a lesson in sacrifice.
('31', 463, 1, 18, 1075645) I congratulate the Committee and staff on their experiment and wish them every success.
('31', 463, 1, 19, 1075733) Young India, 25 6 1925

('31', 465, 4, 10, 1078821) 293. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BHOJESWAR 1
('31', 465, 5, 11, 1078864) June 12, 1925
('31', 465, 6, 12, 1078878) Mahatmaji spoke in Hindi and Badshah Mia translated it in Bengali.
('31', 465, 6, 13, 1078945) Mahatmaji, after thanking them for the address they had given him, said that they had asked him to speak about Congress.
('31', 465, 6, 14, 1079066) He would comply with their expectation.
('31', 465, 6, 15, 1079106) He said that, if they wanted swaraj in Hindusthan, they would have to do three things.
('31', 465, 6, 16, 1079193) Everyone, king or peasant, rich or poor, Hindu or Mussalman, man or woman, would have to spin at least half an hour daily.
('31', 465, 6, 17, 1079316) Everyone should try to bring about Hindu Mussalman unity and to remove untouchability.
('31', 465, 7, 18, 1079403) Mahatmaji did not believe their assertion that there was no untouchability in Bengal as it was in other parts of India.
('31', 465, 7, 19, 1079523) He said that Hindu religion never taught that they should not drink water touched by Namsudras, barbers and washermen.
('31', 465, 8, 20, 1079642) Mahatmaji next advised them to forsake evils.
('31', 465, 8, 21, 1079688) He asked them not to drink, and not to visit the houses of public women.
('31', 465, 9, 22, 1079761) Referring to Congress work, he said that those who thought the Congress to be dead were wrong in their conclusion.
('31', 465, 9, 23, 1079876) Congress was not dead.
('31', 465, 9, 24, 1079899) Its workers had practically died.
('31', 465, 9, 25, 1079933) Hitherto people knew that the Congress work meant speech making and creating excitement.
('31', 465, 9, 26, 1080022) But that was not the real work of this great national organization.
('31', 465, 9, 27, 1080090) The duty of the Congress workers was to serve people and it was the want of that spirit of silent and unostentatious service that had thrown the Congress in the background.
('31', 465, 9, 28, 1080263) He said, as long as there were five real workers in the Congress, it could not die.
('31', 465, 9, 29, 1080347) Congress had no want of work to do as long as one single man of India puts on foreign clothes.
('31', 465, 10, 30, 1080442) Referring to the duties of the Congress workers, Mahatmaji said that millions of Indians were starving.
('31', 465, 10, 31, 1080546) Let them give them the charkha and they would be able to save their brothers.
('31', 465, 11, 32, 1080624) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 16 6 1925

('31', 470, 1, 2, 1089812) 298. VIRTUES OF A VOLUNTEER A volunteer writes as follows : 1
('31', 470, 2, 3, 1089874) It is true that I had once thought of fixing the rate of payment for voluntary workers.
('31', 470, 2, 4, 1089962) I had even discussed the matter with Vallabh bhai 2 and others.
('31', 470, 2, 5, 1090026) But we could not come to any conclusion.
('31', 470, 2, 6, 1090067) We felt at that time, and do so even now, that the ideal of Bengal and Maharashtra is too high for Gujarat.
('31', 470, 2, 7, 1090175) We felt that it would be almost impossible to induce the workers already engaged to accept only ten rupees as honorarium.
('31', 470, 2, 8, 1090297) The situation, as we saw it, was that the country would then lose the services of most workers.
('31', 470, 2, 9, 1090393) Rules can be framed only when certain ideals come to be generally accepted.
('31', 470, 2, 10, 1090469) No rules can be laid down so long as they remain unusual.
('31', 470, 2, 11, 1090527) Gujarat has accepted the ideal of poverty only recently.
('31', 470, 2, 12, 1090584) Maharastra and Bengal accepted it thirty years ago, or even earlier than that, and many young men were trained to live according to it.
('31', 470, 2, 13, 1090720) Very few institutions, therefore, can be run on the basis of the ideal of extreme poverty.
('31', 470, 2, 14, 1090811) In Gujarat we shall have to depend for the present on individual workers.
('31', 470, 2, 15, 1090885) A man who is sincere in his self denial or ideal of self control will not give up his way merely because others do not or cannot follow it.
('31', 470, 2, 16, 1091025) When we have a few Gujaratis who elect to live in extreme poverty and die in the same state, many more will come forward to adopt their way of life.
('31', 470, 2, 17, 1091174) For the present we should accept poverty as the ideal to be reached and act accordingly as far as we can.
('31', 470, 2, 18, 1091280) The most serious obstacle in our path which we have had to face was that of my illness, which prevented me from carrying out fully the experiment of poverty in my own life.
('31', 470, 2, 19, 1091453) I do not at all regard my present experiment as one of living in poverty.
('31', 470, 2, 20, 1091527) Men ascribe the same weaknesses to others which they themselves suffer from.
('31', 470, 2, 21, 1091604) One shivering with cold and covered in several garments believes that the whole world needs all that clothing.
('31', 470, 2, 22, 1091715) One who bathes in hot water pities anyone bathing in cold water.
('31', 470, 2, 23, 1091780) A person who cannot move about without a conveyance wishes that others should also have the same facility.
('31', 470, 2, 24, 1091887) I am in such a pitiable state.
('31', 470, 2, 25, 1091918) I naturally feel that others should get what I eat.
('31', 470, 2, 26, 1091970) I travel by second class, so I hesitate to tell others firmly as I used to that they

('31', 471, 1, 16, 1093710) The two or three unmarried men, who experiment in this way of living do so, we believe, at the cost of considerable suffering to themselves.
('31', 471, 1, 17, 1093851) Those who have not been able to go so far bear with their additional needs as something they cannot help and strive to give up as many of them as they can.

('31', 471, 1, 19, 1094099) We have tried hard to cultivate the spirit of self denial in the Ashram, but our efforts have not met with much success.
('31', 471, 1, 20, 1094220) This having been my experience, I do not have the courage to ask others to undertake far reaching experiments.
('31', 471, 1, 21, 1094331) Would it not be better, then, if I asked those who are not yet ready for the ideal of service to come forward only after they have trained themselves for it?
('31', 471, 1, 22, 1094489) This cannot always be done in the field of public work.

('31', 471, 1, 24, 1094617) But where the aim is the attainment of a particular object, we should get the work done without violating any moral principles through any workers we can get.
('31', 471, 1, 25, 1094776) One of our aims is to educate Antyaja children.
('31', 471, 1, 26, 1094824) It would be best if we could get teachers imbued with the spirit of self sacrifice.

('31', 471, 1, 29, 1095097) For this purpose, we may certainly employ workers of good character who cannot live in poverty, to the extent that our resources permit.
('31', 471, 1, 30, 1095234) In trying to gain everything, we run the risk of losing everything.

('31', 472, 1, 2, 1095344) If we regard poverty as one of our ideals, it is my view, based on experience, that we shall reach it ultimately while working for the other aims.
('31', 472, 1, 3, 1095491) The same argument holds good about tea, etc.
('31', 472, 1, 4, 1095536) It is not our aim at present to reform people’s dietary habits.

('31', 472, 1, 7, 1095740) This world is a strange place.
('31', 472, 1, 8, 1095771) Some of us want to go through it without being caught up in all manner of enslaving concerns.

('31', 472, 1, 12, 1096077) They believe that without crossing it they cannot attain moksha.
('31', 472, 1, 13, 1096142) But everyone does not accept this meaning of swaraj.
('31', 472, 1, 14, 1096195) Even so, the swaraj they want is included in the conception of swaraj explained above and, therefore, the seekers after moksha are unable to forgo their co operation.
('31', 472, 1, 15, 1096362) There are some others who are not interested in swaraj at all but to whom the spinning wheel is everything.
('31', 472, 1, 16, 1096470) Though millionaires, they have accepted spinning as a sacred duty.
('31', 472, 1, 17, 1096537) They want to end the poverty of the country.
('31', 472, 1, 18, 1096582) Those seekers after moksha want to keep these last, too, with them, for the spinning wheel is an essential part of the swaraj which they want.
('31', 472, 1, 19, 1096725) The seekers after moksha journey on, accepting whatever sacrifices people are ready to make, and thus lighten their burden in the initial stages of their journey.
('31', 472, 1, 20, 1096888) I wish that no one should draw wrong conclusions from my reply.
('31', 472, 1, 21, 1096952) I should be very happy to get a band of workers dedicated to poverty, I know that the coming of swaraj would be very much hastened if we had such a band of workers.
('31', 472, 1, 22, 1097117) Individual workers should always bear this in mind.
('31', 472, 1, 23, 1097169) But at the same time, we should also remember our weaknesses and shortcomings.
('31', 472, 1, 24, 1097248) The path we follow is the path of love.
('31', 472, 1, 25, 1097288) We may be strict with ourselves, but should be correspondingly liberal in our attitude to others.
('31', 472, 1, 26, 1097386) That is the way of non violence.
('31', 472, 1, 27, 1097419) Our sacrifice should never make us proud.
('31', 472, 1, 28, 1097461) We should not be critical of the lesser sacrifices of others.
('31', 472, 1, 29, 1097523) It happens sometimes that a man carrying a load of five maunds may yet be a miser about his strength while a man carrying one maund draws upon all the strength he has.
('31', 472, 1, 30, 1097691) Between the two, the honest worker is the one who carries one maund.
('31', 472, 1, 31, 1097760) Hence, instead of sitting in judgment over others, we should examine our own record, use all our strength to force sacrifices from ourselves and, banishing uncharitable thoughts, accept with love whatever sacrifices others make.

('31', 473, 2, 12, 1099055) 299. MY DUTY One gentleman writes : 1 We see in this letter, for one thing, an error which most people fall into.
('31', 473, 2, 13, 1099169) It illustrates our fond notion that big results can be achieved by preaching to people.

('31', 473, 2, 18, 1099659) If he preaches more than what he himself puts into practice, his preaching has no effect—such is the magic power of truth.

('31', 475, 2, 8, 1103904) 300. LETTER TO KHWAJA ABDUL MAJID
('31', 475, 3, 9, 1103938) June 14, 1925 MY DEAR KHWAJA SAHEB, Panditji 1 has written to me about you and sent me your letter to him.
('31', 475, 3, 10, 1104045) You must not saddle the whole responsibility on me.
('31', 475, 3, 11, 1104097) I am but a humble co worker with you about the Jamia.

('31', 475, 3, 13, 1104198) If you consider that consistently with the interest of the Jamia, you can and should contest the Council of State election, you should not hesitate to say and do as you feel.
('31', 475, 3, 14, 1104373) I have simply given my opinion of what I should do in your place.
('31', 475, 3, 15, 1104439) If you must consult friends, you should consult Hakimji, Dr. Ansari and if you don’t mind, the Ali Brothers.
('31', 475, 3, 16, 1104548) As a matter of fact I am no judge in this matter.
('31', 475, 3, 17, 1104598) But you and the other friends must know the thing better than I ever can.
('31', 475, 3, 18, 1104672) Whatever you do, let it be your decision and not mine, please.
('31', 475, 3, 19, 1104735) My regards to you and Khurshed Begum.

('31', 476, 1, 2, 1105044) 301. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BARISAL 1
('31', 476, 2, 3, 1105085) June 14, 1925
('31', 476, 3, 4, 1105099) In a joint reply Mr. Gandhi said that, when he visited the place last time, he found Aswini Kumar Dutta, though not in the best of health, yet, alive.
('31', 476, 3, 5, 1105250) He was an extraordinary man, with innumerable qualities, a man who founded a number of institutions.
('31', 476, 3, 6, 1105351) He suffered for the country and made wonderful sacrifices.
('31', 476, 4, 7, 1105410) Mr. Gandhi thought it their bounden duty to perpetuate the memory of a man of that character, but he was sorry to hear that attempts made to collect money to perpetuate his memory had not been crowned with success.
('31', 476, 4, 8, 1105625) He had heard with regret that sufficient funds had not been collected.
('31', 476, 4, 9, 1105696) He recollected vividly all that he had seen at Barisal on the last occasion and regretted that the Ali Brothers were not with him this time.
('31', 476, 4, 10, 1105837) He was not satisfied with the charkhas, though he was pleased to hear from reports that yarns produced in the district were much better than those of other districts.
('31', 476, 5, 11, 1106004) Mr Gandhi appealed to the people to follow the Belgaum Conrgess resolution and to show a brighter record in the near future.
('31', 476, 5, 12, 1106129) He was pleased to note that the question of untouchability was not so acute in Barisal as in Madras and that Hindu Muslim relations had not reached a deplorable state.
('31', 476, 5, 13, 1106297) The Hindu, 16 6 1925
('31', 476, 6, 14, 1106318) 302. REMARKS TO FATHER STRONG
('31', 476, 7, 15, 1106348) [June 14, 1925]
('31', 476, 8, 16, 1106364) Father Strong of the Oxford Mission had invited Gandhiji to call on them and inspect their weaving.
('31', 476, 8, 17, 1106464) He paid a flying visit, and Father Strong showed him over the weaving shed.
('31', 476, 8, 18, 1106540) Gandhiji said to him : But this is all mill yarn and if you use mill yarns you do not benefit the millions, but the millionaires.
('31', 476, 8, 19, 1106670) Weaving cannot be a cottage industry for the millions.
('31', 476, 8, 20, 1106725) For them the only supplementary occu pation can be spinning.
('31', 476, 8, 21, 1106786) According to Lord Curzon, the annual aver age income of an Indian was 30 rupees, according to our cal culation it is 26. And if it is the average income of the masses exclu ding the classes, the actual would be much less.
('31', 476, 8, 22, 1107008) Now if by spinning you can add 10 rupees to this, would it not be a fortune to them?
('31', 476, 8, 23, 1107093) You may not miss 5 rupees, but to those who have nothing, 5 rupees is a fortune.

('31', 477, 4, 10, 1107914) 304. LETTER TO MOTILAL NEHRU BARISAL, June 15, 1925 DEAR PANDITJI, I was distressed to learn from your letter of relapse and Jawahar’s fever.

('31', 477, 4, 17, 1108432) It may be reformed, if it has become bad, but in my opinion it must not be allowed to die for want of care.

('31', 479, 1, 2, 1111250) 306. LETTER TO SARAT CHANDRA BOSE
('31', 479, 2, 3, 1111284) June 15, 1925
('31', 479, 3, 4, 1111298) MY DEAR SARAT BABU, I am glad you at once understand that another meeting could only be treated as a counter demonstration.
('31', 479, 3, 5, 1111422) Non violence is love.
('31', 479, 3, 6, 1111444) It works silently, almost secretly.
('31', 479, 3, 7, 1111480) Hence the saying: the right hand knoweth not what the left is giving.
('31', 479, 3, 8, 1111550) Love has no play as between friends and relatives.
('31', 479, 3, 9, 1111601) These love one another from selfishness, not from enlightenment.
('31', 479, 3, 10, 1111666) It has play only as between opponents so called.
('31', 479, 3, 11, 1111715) It demands, therefore, the highest charity and all the chivalry one is capable of showing towards those who oppose or persecute one.
('31', 479, 3, 12, 1111848) In the light of the above please consider and answer the following charges they brought against you yesterday after you had left.
('31', 479, 4, 13, 1111978) I find it impossible to believe any of the charges.
('31', 479, 4, 14, 1112030) You need not answer them now.
('31', 479, 4, 15, 1112060) You may do so when I call on you.
('31', 479, 4, 16, 1112094) But if you would give a categorical answer in writing, you may do so.
('31', 479, 5, 17, 1112164) Yours sincerely,
('31', 479, 6, 18, 1112181) M. K. G. From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('31', 479, 6, 19, 1112236) Courtesy : Narayan Desai
('31', 479, 7, 20, 1112261) 307. COMMENTS ON A LETTER 2
('31', 479, 8, 21, 1112289) [Before June 16, 1925] I have much pleasure in printing the foregoing as received.
('31', 479, 8, 22, 1112372) Sardar Jogendra Singh has written from the depth of his heart.
('31', 479, 8, 23, 1112435) I value his advice.
('31', 479, 8, 24, 1112455) I have a vivid recollection of the conversation referred to by the Sardarji.
('31', 479, 8, 25, 1112532) He questions the advisability of my having entered into the agreement with the Swarajists.
('31', 479, 8, 26, 1112623) 3 Nine months have nearly gone by since it was entered into.
('31', 479, 8, 27, 1112684) But I have seen no reason to repent of the agreement.
('31', 479, 8, 28, 1112738) I have sacrificed no principle.
('31', 479, 8, 29, 1112770) The Congress is no preserve
('31', 479, 9, 30, 1112798) 1 In the source here follows a sentence, obviously by Mahadev Desai, which reads: Here follow charges about hindering even constructive work, vilifying Congress members, collecting yarn without authority, refusal to deliver Congress furniture, etc.

('31', 480, 0, 1, 1113312) VOL.31 : 22 MARCH, 1924 15 JUNE, 1925 481
('31', 480, 1, 2, 1113354) of any single individual.
('31', 480, 1, 3, 1113380) It is a democratic body with, in my opinion, the widest intelligent franchise the world has ever seen.
('31', 480, 1, 4, 1113483) For it gives statutory recognition to the dignity of labour.
('31', 480, 1, 5, 1113544) I wish it was the sole test.
('31', 480, 1, 6, 1113573) It accommodates all shades of opinion save violence and untruth.
('31', 480, 1, 7, 1113638) The Swarajists had a perfect right of enforcing their will by a battle of votes.
('31', 480, 1, 8, 1113719) I was unprepared for it; for I have known the voting power to demoralize the people, especially when the electorate has not been accustomed to use independent judgment.
('31', 480, 1, 9, 1113888) I was bound as a sane man to recognize the growing power of the Swarajists.
('31', 480, 1, 10, 1113964) They were willing to give the predominant place to the constructive programme.
('31', 480, 1, 11, 1114043) More could not be expected from them.
('31', 480, 1, 12, 1114081) If I had forced them to the vote, they might not only have made Council entry the national pro gramme, but they might, in the heat of battle, have even thrown overboard the constructive programme or relegated it to an insignificant place.
('31', 480, 1, 13, 1114320) So much for the principle.
('31', 480, 1, 14, 1114347) In practice the agreement has largely laid to rest the acerbity between Pro changers and No changers.
('31', 480, 1, 15, 1114449) It has enabled both to work the joint programme in tolerable harmony.
('31', 480, 1, 16, 1114519) I witness the benefits of the pact in the South.
('31', 480, 1, 17, 1114568) I witness them in Bengal.
('31', 480, 1, 18, 1114594) I do not share the opinion that Swarajists have failed.
('31', 480, 1, 19, 1114650) I do not attach much importance to promises made at the hustings.
('31', 480, 1, 20, 1114716) It is the tacitly recognized law that like promises made at marriage, those made at election times must not be taken too seriously.
('31', 480, 1, 21, 1114848) Once grant the premise that Council entry is not wholly bad, the Swarajists have nothing to be ashamed of about their achievements.
('31', 480, 1, 22, 1114980) They have spoken fearlessly in the Council halls; they have outvoted the Government; they have shown that the Government does not enjoy the confidence even of the electorate of its own creating; they have shown a discipline and solidarity hitherto unknown among Councillors and above all (for me at least), they have introduced khaddar in these forbidden places and have not been afraid to appear in their daily national costume which, at one time, as if we were ashamed or afraid of it, we wore only in our homes.
('31', 480, 1, 23, 1115495) Have not the proceedings of the Swarajists set the Government a thinking?
('31', 480, 1, 24, 1115569) It is true that the latter has flouted public opinion.
('31', 480, 1, 25, 1115624) It is true that it has gone its way in the face of hostile votes.
('31', 480, 1, 26, 1115690) The Swarajists could not help it.
('31', 480, 1, 27, 1115724) If they had the power behind, they would have dislodged the Government and dared it to defy their vote.
('31', 480, 1, 28, 1115828) That power has still to come.
('31', 480, 1, 29, 1115858) It is coming slowly but surely.
('31', 480, 1, 30, 1115890) The Government knows that it dare not act against public opinion for all time.
('31', 480, 1, 31, 1115969) The Swarajists have made it feel more than before the weakness of its position.
('31', 480, 1, 32, 1116049) I have political differences with them, but their bravery, discipline, patriotism command my admiration.
('31', 480, 1, 33, 1116154) And I should do all in my power consistently with my principles to help and strengthen them.
('31', 480, 1, 34, 1116247) I remain
('31', 481, 0, 1, 1116256) 482 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 481, 1, 2, 1116298) as the head of the Congress only so long as it pleases them to keep me there.
('31', 481, 1, 3, 1116376) Where I cannot help, I must resolutely refuse to hinder.
('31', 481, 1, 4, 1116433) For me personally, non violent non co operation is creed.
('31', 481, 1, 5, 1116491) I heartily endorse the Sardarji’s statement that Non co operation is co operation in essence and stronger than the might of armies.
('31', 481, 1, 6, 1116623) And if I could convert but the major part of educated India to my view, swaraj can be had without further effort.
('31', 481, 1, 7, 1116737) The conviction is daily growing stronger that there is no peace for India, and indeed for the world, save through non violence.
('31', 481, 1, 8, 1116865) For me, therefore, the spinning wheel is not merely a symbol of simplicity and economic freedom but it is also a symbol of peace.
('31', 481, 1, 9, 1116995) For if we, Hindus, Mussalmans, Sikhs, Christians, Parsis and Jews unite in achieving the universalization of the wheel in India, we shall not only have arrived at real unity and exclusion of foreign cloth, but we shall also have acquired self confidence and organizing ability which render violence wholly unnecessary for regaining our freedom.
('31', 481, 1, 10, 1117340) Success of the charkha to me, therefore, means victory of non violence, such as to serve as an object lesson for the whole world.
('31', 481, 1, 11, 1117470) The Sardarji advises the introduction of electric power in the villages side by side with the charkha.
('31', 481, 1, 12, 1117573) I fear he knows only a few villages of the Punjab.
('31', 481, 1, 13, 1117624) If he knew the life of all India, as I claim to do, he would not write of electricity with the assurance he does.
('31', 481, 1, 14, 1117738) In the present state of India, anything like a universal introduction of electric power in our villages is an utterly impracticable proposition.
('31', 481, 1, 15, 1117883) That time may come.
('31', 481, 1, 16, 1117903) But it will not before the charkha occupies an abiding place in every home.
('31', 481, 1, 17, 1117979) I am anxious, therefore, to avoid fogging the public by raising side or false issue and false hopes.
('31', 481, 1, 18, 1118080) Even if the charkha means no more than what the Sardarji says or implies, we must concentrate upon it and it alone till we have made it a success.
('31', 481, 1, 19, 1118227) And when through it we have made the lives of the villagers livable and have provided them with honourable and profitable work during the slack season, all the things that should be added to make them happier will follow as a matter of course.
('31', 481, 1, 20, 1118471) Let me assure the Sardarji that I am not against machinery as such.
('31', 481, 1, 21, 1118539) The charkha itself, for that matter, is machinery.
('31', 481, 1, 22, 1118590) But I am a deter mined foe of all machinery that is designed for exploitation of people.
('31', 481, 1, 23, 1118679) The Sardarji need not entertain any fear of Englishmen being excluded from the circle of unity.
('31', 481, 1, 24, 1118775) For it includes everyone who chooses to call himself an Indian, whether by birth or adoption.
('31', 481, 1, 25, 1118869) It includes all denominations and all races.
('31', 481, 1, 26, 1118914) Nor is the combination intended to be hostile to any nation or individuals, not even a Dyer.
('31', 481, 1, 27, 1119007) For it seeks to convert, not to destroy.

('31', 482, 2, 3, 1119124) APPENDIX I
('31', 482, 3, 4, 1119135) LETTER FROM JOGENDRA SINGH
('31', 482, 4, 5, 1119162) I feel diffident in writing to you about matters which have been engaging your
('31', 482, 5, 6, 1119241) mind and heart night and day all these years.
('31', 482, 5, 7, 1119287) Indeed, I confess I have hardly any claim
('31', 482, 6, 8, 1119329) to hazard an opinion except that I have been in close touch with life and few people in
('31', 482, 7, 9, 1119417) the political world know the villages, as I do, which make real India.
('31', 482, 7, 10, 1119488) A voice from the
('31', 482, 8, 11, 1119505) villages may be of some use to you in reaching realities.
('31', 482, 9, 12, 1119563) I had the pleasure of meeting you, in Lahore, many years ago, with Mr. Padshah.
('31', 482, 9, 13, 1119643) We discussed the economics of charkha and power driven machines.
('31', 482, 9, 14, 1119708) I disagreed with your view.
('31', 482, 9, 15, 1119736) I still feel that human nature in itself is not capable of working above and beyond the surrounding environment and the environment now embraces the whole world; none the less, I admit that if human nature could find illumination for a while, simple living and high thinking point the surest road to happiness.
('31', 482, 9, 16, 1120047) I also see that if men learn to co operate against things which they dislike and accept self suffering, they can enforce their will wielding compelling powers without incurring the risk of devastations which follow wars and revolutions.
('31', 482, 10, 17, 1120284) God entrusted you with a message, a message of freedom based on goodwill, ensuring peace; saving civilization from committing hara kiri by exploiting forces
('31', 482, 11, 18, 1120441) of nature without cultivating necessary discipline and moral restraint which from time immemorial has been held essential in the East.
('31', 482, 11, 19, 1120576) Give your message and time will carry it to the hearts of men.
('31', 482, 11, 20, 1120639) The love of your motherland calls you to apply your principles to the pressing problems of the day; you have been even persuaded to permit others to test a policy of pacts and compromises which appeal to the politicians more than the uncompromising pursuit of truth.
('31', 482, 11, 21, 1120906) They have been at it for a long while seeking to weld the people together by an agreed distribution of loaves and fishes and hoping to secure swaraj by constant obstruction in the Legislatures.
('31', 482, 11, 22, 1121100) Failure has been pursuing these efforts from the start.
('31', 482, 11, 23, 1121156) I wonder if the leaders are disenchanted.
('31', 482, 11, 24, 1121198) In any case pursue your own path, it is your dharma.
('31', 482, 11, 25, 1121251) You and they cannot walk the same road for long.
('31', 482, 11, 26, 1121300) The great work before you is to confine yourself to the essentials; prove that non co operation is co operation in essence and stronger than the might of armies, that non co operation is co operation of righteous men to overcome the unrighteous in a spirit of tolerance and goodwill, accepting self suffering to awaken an understanding in the opponents.
('31', 482, 11, 27, 1121654) India needs it, but more than India Europe needs it, and indeed the whole world needs it.
('31', 482, 11, 28, 1121744) This alone can give the League of Nations strength to enforce its will.
('31', 482, 11, 29, 1121816) This alone can confer power on unarmed nations to assert their manhood and to keep their places in the sun.
('31', 483, 0, 1, 1121924) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('31', 483, 1, 2, 1121966) alone can dispel darkness which drives nations into wars, in search of supremacy at the sacrifice of protection and peace.
('31', 483, 1, 3, 1122089) The new world waits for this new message; proclaim it with all the power that God has given you.
('31', 483, 2, 4, 1122186) The problem of food is as important as the problem of peace.
('31', 483, 2, 5, 1122247) When you placed charkha on the banner of your flag you raised the symbol of economic independence of nations great and small.
('31', 483, 2, 6, 1122373) Happiness is not to be found in wild pursuit of pleasure and possessions and unlimited production.
('31', 483, 2, 7, 1122472) These feed the flames of desire.
('31', 483, 2, 8, 1122505) Let each householder produce what he needs and then what he cannot produce let him procure from his neighbour in and outside the bounds of his own land.
('31', 483, 2, 9, 1122658) Let trade be an exchange of things, not wild exploitation by one nation of the other; an organized competition which must fail unless saved by a large hearted readjustment of economic relations of the world.
('31', 483, 2, 10, 1122866) Let charkha be as a symbol for practical purposes; we must modernize the village bringing electric power to its service, to weave cloth, to pump water, to press oil and to do a thousand other services which some of our congested villages need to secure enough food and clothing.
('31', 483, 2, 11, 1123145) You cannot be altogether unaware that no country can entirely escape the influence of the new age; an age of magic and machinery, ruled by new inventions and human nature.
('31', 483, 2, 12, 1123317) You can place new inventions in the hands of the village worker in his own home, you can transfuse a divine sense of service to elevate human nature.
('31', 483, 2, 13, 1123467) You can inculcate ethics of work, love and labour by reviving the system of kathas, to keep alive ideals and traditions which have
('31', 483, 3, 14, 1123598) saved India through centuries of unfavouring circumstances.
('31', 483, 4, 15, 1123658) The great problem you have set your hand to is to bring harmony between Hindus and Mussalmans.
('31', 483, 4, 16, 1123753) I am sure you will not exclude Englishmen from this great concord of hearts and minds.
('31', 483, 4, 17, 1123840) I fear you have been exploring the possibilities of pacts and political arrangement against your better reason and agreed to let your friends try the methods with which they are familiar.
('31', 483, 4, 18, 1124028) They have failed and you can now turn round and tell them to let you go your own way.
('31', 483, 4, 19, 1124114) You may not be followed today but truth shall conquer.
('31', 483, 4, 20, 1124169) Light up the flame of understanding by your example transfiguring unity by living it.
('31', 483, 4, 21, 1124255) No one can do more.
('31', 483, 4, 22, 1124275) Hindus and Mussalmans who have their eye on the main chance repeat the creed without conviction.
('31', 483, 4, 23, 1124372) They will never find unity.
('31', 483, 4, 24, 1124400) They want places of power.
